PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, as Manager of Opposition Business in the House I would like to raise concerns about what occurred last night which we think goes to the question of the privileges and entitlements of members in this House to be heard. On three occasions in the debate last night, where we had circulated a number of amendments in relation to the establishment of committees in this House, two different deputy speakers in the chair ignored the call on our side of the House. They did not see our side of the House, despite the fact, in our view, that those speakers were clearly in view and on their feet before the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) was subsequently called.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two matters of privilege associated with this, Mr Speaker: firstly, members are not being given the opportunity they should to speak in this House and, in our view, the chair is not recognising as it should the call of speakers on this side of the House; secondly, the issues in question go to the very functioning of this House and the committee structure.

I simply raise this issue with you, Mr Speaker, and ask you to think about it. I indicate to you that, if this practice continues, we on this side of the House will have to look at what other options exist to consider our position and to seek redress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to speak on the purported point of privilege that the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) has just raised. The conditions and the circumstances of privilege in this place are laid down—

—I know the right honourable member for New England has been in the place a long time and thinks that he knows it all. I did not rise on a point of privilege. I sought indulgence, which was extended to me, and indicated that the point that I was raising under indulgence went to matters including the privileges of members of this House.

—Mr Speaker, that just illustrates what I was about to say: the member for Hotham rose apparently on an indulgence. He did not, in the last instance, raise a point of order. If it were a point of order, it should relate specifically to our standing orders. I would suggest to you, Mr Speaker, that while he might well seek that members of the opposition be recognised, it is certainly not a matter of privilege, which I understood him to be asserting, whether or not members are called on one side of the chamber or the other. If matters pertaining to people who are to be called are to be recognised, it is strictly a matter of who the chair recognises.

SPEECH.PARA: As one who sat for 13 years in opposition, including in front of one now in the House who is a former Speaker of this place, I can assure the honourable gentleman that the discretion as to who is called should and does remain entirely in that person who, for the time being, is in the chair of this place. I suggest to him that the point he has just raised is entirely frivolous and is quite contrary to the practice that he and his colleagues asserted through that time they were in government. I suggest we get on with the business of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask leave of the House to move a motion relating to the appointment of a Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies. By way of explanation, last night I leapt up like a rocket to seek the call, beating the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), I would say, by at least a half‐head, but the Leader of the House got the call and the result was that the adjournment was put through. So I ask leave to move a motion relating to the appointment of a Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is not granted. I will respond to the point made by the member for Hotham. I watched the proceedings with some considerable interest last night. In light of the fact that there were a large number of divisions, there was a great deal of milling as members moved from one side of the House to the other. I remind all members that the allocation of the call is a matter for the discretion of the chair. Standing order 61 provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . the Speaker shall call upon the Member who, in the Speaker's opinion, first rose in his or her place—

It is sometimes difficult for the occupant of the chair to determine who rose first. I think that was the case a number of times last night. In a close call, we do not have the benefit of a photo‐finish facility, although some of the racing enthusiasts in our midst might want to extend some of the paraphernalia already in the House. The decision of the chair can be challenged but it must be challenged immediately and not subsequently as it was done last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I take this opportunity to extend to you my congratulations on your ascension to this chair.
—It won't do you any good.

—If you don't agree, just shut up. Mr Speaker, I do that with sincerity. We have worked together over a number of years and I have appreciated the integrity of your actions in respect of members. I look forward to that continuing integrity. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Lalor moving forthwith for the appointment of a committee to examine long term strategies for the future.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading debate on the Shipping Grants Legislation Bill came before the House last night. This legislation does not really have regard for the future of the Australian shipping industry or to Australia's national and international shipping interests. In a few words, this is treacherous legislation. It is legislation that is designed to destroy the Australian shipping industry, to give substantial advantage to foreign shipping interests that service this nation and to destroy Australian seafarers' jobs and damage their families. It has been put forward without any regard whatsoever to the impact that it will have upon the Australian shipping industry and upon shareholders and investors in the Australian shipping industry. I will return later to the impact it will have upon the Australian sugar industry, but Mackay Sugar is going to suffer a great deal if this legislation passes through the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The substance of this legislation is that it will remove the cash grants or capital assistance to Australian shipowners on the purchase of vessels, it will remove accelerated depreciation and it will remove the rebate of the PAYE tax payments by Australian seafarers where ships spend most of their time in international trades. It will remove the rebate of those PAYE payments to the Australian shipowners. In other words, where an Australian ship is operating for the majority of its time and spending the majority of its activity in international trades, then the PAYE deductions from seafarers on that ship—which are currently being rebated to the shipowner—will go straight back into the Australian Taxation Office and straight back into consolidated revenue. It will be a substantial disadvantage to the Australian shipowner.

It is interesting, almost farcical, that this so-called saving, set out in the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), will not be a saving to Australian revenue. Ultimately, it will mean that, if the government is successful in what it is about, Australian seafarers will be substituted by foreign seafarers. Australian seafarers' earnings and tax payments, which are being collected from them now, will disappear and we will have foreign seafarers who will be accounting for their income abroad. As the shadow minister, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), said last night in his speech, it is not a saving; it is an illusion and will cause considerable damage to the Australian shipping industry.

What is the background to this legislation? The background is a longstanding vendetta, particularly by the National Party and some shippers, against Australian seafarers, against the Maritime Union of Australia and against the trade union movement. There were repeated misrepresentations by the minister, when he was in opposition, about the effect and the beneficiaries of the PAYE section of the legislation. He repeatedly referred to it, as did the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) last evening, as a rort, as a benefit, for Australian seafarers. That is a blatant falsity, and they know it to be that. But they have peddled that line because it suits some of their constituents. They have peddled that line when they know full well that the rebate of the PAYE deductions goes to the shipowners in the circumstances that I outlined earlier.

In this parliament of Australia we have a situation now where the minister responsible for the Australian shipping industry and Australia's shipping interests internationally is the champion of foreign shipowners. It is very clear from this legislation, and it is very clear from his repeated utterances, that his priority is the protection and the benefiting of foreign shipowners. It is an incredible situation.

PARA.BREAK: Recently, the minister has taken on as his maritime adviser none other than the former executive director of the Australian Chamber of Shipping. The Australian Chamber of Shipping, as was pointed out last evening, is the lobby group for foreign shipping interests in this country. Could you possibly imagine a situation where the European Commission—or the German minister for transport, the Japanese minister for transport or the minister for transport of any other country that has a sense of national involvement and pride—took on to their staff the adviser of foreign shipping to advise them on domestic ship ping? It is an incredible situation. I believe that it is without parallel.

SPEECH.PARA: I get on very well with the former executive director of the Australian Chamber of Shipping—we have been friends for many years—but there is a direct conflict of interest here. It is an intolerable situation where that gentleman has now been taken on to provide advice to the Australian Minister for Transport and Regional Development on shipping policy. It is an intolerable and an incredible situation.

What is the policy of other countries on this issue? They see—as some of us, certainly on this side of the House and most of the Australian industry, see—that there is a major multiplier effect in having a strong shipping industry. The actual number of seafarers and the work of seafarers is a minor part of the operation, but it is the crucial link. Control and development of your own shipping industry generates thousands upon thousands of jobs ashore in related activities. Let me quote from a document from the Commission of the European Communities entitled Shaping Europe's maritime future: A contribution to the competitiveness of maritime industries, Brussels, 13, March 1996, page 2:

In issuing this Communication, the Commission intends to demonstrate its conviction that the maritime industries are essentially an industrial sector with a high potential for growth, development and technological improvement. Exploiting this potential will contribute to job creation across the Union.

The largest market in the world and the oldest shipping nations in the world are subscribers to that document. That document has been adopted by the commission, referred to the European parliament and is under consideration by the members of the European Union.

We can go on from that and look at the Australian Maritime Network. The Australian Maritime Network is a voluntary group of people who are interested in furthering the development of shipping related activities ashore and the shipping industry itself. The list includes: shipowners, ship operators, managers, maritime transport unions, port authorities, terminal operators, customs agents, crewing agents, ship repair and ship building design, ship chandlers, maritime education, professional maritime associations, maritime media, maritime insurance, P&O clubs, arbitrators, adjusters and lawyers. There is a whole gamut of shore activities, and most of them are professional and administrative jobs. They are all activities which swing from the operation of ships.

What other strong shipping nations know, and what the European Commission has confirmed in that document from which I have just quoted, is that they all depend upon having a strong shipping industry. The British suffered under the Thatcher government from the destruction of their shipping industry. Britain: Britannia rules the waves, the greatest shipping fleets in the world, the ones that used to control shipping services into this country. The Thatcher government in the 1980s set about the destruction of the British shipping industry. As stated in an article headed `British shipowners do it tough, says study', the realisation has now come to that:

. . . Britain has one of the least attractive fiscal regimes in Europe. By comparison, Sweden and Belgium have fiscal regimes that are three times more favourable, with France and Germany not that far behind.
The article goes on to refer to London. It states:
London remains the world's premier maritime centre.
But then it adds that it was:
. . . also disclosed that the city's maritime net overseas earnings (excluding shipping itself), are, at £1 billion a year, lower by 25 per cent compared to the level of revenue ten years ago.
The comparison those figures make are pre the Thatcher destruction, before Thatcher got in with the kinds of policies that this legislation entails.

What we are seeing here is a throwback to Thatcherism. They have picked up what Thatcher did, read about it some years ago, absorbed it—and cannot forget it. They do not seem to recognise what has happened in Europe since then. Now the Brits are fighting, trying to regain their industry. They are trying to regain their industry because of the substantial shore related benefits, jobs and activities that flow from it. That article also states:

BREAK.PARA: UK shipowners continue to campaign for the restoration of the special capital allowances which the government removed in 1984.

That article from which I was quoting is dated May 1996. Then there is another article dated 13 May 1996 and headed `The city of London's maritime‐related earnings have declined in real terms by one‐third between 1984 and 1994'. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can go on looking at that those comparisons.

Norway with 4¼ million people, one per cent of world GDP, controls 10 per cent of world shipping. Why? Because they are smart enough and have the wisdom to know, to realise, that there are 70,000 shore jobs swinging off control of that shipping. They do not have to own it but control it. That is the line we should be following, and that is the line we are arguing in this chamber here today.

This legislation is borne out of a longstanding animosity towards Australian seafarers and their families. It is really a throwback to the Peter Nixon days, to the old adversarial situation: hit the unions, fight the unions—from your predecessor. Take that dorothy dixer of 20 items denigrating waterside workers. The role of a minister—and I say this to the Minister for Transport—primarily is to solve problems, not create them; to weld people together, to weld industries together—workers and leadership and management—not to divide them. This is divisive, confrontationist legislation designed to destroy seafarers and their unions and it is the first attack upon the trade union movement.

Behind this is the advice coming from top level Treasury and Finance bureaucrats. I mention just one name, that of David Borthwick, so that it goes into Hansard. At some time this is going to have to be sheeted home to these people who sit safe and comfortably in the cloistered havens of Treasury. Those Treasury and Finance bureaucrats do not have to compete with international consultants working for low wages, seven-day weeks, a one-month holiday a year with no international holiday trips at taxpayers' expense. They are comfortable and safe there. They have no competition in their jobs from international consultants.

We should put a lot of that Treasury work out to the international marketplace and let those bureaucrats face up to the consequences. If we utilise the international market, we create a more level playing field, don't we. But let us do it in the area of economics advice and we will see the situation then, when the mistakes are brought out into the open—not buried away, as Mr Borthwick and his colleagues are able to do.

Let me mention one very quick instance. I became Assistant Treasurer. I went over to Treasury for a briefing. We had a cup of tea with a few biscuits, and talked. It was sparse; I do not want to create the impression of too much luxury over there. They were just plain biscuits with cups of tea and a bit of milk. One of the very senior officers sidled up to me and said, `Minister, this waterfront, now what sorts of problems are there with it? Of what kind of magnitude are they? Are there really problems on the waterfront?' I looked at him and I was speechless.

Here were the people who were at the most senior level advising government, the weight of whose advice is probably a hundred times the weight of any other department's, and they were asking me about the waterfront! I thought they might have read a report or found something. But that is the kind of advice which is coming forward. Those people are totally inadequate. That link with the people who are determined upon a course of trade union destruction and animosity towards the unions brings forward this kind of legislation.

What we see in the legislation is a betrayal of the Australian industry. It is in conflict with the former member for Gwydir, Ralph Hunt. Back in 1982 Ralph Hunt started the legislation which arose from the Crawford report. He was the one National Party minister for transport who had the wisdom to realise that the solution to these problems is to bring people together, understand them, make room for that understanding and get people working together.

When I took it on from there, we brought about tremendous reform in the industry. Not one hour was lost through dispute. It was a consensus approach, a recognition by people working in the industry that they had to make a contribution, they had to accept change—but then the government had to support them, the country had to support them and there had to be investment. There has been $2 billion worth of investment over the period since in the Australian shipping industry. It is a young fleet; its average age is about nine years.

What this government wants in this legislation—no matter what the words are which come from the other side—is Australian ships off the coast, out of the business, and foreign ships in. That is what it wants. I warn those opposite, I warn them now: you do that, and you accept responsibility for a repetition of the Kirki incident, for the dangers you are going to create for the Australian coastal environment and in Australian ports.

I am not being an alarmist. I will show you the figures from abroad. The European Commission—the largest shipping market in the world, with most of the maritime nations within it—has determined that the greatest danger to the coastal environment comes from substandard shipping. Why is substandard shipping there? Why does this government want it? It is because those organisations that operate substandard ships can get a 13‐ to 15 per cent saving on operational costs by using those substandard ships and avoiding international safety obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —And taxation obligations.

—Most of the taxation rorts relate to tax havens and to the avoidance of the standards that legitimate operators have to meet. Government members are trying to tell us that they will make sure the Australian Maritime Safety Authority will have sufficient resources to ensure that all of these ships are inspected. We recommended in Ships of shame: A sequel , which was released in December last year, that all single voyage permit vessels be inspected prior to loading cargo in this country. I have not got time to go into the details of that. The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) will touch on some of that.

BREAK.PARA: The A.P.J. Annand was one of the worst ships ever to come to this coast. It had a single voyage permit and carried wheat for the Wheat Board. The carriage of that wheat means the Australian Wheat Board is one of the major offenders in this country. The board does not carry out its obligations to ensure that the vessels it charters are up to international maritime safety standards.

You will see more vessels like that. The Nanda Rati is one of them. Those vessels come here, and there is no way in the world that those sitting opposite can ensure that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority has the required resources to carry out adequate inspections of all of them.

There was one good thing in the favour of the member for Corangamite: he strongly supported the committee's report. I want the honourable member to assure us that he will stand by the recommendations of that report and make sure that these ships are not brought to our coast in that manner. You know what is involved. You have been a party to this inquiry.

Let us turn to BHP. BHP is dramatically disadvantaged by this legislation. It has made a commitment for a new vessel. Mackay Sugar has made a commitment for a special technically designed vessel for the loading and packaging of sugar. It will be affected by this legislation's retrospectivity. The retrospectivity was recognised by Senator Hill in the other place a few days ago on 20 May. He recognised Mr Justice Wells's judgment on retrospectivity. Senator Hill said:
. . . I am pretty much in accord with what you have read out, Senator.
I will not take up the time of the House by reading the rest of what is on page 701 of the Senate Hansard . As Senator Bob Collins said on page 722 of the Hansard :
BHP, Shell and Mackay Sugar have all contracted the construction of very large and important vessels to the Australian fleet.

Mackay Sugar has a unique vessel. Mackay Sugar, which is in the electorate of Dawson, will be in diabolical trouble if this legislation gets through. Where are the National Party members? This is legislation put forward by a National Party minister. It is his legislation, but that is what the effect of it will be. I have not got time to read the rest of what Senator Collins said, but I recommend that members read pages 701 and 722 of the Senate Hansard .

When Mr Hockridge, the manager of BHP Transport, was before the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee a few nights ago, he made the point that, even if the crew on your new Australian ship was free, if God had given you the crew and it did not cost you anything—and that would please a lot of people opposite no end—you still would not be competitive because a host of other factors are involved, and they are the financial factors.

When the original legislation was designed, its aim was to give Australia's shipping owners and shipping operators the incentives that are available to our competitors. It was designed to try to put Australian shipping on a more even keel in relation to competitors abroad. To peddle the lie that somehow the PAYE grant will go to seafarers is something that I find obscene. It is dishonest and obscene. This legislation, which proposes to abolish assistance to shipowners, will be rejected by the opposition. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that it is always interesting to listen to the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) talking about transport because he is recognised as a longstanding authority on transport in Australia, having been a former transport minister and a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in the last parliament. He referred to one of the reports that that committee presented at the end of the last parliament.
—But is he right on this issue?

—I did not say that he was right; I just acknowledged that he was recognised as an authority on the matter. Some of his comments raised a few questions. He closed on the point that nobody should peddle the lie that the subsidies are being paid to seafarers. I am not going to repeat his statement because it is not worth repeating. The fact is that these subsidies are not being paid to seafarers; they are being paid to the company. We know why they are being paid to the company. It is because of the strife that the previous Labor government got themselves into with ANL.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a deal struck with all the players involved at the time, but the deal is as good as. The previous Labor administration knew that they could not subsidise ANL straight out. They could not ask the taxpayers of Australia to directly pay the group tax for ANL. They had to inject it through the side door, and opposition members know that. That is the truth of the matter and that is part of what we are trying to address here today.
I ask members of the House this question: is there any other section of the Australian working community that taxpayers of Australia pay the PAYE tax for? The answer is no. That does not happen.

We all remember who the relevant minister was when this legislation was introduced, and we all remember the strife he got himself into after trying to deal with the problems of ANL. The former Prime Minister used to call him Dangerman. They brought in Turnbull and Wran to try to salvage the situation, and it got worse. Then, when they were trying to sell part of ANL off to get some money back in, they had to do a backdoor deal to try to stave off a revolt by the Maritime Union of Australia. At that time—and I remember this quite clearly—we saw in this place just who was controlling the Labor Party in government. They were being controlled by the ACTU and the Maritime Union of Australia.

It was interesting to note that, at the time when this piece of legislation went through this place, the government agreed to pay that money. It might not have been a direct payment to the seafarers, but that was certainly the intention and that is where it went. That is what it was all about. I will quote from a press release from the Australian Taxpayers Association—the organisation that represents the taxpayers of Australia who have no choice in how they pay their group tax; it is deducted from their income and they make a contribution to the wellbeing of the Commonwealth. The headline was `Taxpayers lose in ANL deal'. The press release stated:
The ANL deal holds the Nation to ransom.
The Federal Government has signalled that the use of industrial muscle is a legitimate tactic and will be rewarded.
Taxpayers are the big losers in this deal because the government—
that is, the former Labor government—
has committed all other taxpayers (especially workers paying PAYE) to subsidise the ANL.
There is no guaranteed end date and it commits all taxpayers to subsidise ANL for over $20 million per year.
Under the deal, the company gets to keep the PAYE instalments that would have been deducted from the seafarers wages, and the workers are exempt from income tax.
The proposal sets a dangerous precedent and flies in the face of the Federal Government's claim to champion competition, reform and opening Australia to the world.

The former Labor government maintained that, with the introduction of the Hilmer report, it was the champion of opening up competition and maintaining a level playing field. The former Prime Minister used to go to all parts of Australia and crow that it was the Labor Party that opened up all the markets in Australia to competition. They would not touch the labour market and they would not touch the marketplace where ANL operated. They would not touch the marketplace in which the Maritime Union of Australia operated. The Australian Taxpayers Association's press release states further:
It's an appalling situation when Australia can't give away the ANL (according to Lawrie Brereton), but it can afford to throw over $20 million each year of taxpayers' money at it `ad infinitum.'
It gives a hollow ring to the claim that Australia's tax system is fair and equitable.
The government—
and they are talking about the former Labor government—
must come clean and explain exactly how this proposal will work. What are the total costs? And what are net benefits—if any, to the whole community?
All taxpayers have the right to be treated fairly and equitably. This proposal distorts the tax system by excluding some workers and not others.
It also raises the possibility of further tax losses if other income is also free of income tax and may result in a future tax free wages push on ANL which further distorts the tax effect.
This is the salient point:
Is the door now open for all struggling businesses to receive such tax benefits? Or is any group with sufficient power now able to have themselves excluded from the income tax net?

How many times do members in this place get representations from constituents in their electorates about businesses that have been struggling and, admittedly, have done the wrong thing and not remitted their group tax to the Australian Taxation Office within the 14 days or seven days required of them? They are then in trouble and the tax office takes them to court. That was not the case with ANL. The former Labor government headed off in the opposite direction. They gave them the assistance they needed whilst other businesses in Australia, which have found it difficult to remit group taxes collected within the required time, have ended up in court with the Australian Taxation Office.

The bill that we are debating this morning sets out to repeal the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act 1995—that was the act I was just referring to—and to alter the sunset clause in the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 from 30 June 1997 to 30 June 1996. I think the requirements of this bill have been operating for 10 years. I understand that this bill was originally introduced by the member for Shortland, who was the minister at the time. The bill was intended to have effect for five years, but the former Labor government extended it for another five years, which takes us to 1997. This bill we are debating today requires that the sunset clause in that act be changed from 30 June 1997 to 30 June 1996.

Shipping serving Australia is both a major industry and a large contributor to Australia's current account deficit. In 1993-94, the cost of freight on Australia's external trade carried by sea was approximately $9.9 billion, with Australian shipping earning approximately $1.6 billion. The net cost of using foreign shipping in 1993‐94 was approximately $2.5 billion or 15 per cent of Australia's current account deficit in that year. In June 1995, there were approximately 30 Australian ships engaged in international trade.

BREAK.PARA: Australian shipping faces greater costs than many other international operators. This results from the higher standard of Australian ships than those registered under flags of convenience, relatively high wage costs and relatively high crewing levels. The latter problem has been addressed through industry reforms, which saw the number of seafarers at the end of 1993-94 being 233 or eight per cent lower than at the end of 1992-93. Australian crewing levels are now close to international standards.

The shipping industry receives a number of concessions, which are worth noting, including: the exemption of international shipping from many of the restrictive trade practices prohibited by the Trade Practices Act, the existence of cabotage which restricts most coastal trade to Australian ships, the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme, the Bass Strait passenger subsidies, an accelerated rate of depreciation for Australian trading ships, grants under the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act and grants under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act. As this bill deals with the two latter acts, they will be dealt with in more depth.

The International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act was introduced following negotiations on the proposed sale of the Australian National Line. The proposed sale of a substantial part of ANL was raised during debate on the appropriation bills in 1994. In August 1994, the government appointed a new board with the task of restructuring ANL—how many times did that happen?—after doubts were raised about the financial viability of ANL. The sale of ANL was subsequently endorsed by the ALP National Conference. In September 1994, members of the Labor government, the ACTU and the maritime unions met to discuss an industry reform package, which was designed to make ANL more attractive for sale. As part of the reform package, it was announced that grants would be paid to ship owners and operators to offset the impact of income tax on seafarers engaged in international shipping.

PARA.BREAK: The international shipping act was opposed by the then opposition. We were the then opposition and we voted against that legisla tion. Now that we are in government, this bill is moving to repeal that. The sale of ANL did not proceed. After various other potential buyers had dropped out, negotiations continued with the sole remaining potential buyer, P&O. However, the sale of ANL to P&O was strongly opposed by the MUA, which threatened industrial action unless P&O gave certain assurances about crewing matters. Such assurances were not given and the former Labor government announced in December that the sale had been abandoned and that ANL would be restructured instead.

BREAK.PARA: How many times did the Labor Party attempt to restructure ANL? How many millions of dollars worth of taxpayers' funds did the former Labor government pour down that black hole? It is outrageous. There has not been too much participation in this debate by the former minister who oversaw a lot of that. Some of the headlines at the time were `Dithering leaves ANL in dry dock'—I see that we have the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in the House now—and `Beazley defends ANL funding'.

I can remember at the time the very, very strong debate coming from the then government defending the money that was poured into ANL—the headline was `Secret funding deal in ANL sale'. There were some very interesting things which happened, and the Leader of the Opposition would recognise that, when Turnbull and the Minister for Transport at the time and company were negotiating the sale of the stevedoring component of ANL, they hived the profitable part off and kept the unprofitable part. We even got a lecture a little while ago from the member from Shortland about the reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't listen.

—I did listen. He was talking about the reforms in Britain. But what reforms did the former Labor government undertake here? They sold off the profitable part of the government business and kept the unprofitable part. He referred to the Conservatives in Great Britain having privatised a lot of the government business enterprises over there. The only mistake they have made in some areas is not introducing the regulation to maintain control over it.
—You are wrong.

—No. I have been over there as well and had a look at it. The member for Shortland referred to a lot of the privatisation that took place in Great Britain. But, in this process, the former Labor government desperately wanted to get rid of this dead cat that was strapped around its ankle called ANL, which it kept dragging into this place.

BREAK.PARA: The former minister was just dogged with bad luck over ANL and dogged with the bad luck that the Maritime Union of Australia brought to the debate because, instead of selling some of the profitable enterprises and agencies in Australia, the former government should have been getting rid of the unprofitable one and cutting their losses there. Yet the taxpayers are still subsidising it.

We then had the appointment of the new board—the appointment of some people, namely, Turnbull and Wran—to try to restructure ANL and get it up and going again. And who was Wran? We know who Wran was. He was one of the mates. But it did not happen and they did not achieve it; it just cost the taxpayers of Australia more money.

The second part of this bill addresses the Ships (Capital Grants) Act. The Ships (Capital Grants) Act was again introduced as part of the shipping reform program. The act provides for grants at the rate of seven per cent of the cost incurred in relation to registered Australian ships that are purchased as new ships—which is fair enough—purchased as ships less than five years old that have not previously been registered in Australia or extensively modified ships.

The capital grants act was introduced to facilitate the updating of the Australian shipping fleet to allow crewing to reflect international standards. It is a condition of all grants that the crewing of the ship in respect of which a grant is made does not exceed the maximum number fixed under the capital grants act. The capital grants act, as originally enacted, contained a sunset clause under section 9 which provided that grants would not be payable in respect of activity, that is, the purchase or modification of vessels, that occurred after 30 June 1992. The sunset clause was extended to 30 June 1997, and that happened in 1990. My understanding was that it was the minister at the time who extended that. This bill proposes to bring the end date of that sunset clause back to 30 June 1996. It is interesting to note the number of speakers from the opposition on these bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because we feel about it.

—I know that you feel about it. In government, why did you not do something far more responsible about the shipping industry? I acknowledge that the member for Throsby is in here talking about every single transport issue, particularly shipping, but we are not world competitive. The member for Shortland highlighted a number of reasons why we are not world competitive, but the Labor Party in government had 13 years to do something about it.

BREAK.PARA: The bill before the House this morning is principally to repeal the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act and to alter the sunset clause in the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. The first act that it is going to repeal contained that arrangement that was made by the former Labor government to prop up ANL at the time, and it obviously has not worked. We have seen Australian taxpayers continue to pour an enormous amount of money into that government enterprise that is not profitable. We have seen the former Labor government over the years that it was in office sell lots of government business enterprises that were profitable. They sold the profitable ones and kept the unprofitable ones. The minister at the time, Mr Brereton, acknowledged at one stage that you probably could not give ANL away.

It is important that the interests of the taxpayers of Australia are being acknowledged by this bill and that we recognise that we have a responsibility to try to address, in a responsible way, what we inherited with regard to the size of the budget deficit. The coalition strongly opposed the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Bill when it was debated in the parliament last October.

This scheme was developed from the deal made by the former Prime Minister and his senior ministerial colleagues with the ACTU and the Maritime Union of Australia to end the shipping strike called by the Maritime Union of Australia over the sale of ANL Ltd and ANL shareholding in Australian Stevedores. For its part of the bargain, the Maritime Union of Australia undertook to give serious consideration to supporting the government's proposed sale of ANL and negotiating an industrial agreement with shipowners to deliver significant cost savings.

The MUA opposed the sale tooth and nail and forced the government to back off from selling the line to P&O. That was the end result. The former Labor government did the deal to subsidise the company and pay PAYE tax. In the end, they did not achieve anything because the MUA still would not let the government of the time sell ANL to P&O, the only prospective buyer. Needless to say, ANL made further losses which continued to be a drain on the Australian taxpayer.

The so‐called maritime industry restructuring agreement was duly negotiated and was supposed to produce cost savings of some $200,000 per ship per year. However, the Maritime Union of Australia has largely failed to deliver on its commitments with the result that the promised savings have simply evaporated. The result of these measures that are being introduced and debated today is that Australian taxpayers will save about $52 million over the next four years. We inherited a fairly despicable sort of budget situation from the former Labor government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, nonsense!

—It is no good hoo‐hooing and ha‐haing from the opposition benches because it is a fact of life and the government of the day has to try to address that on behalf of the Commonwealth and the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to intervene briefly in this debate basically because, while the Shipping Grants Legislation Bill has not necessarily attracted a great deal of public attention to this time, we are a maritime nation both in terms of our trade and our national security. We are also a maritime nation in terms of our social amenity, as most of our population lives on the coast. The environmental issues entailed in the way we pursue maritime policy are also important.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what the previous speaker, the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), thinks he is going to do with ANL at the present time, but I can tell him exactly what he would be able to do with ANL if this bill were to pass and if he were to get the way of his minister on the subject of cabotage. I suspect that cabotage will be dealt with in the not too distant future in a related bill. What he will be able to do then with ANL is take out the Australian Navy and provide them with sorrowful target practice on the way to the bottom, because there is absolutely nothing else you will be able to do with the remnants of that organisation.

This bill and the other propositions that this government is pursuing render our maritime industry null and void. This is the death knell of the Australian maritime industry. It does not matter what clever game the government thinks it is playing in this area, this is a manifestation of prejudice, in the form of policy, to the great detriment of the national interest. It is not as though it is being done to an industry which has exhibited great strength; it is not as though it is being done to an industry that is otherwise than in strict survival mode.

When the United Kingdom went through this process in the late 1970s under the influence of the Thatcher government, we witnessed the destruction of the greatest civil maritime nation in the world. The British used to say that their diminution in international standing was a product of the loss of empire and the consequences of their having to fight two wars that were enormously economically debilitating to that nation.

Whatever happened with their empire and those wars, it did not happen to the British maritime industry. What happened to the British maritime industry was Maggie Thatcher. They have gone from a point where they had some 2,000 ships plying international trade down to about 200 now. That is the position they got into. They were very lucky during the Falklands War that that depredation had not proceeded so far that they were in the position of having no ships to fight with. They were very lucky to catch it at that early point. If they had to fight that war over again, they would be in a materially more difficult position than they were in then.

For the information of the previous speaker, it was not a product of privatisation; it was a product of the removal of precisely these sorts of financial supports to the British system. The Europeans paid no such attention to that sort of nonsense. The Europeans, with whom our international traders compete internationally, have these sorts of financial arrangements and more. They rigidly adhere to cabotage around the European coastline and, on the basis of all that, they produce a massive maritime industry. They have sustained it against the depredations of flag of convenience countries. They have survived on the basis of that and they maintain their maritime position through cabotage and these sorts of support mechanisms.

This is not about creating an even playing field; this is about destroying the last vestiges of the playing field on which our international shippers can play—and they are not thanking you for this initiative. Your hatred of the seamen and the MUA is all very well when you are standing on the barricades and waving your flags, but it does not sit very well with the poor devils who are employers—the people who are out there trying to make a quid, assist our balance of payments problems and trying to ensure that Australia maintains a maritime industry.

I will quote from Robert Hartley, the Manager of Maritime Policy for the Australian Shipowners Association. They are used to dealing with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) in this area and they have a kindly view of him. He has been trailing around their offices for years being educated by them. But they did not comprehend that education does not necessarily cure prejudice; it merely gives it a wider stage. This matter has provided this minister with a wider stage. He has read everything, knows everything and understands nothing. So they said gently:

The minister, Mr Sharp, has expressed a belief that under the coalition plan for an Australian second register and dismantling of cabotage, the increased competitive environment will rejuvenate shipping and lead to an expansion in the Australian flag fleet.

The ambition for a healthy, expanded fleet is admirable and we shall endeavour to see whether it can be made to work. In the meantime Australian shipowners have to carry on business as usual, which indeed they will do, until competition from foreign government assisted shipping with cheaper Third World crews makes the business of running Australian flag and crewed ships in international trade uneconomical. In the current hiatus new investment in Australian tonnage is already being put on hold. I understand that there are some three ships to which this will apply retrospectively, in effect. It is a massive breach of faith with the Australian shipping industry.

And haven't they ever performed? Since those reforms were put in place in the waterfront in the mid-1980s, some $2 billion worth of investment has gone into the Australian shipping industry, and that was in a very short time. As I said before, it is an industry which we cling to with our fingernails. What a gesture of confidence for people who understand that they have to operate in an international environment where you have flag of convenience crews operating and where the employers of those flag of convenience crews do not care whether their ships sink or float, provided they can make a quid out of it at the optimal opportunity!

The Australian shipping industry are competing with them. They are probably taking on board a greater challenge than any other section of Australian industry. They put $2 billion into it on the basis of the changes that were made by the Maritime Union in relation to the crewing arrangements of ships. Those changes were enforced, taking crew numbers down from something like 31 a ship to 18 a ship—enforced by their willingness to acquire, or repair or refurbish the sorts of ships that could sustain that crewing level. So the crew numbers went down from 31 to 18 and $2 billion was invested. We have the advantage, therefore, of having a shipping industry that is approximately half the age of the international average—in other words, a shipping industry capable of delivering a substantial performance outcome.

It is not as though those reforms of crewing levels have not been accompanied by other reforms on the waterfront. For example, in the handling of bulk cargoes we have had an improvement of 60 per cent over this period. The national average cost of loading or unloading containers declined by 29 per cent in the early 1990s. Competition passed these gains on to shippers in the form of lower freight rates and higher trade, with the BTCE estimating the total benefit to all shippers in 1993 at $276 million, of which $200 million accrued to Australians.

The government, sustaining its attack on the MUA, of course now seeks to pooh-pooh those sorts of figures and suggests their irrelevance. Yet every day or every month new agreements for better practice on the waterfront are being reached. There is a total awareness, as far as that industry is concerned, of its need to improve its performance constantly. But one thing they all agree is the central thing for improvement in productivity—be they stevedoring companies, shippers, the workers in the industry or those who use that industry—is the capacity of the companies engaged in the process to refurbish that industry, to provide it with capital infrastructure which modernises it. That is absolutely critical to the improvement in productivity.

In the same way as work practices are ignored by this government as the central problem in the stevedoring industry, the government also ignores the fact that in the shipping industry the central problem in productivity is the lack of investment in the capital infrastructure. It is even more important that those investment decisions are taken in order to give us a chance of being internationally competitive at all. So not only does our Australian shipping industry have to compete with those flag of convenience crews, but also it has to compete with the well subsidised, well supported European, American and Japanese fleets. It is not as though it necessarily does it terribly well in this sense.

As I said before, it clings by its fingernails to its capacity to provide a service to us. For example, Australian resident operators' freight on imports and exports is worth just over $1½ billion a year, or about 13.7 per cent of the total. Foreign operators are now at $10.5 billion, about 86 per cent of the total. So, as I said, the industry is clinging to it by its fingernails, but that has a tremendously important impact upon our balance of payments. If you take that $1½ billion out and add to it about $600 million worth of trade on the coast, if that subsequently gets done by foreign crews, you punch a $2 billion hole in the balance of payments position—because of this piece of arrant arrogance and stupidity, this breach of faith with the shipowners of this nation.

I said before that there are other factors involved in this. I mentioned environmental factors. If you start to build up a flag of convenience crew ship operation around our coastline—we already have it, of course, in the international shipping arrangements—in a very short time you will start to get a threat to the major tourist industries of this nation. Most of those major tourist industries lie on the coast of this country, and most of them lie on the north-east coast of this country. Those areas will be where surveillance is at its worst by virtue of their distance from population centres. It will take just one or two savage accidents in those areas and the tourism industry there will shut down. In taking ourselves out of the maritime industry—as this legislation would do—we would be removing a whole basis of expertise on surveillance anyway as far as these sorts of areas are concerned.

I mentioned too the issue of national security. There is a very interesting statistic again involving some investment by shipowners that the government has taken upon itself to persecute. There are memoranda of understanding between the defence department and our seven major shipowners. They cover around 40 ships to provide assistance in case of a national emergency. A number of those shipowners have, at their own expense, fitted ship‐to‐ship refuelling facilities and other modifications specifically to assist the navy. Australia's defence forces depended on merchant seamen for emergency manning in both world wars, and during the Falklands War the Royal Navy was able to rely on 53 ships from 24 different companies for troop transport, communications and supply.

When I was defence minister, I directly experienced what all this meant. You might well say that that is out there in the distant never‐never and not to worry about that sort of thing. We decided to finally test a division in the north of Australia. We decided to mobilise that division by taking it essentially from the south‐east and western corners and putting it in the north in a timely way—the sort of response time we would need in international conflict—and to supply it. It was as heavy a division as we normally provide. There were tanks, artillery and other heavy weapons associated with it.

Most of it had to be carried up the Stuart Highway. We discovered from that that, grateful though the Northern Territory government was that we were spending that much money in the Northern Territory and that they were getting a bit of attention in an area that interests them—defence—they were not grateful that the tourists who plied the Stuart Highway found themselves locked into slow‐moving convoys with tank transporters proceeding in front of them. They did not enjoy the experience. They had a very substantial look at the exhaust pipes of a number of very interesting heavy transporters but, apart from that, they had less enjoyment than they could normally expect to get from the Northern Territory.

But, even with all of that, one-third of that division's supplies had to be sent by sea. One-third of the supplies to sustain an Australian effort in the field had to be sent by sea. The notion that we could do that without an Australian maritime industry is laughable. I am not talking about sending Australians to do anything in Papua New Guinea or anywhere else. I am talking about sending Australians inside Australia to do things inside Australia for the defence of Australia. That is what we are talking about here. One-third of the supplies had to go by sea, and that was a very generous interpretation of what it was that we had to do. In fact, it would have been a great deal more efficient to send a lot more by sea.

I once had the pleasure of discussing the relative merits of sea transport against other forms of transport for defence purposes with a chap who headed the NATO command for the area adjacent to Europe. It is the only NATO command not commanded by an American. It is commanded by a Britisher for auld lang syne. It is commanded by him because of Britain's once great reputation in the maritime area.

I said to him, `This is all a bit out of date, isn't it, Admiral? These days you could send all this by air transport.' He said, `Well, let me tell you this, sport'—he did not actually use that expression but called me `Minister'—`if you took 20 of the biggest American army freighter planes'—I think a Starlifter or a Galaxy; it was one or the other—`and flew them end to end 24 hours a day for 10 years, you would provide sufficient ammunition for war on the central front for six weeks. That is what you would do if you rendered yourselves reliant upon air transport. That's why we like to keep sea lanes open, Minister. It's the only way the Americans can get here.' That was an interesting demonstration again of the absolute significance of the maritime industries to the national security of the nation.

So this bill is no joke. This little piece of revenge on the MUA is massively destructive of our balance of payments, massively destructive of Australian industry, massively destructive of our national defence and potentially massively destructive of our marine environment. This minister is a classic. This sort of semi-educated minister in his portfolio jumped the starter's gun. He got that starter's gun when they swore him in a couple of days after the election and, instead of holding the darned starter's gun in the air, he pointed it at his foot.

What he has been doing with that starter's gun ever since is pointing it at the foot of Australian industry—be it in the railway area or be it in the absurd set of propositions we are now left with at Sydney airport. Having failed to bite the bullet on the privatisation of Sydney airport at the appropriate time and get a bunch in place at Sydney airport with an obligation on them to develop a second airport out at Badgerys Creek—that is what was entailed in that privatisation proposition—those opposite squibbed it for the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and have found themselves wandering around in never-never land ever since. The great micro-economic reform task that was in place to fix up the aviation industry in Sydney has been wrecked. The great task of keeping us in the Australian maritime industry, an industry absolutely vital for the national security of this nation, is in the process of being wrecked.

This is an exorable bill that requires rejection by this parliament. Above all, it is a bill that requires the understanding of this parliament. It is a bill that really needs to sink into the minds of the Australian citizen, because the Australian citizen accepts too readily the notion that we are a maritime nation without seeing the evidence of it and without necessarily seeing what is required to keep us in that industry.

We are in it only by the very skin of our teeth. We are in it only by the sorts of propositions that are being rejected here today. We are in it only because our government was prepared to create a level playing field and take away the impediments to maintenance of an effective maritime industry—be it the reforms necessary in the labour market or the reforms necessary in support mechanisms for our shipowners via the taxation system. We did no more for that industry than has been done by the European nations to support theirs and we did a great deal less for it than has been done by the United States to support theirs, but what little we did is now being removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with interest to speak in this debate on the Shipping Grants Legislation Bill, having been the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries in New South Wales and having had the prime responsibility for export from that state, which I remind members of this House is one of the biggest exporters of primary produce in the nation. I noted with interest the contribution from the Leader of the Opposition and former Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley). It is obvious that he has learnt little from the former government's defeat at the polls a few months ago. He continues to carry on down that same track of economic rationalism or economic policy that was responsible for the Labor government being defeated at the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the former Minister for Finance, and the former Treasurer, Mr Willis, have not yet come to terms with the fact that their financial policies are one of the big reasons they were thrown out of office. Their policies and their performance are the reasons the Australian people are absolutely disgusted with the Labor Party at the present time.

There is no doubt in my mind that, if you look closely at the credentials of these people, you would question why they might continue to believe that they can con the Australian people. We had the former Minister for Finance and the former Treasurer selling off half of Qantas and half of the Commonwealth Bank, including the funds in the recurrent budget. I would remind Australians that that is similar to an Australian selling their house and spending the money in one year. These are the people who now stand up here—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will talk about GIO. I welcome the interjection because what happened with the GIO, and the State Bank of New South Wales, is that they were taken off debt. We now have the Labor Premier of New South Wales selling the fleet of cars and—copying the Keating experience—spending it in the recurrent budget. That is the management philosophy of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at the bill itself, it is clear that the previous Labor government bribed the maritime unions of Australia so as to encourage the sale of ANL because the owners were being held to ransom by the union. What is new about that with the union movement in Australia? There is no doubt in my mind that they were attempting to sweeten the sale of ANL. Of course, not only were they attempting to sweeten the sale of ANL, but you might note that, in the original bill, there was a sunset clause finishing the Ships (Capital Grants) Act in 1990. But of course the sunset clause was extended to 30 June 1997. It is fairly clear that this is about looking after the Labor Party mates in the maritime unions.

The maritime unions have a great reputation in Australia, and I have had some interesting letters in the last few weeks about this. We should look back in history to see the record of some of these people and their cousins in the Waterside Workers Federation and to see what they have done to Australia over the years. I know that it is painful for the Labor Party to hear about these things because, obviously, they do not like to hear what has gone on in the past and they do not like to hear what good honest Australians say about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't think Australians—
—I will read this letter I received from a constituent of mine and you can see what you think about it. It will give a perspective on what we are talking about with these sorts of people.
—Have you met a seaman?

—Yes, I have met a seaman. I will tell you about that later. This letter is from a constituent of mine who, during the Second World War, had first‐hand experience of what these people were doing to this country. This is a letter which I think should be read to the parliament, because it puts in perspective some of the things which go on with these unions. This is a letter from my constituent, Mr Coolahan, in Yamba. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: About 28th May, 1945 I was instructed by my Commanding Officer (CO) for the 2/27 Battalion 7th Division AIF to proceed from Atherton (Atherton Tablelands) to Townsville. I was to supervise the loading of a ship allocated to us to once more service overseas. My CO advised me that the ship had to be loaded by the 1st June, with our equipment, or else I would have to answer to him personally. That was something I would have preferred not to have to do. On the other hand if I upset the Waterside Workers I would face a Court Martial because they would go on strike there and possibly through Australia. It had happened previously, ie go on Strike Australia Wide—"a rock and a hard place".

I arrived at the ship the following day and found the Wharfies in a shed having a tea break. I sought out the Foreman and was informed that it was their morning tea break. After 20 minutes or so they went outside to load the ship. Approximately 10 to 15 minutes later they were back in the shed. I again spoke to the Foreman who informed me that they could not work in the rain, as they didn't have their wet weather gear there. When I told him about the troops conditions in the tropics with rain, mud etc, he said that it was not his problem. I asked him again to proceed with loading the ship, not when it's raining he replied. It was not raining hard enough to get wet.

I asked him if I could use his phone which was hanging on the wall. He said "yes". I told him that seeing his Wharfies were not loading the ship on time I would get some Army Engineers in to do so. I went to the phone and pretended to speak to the CO for the Engineers Unit. The Foreman said my "blokes" will throw the Engineers in the Harbour. My answer was, I will ring the nearby Infantry Unit and have them come and protect the Engineers and if his fellows interfered they would enjoy a swim.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is where they got the idea of putting troops on the wharves.
—I can hear the jackals. This is typical union—typical jackals. I have been a unionist. I have been through it and I know what they are like.
—You know all about it!
—I was a canecutter, mate. I have been through all your bloody hard‐hand tactics. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreman then replied that they would go on a general strike throughout Australia. Oh boy! A rock and a hard place.

The Wharfies then loaded the ship without any further trouble and in good time. As a result the loading was completed before the Battalion, approximately 1,000 men, arrived and embarked on the 2nd June, 1945.

That was what they were prepared to do in the war when our men were being killed in New Guinea. When young men—my uncles—who were only 17 years old were up there fighting for Australia, the waterside workers and the maritime unions of Australia were not prepared to back the country. That is the type of people that the Labor Party are defending. There is no doubt that we have to try to find efficiencies in Australia. When I say to you that it is important to the export industries of this country, I mean it.

Australia, despite the $300 million to $400 million that has been thrown at the problems by the Labor Party over the years, still has not reached world standard. We are still way below world standard in these areas. Export industries are being asked to play on a level playing field. How can you possibly play on a level playing field when you have one hand tied behind your back by the Waterside Workers Union of Australia?

The honourable member interjected: `Have you ever met a waterside worker?' Yes, I have met a waterside worker. I have had them drink in my pub. I have had them fly back to the electorate from all parts of the world first-class. That is the standard they set and the costs they enforce on the industry. I have heard these people skite about how they get the income they want by holding industries to ransom. That is the type of thing we have had happen in Australia and the type of thing we have to break.

No-one would agree that we should accept so-called `rust buckets'. No-one would agree that we should have people paid below the reasonable wage for working on these ships. That has to be addressed; I agree. But at present, when Australia is trying to compete on the world market, we are not competitive. I recall vividly some two to three years ago when Australia was trying to sell some wheat to New Zealand that the New Zealanders bought the wheat from the Middle East. The reason they bought the wheat from the Middle East is that it was cheaper to ship that wheat from the Middle East to New Zealand than to ship Australian wheat from Australia to New Zealand. Why? Because of the costs of our wharves, the costs of our maritime unions. That is the problem we have in this country and the problem that must be addressed.

Our great agricultural industries are battling to compete on the world market. If you look closely at the costs out of the New Zealand ports, the costs of maritime unions in New Zealand and the costs out of the United States of America—who are our prime competitors in the markets we have in South‐East Asia—you find they are beating us hands down. Even though the Australian Labor Party has thrown $300 million to the waterside workers and said `Put this in your pockets', it has achieved very little. We are nowhere near the efficiency of ports like Singapore and Antwerp—the ports we are competing with. That is why we have to address these problems. We have to address the industrial relations legislation as well if we are to become competitive.
I am not a slavish advocate of the Hilmer reforms. I am practical enough to know that you have to take a couple of steps back from this economic philosophy and ask what is practical.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an agrarian socialist.

—We will talk about that. At least the agrarian socialists work. They do not sit on their backsides and hold everyone else to ransom. We understand that pure economics do not work out there in the big world, but you have to have the competition. You must be efficient. The members of the Labor Party are laughing about this. —Alleged.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It was only a passing reference, and we all know that Frank Walker saved him with a no bill. There is no doubt that the only reason that the Labor Party members are here in strength defending this piece of legislation is that it was brought in as a bribe to the maritime unions, their mates who fund them. That is all they are interested in; they certainly are not interested in the future of Australia, and they certainly are not interested in the fact that we must be a competitive trading nation.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are ever going to get away from the financial mess that this country is in, we really have to be able to trade our way out of it. It worried me some 18 months ago to read headlines referring to Australia having the best balance of trade result in 15 years while, because of the interest on the debt, we were still not in front. That is the legacy of the Labor Party: a foreign debt blow‐out from something like $28 billion to $184 billion. The former government dishonestly told this House last year that it was going to have a budget surplus, only to come back later in the year to say that it had got it wrong. Even after the creative accounting of putting Victoria's debt repayment into the current account, the former government still claimed to have a surplus of $150 million.

I clearly remember the surplus figure being challenged during the election campaign when Labor Party leaders such as Mr Carr stood up and swore on oath, in blood, that it was correct, but they were prepared to throw Australian taxpayers' money to the wind to try and hide the unemployment figures in an effort to win. Now, of course, the Australian people have been left with an $8 billion black hole that has to be somehow filled.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a lie, and you know it's a lie.

—It is not a lie; it is a fact. It is a bit like the New South Wales budget at the present time: all smoke and mirrors about how we are going to get a balanced budget. The fact is that the opposition when in government deliberately overspent and did not care about the Australian people. They adopted a `tick it up' approach because it was more important to win than to worry about the Australian people. Now we have an $8 billion black hole that the Labor Party will have to remember for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has taken some strong decisions. The Leader of the Opposition has talked about Sydney airport. It is about time someone did something because we have been talking for 25 to 30 years about a decent airport in Sydney. I recall that it was Gough Whitlam who said, `The airport will not go here.' We still do not have an airport in Sydney so it is about time we had a minister like the present one who will make decisions and try to address the problems. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I found the comments of the honourable member for Page (Mr Causley) of interest because, like most of the arguments that have proceeded from the other side of the House, the content of his speech was driven not by any real knowledge of the issues before the House in this legislation, not by any deep background knowledge of the problems—and there are problems on our waterfront and in our maritime industry—but by prejudice, by a lack of understanding—
—Ignorance.

—By ignorance and a culture which is exemplified by the quite infamous Nazi leader in the Hitler regime who said, `Every time I hear the word "union" I reach for my gun.' That seems to be a motivating factor with some of the members on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: Having sat through many of the maiden speeches made from the other side telling us about their concerns for their electorates and how they are out there to serve the Australian people, it is interesting to ask where they are now while an important piece of legislation which just—

TALK.START.PARA: —The same place your lot are—in their offices watching it on television.
—You are here because you are trying to do some work on other matters to find out what your ministerial responsibilities are. You will be as hopeless and as prejudiced as the rest.
—I assure the honourable member for Melbourne Ports that I have no ministerial responsibilities. Please address your remarks through the chair.

—I am delighted to do that, sir, because I know of your genuine concerns for the future of this country. Let me start with the basic premise that all governments over the last two decades, whatever their political composition, have been dedicated to the proposition that, in the defence of Australia, we have to have armed services which are self‐reliant so that, if we enter a regional dispute where we are not necessarily going to be able to be assisted by someone else, we have a capacity to defend ourselves. Self‐reliance became the touchstone of our defence policy, irrespective of which governments were in office. No‐one can argue that there have not been historical industrial problems on our waterfront, and I am not doing that either; nor do I say that all the fault and all the blame are on one side.

SPEECH.PARA: When I hear the kinds of references made to Australian merchant seamen, it is odd that people opposite, who like to wrap themselves in the flag of patriotism on Anzac Day, cannot even simply acknowledge that there were merchant seamen who put their lives on the line time and time again to see that necessary supplies got to Australia and got to our armed forces—and many of them lost their lives.

I say that to balance the picture. We are, after all, the largest island continent in the world. Think about that. If you are the largest island continent in the world, you not only need a navy, but you need a merchant navy. You need a merchant navy which is an integral part of the economic fabric and structure of your nation. It is the job of government, irrespective of its political complexion, to see that, if you are going to be self‐reliant with your armed services, there are many pieces of equipment that they need. Australian manufacturing industry needs to import all sorts of component parts, not merely for defence equipment, but for everyday living. We are a nation that lives on our exports. So do we not need to follow the pattern that is occurring in Asia—in Singapore and Malaysia?

The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), a former distinguished minister in this area, has pointed out the significance of the maritime industry when seen as a total industry for the economic development of any country. He cited statistics that are relevant to Europe. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) pointed to the decline of the once great merchant fleet of the world in Great Britain as a result of Thatcherite policies. Don't we learn from those experiences? Why is it that Singapore and Malaysia are now concentrating on developing their merchant fleet, and that China is rapidly progressing in this area?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about competition?

—Competition? Let me deal with that. If you find yourself in a regional conflict—and that is the basis upon which we are funding our defence services; that is the concept of self‐reliance—which flag of convenience do you go to? What sorts of charges will they make on your export industries and to bring stuff into Australia in areas where you have submarines—
—We need good strong friends.

—Good strong friends—there we are! There is the voice of Australian nationalism—we need good strong friends! When the Americans arrived in my electorate, in Port Melbourne, and were confronted with the structures that were administered by the state of Victoria—not by the waterside workers, not by the seamen's union, but by the state—in order to unload their ships and move their men, they simply drove their bulldozers right over gates and existing buildings so they could move men and equipment.

BREAK.PARA: Let us face it: when it comes to being self‐reliant, do you say, in terms of your expenditure on the purchase of sophisticated, updated aircraft, `Let's stick with the Wirraway because we can rely on our friends to save us. Let's rely on a 1950 tank. That's all we need because our friends will save us'? What a miserable, appalling, prejudiced, stupid position that is. It denies the policies of former Liberal governments. Therefore, I say, without any apology, the reason I am in this House to argue on this legislation is that I want to see—

TALK.START.PARA: —We were wondering why you were here.
—You are full of wonderment. You are in a constant state of wonderment.
—You're irrelevant.

—The minister is irrelevant. I believe that for the future of Australia, whatever it takes, we must have a competent, efficient and modern marine fleet, run by Australians. We must train our young mariners. Indeed, that was part of the recommendations of the most recent joint parliamentary committee dealing with this issue, which made it perfectly clear that that was their position. That was a joint party proposal. There are problems, but you do not solve those problems by saying that the future of the Australia maritime industry is to rely on ships of convenience. You have got a report from a joint committee that says there are ships of convenience which are rust buckets that should not be at sea.
—How many?
—Too many. One is too many. Overseas seamen are exploited, murdered, dumped at sea. That is in the report of a joint committee of which your members were a part.
—You're being selective.

—Take it up with the committee. That is the reality. You can't always rely on your friends. If we are to be a trading nation, if we are to have self‐reliance in defence—and the Leader of the Opposition indicated in a very graphic way the problems of troop movements—we must have a merchant fleet which is capable of meeting the needs of this nation domestically, internationally and commercially and, above all, be seen as part of our total defence capacity.
—At what cost?

—At less cost than it takes to buy some very sophisticated military equipment. This view that you act like a publican and say, `We've got to look at the price of beer and that's the way we will determine the future of our merchant navy,' is arrant political nonsense.
—I only talked about—
