What has the government actually considered in this legislation, other than its hatred of the Maritime Union of Australia?

There is considerable damage to this nation implicit in this legislation. What about marine insurance? No answer. What about the provision of stores to ships? No answer. What about towage? No answer. What about pilotage? No answer. What about the development and supply of shipping technology? No answer. What about repairs and maintenance? No answer. What about jobs and investment in those areas? What about the cities and the people who live there? What about the future of this nation? Is the coalition going to make the export of jobs and investment a growth industry under its stewardship and have it follow the proposed Telstra debacle?

When the reality eventually dawns on the Australian electorate—and make no mistake it will, although it will take some time—they will react accordingly. I made a prediction back in 1990 that this government would eventually get onto the treasury bench and that it would be there for one term. You will not see the year 2000. You do not deserve it and you have started to get yourself back over here where we are.

This coalition will very quickly—and much quicker than you think—take its rightful place on the opposition benches, and it will do it much more quickly than some of those commentators up there think. Let us face it, port and other maritime regulatory authorities will have a greatly reduced pool of skilled labour to draw on. Not only may this affect the provision of harbourmasters and ship control officers but also safety, investigation and emergency personnel.

No-one ought to be surprised that most countries, be they in the OECD or otherwise, provide fiscal assistance to their national fleets. They use their brains, they use their nous. They do this for the reasons I have outlined. It is sensible, it is responsible and it is prudent for any nation to secure its merchant fleet. Why not Australia, shadow minister, why not Australia?

Why is it that this country under the leadership of the coalition—I am trying to promote you—can ignore what no other responsible country would do? What do these responsible countries do? These countries provide depreciation allowances. These countries provide concessional tax rates. These countries provide concessional loans and they provide subsidies. They know through their own bitter experience that you do not under any circumstances decimate your merchant fleet, and those who ignore history do so at their peril.

Abolishing the assistance as proposed by this legislation will not create a competitive level playing field for Australian shipping in the international market but what it will do is place the Australian shipping industry in a great big black hole. This early withdrawal of the capital grant will have a number of specific effects on the Australian shipping industry.

What incentives will there be for shipowners to invest in new ships and technology? We have one company in my electorate of Port Adelaide, South Australian Ships, building fast, aluminium, catamaran ferries. Is there any appreciation on the government's side that unless we invest in new shipping technology and jump ahead of the pack the Australian fleet will age and that this will have the guaranteed result of increasing costs which ultimately will be passed on to consumers?

What did you say before the election to these people who were investing in ships? Did you say anything about all of this? Did you tell them in your negotiations? No. Even when they were asked over there in the other place they had no indication whatsoever that this was going to occur.

If the costs of new vessels increase, as they surely will, then further increases in capital productivity and hence manning levels simply cannot occur. There are at least three vessels, as has been pointed out, currently under construction that were to be delivered in the 1996‐97 financial year. This will see a direct, unplanned increase in the cost of these vessels which cost tens of millions of dollars to build over the space of a number of years. This is in direct contradiction to the minister's comments in his second reading speech about the need to provide transitional arrangements for the withdrawal of the accelerated appreciation allowance.

Repealing the grant paid to international trading vessels will have some unintentional consequences. Australian vessels will switch their operations from international to coastal services, and this will increase the cost of international trade relative to coastal trade. Australian shipowners will therefore be placed at a competitive disadvantage in relation to ships registered in other countries where there are generous tax concessions and ships registered in tax havens.

Legislation—or anything else—that is based on ideological frenzy, hatred, vengeance, black‐heartedness, scapegoating or whatever, is folly of the penultimate kind. This legislation ought to be vigorously opposed by anyone in this House who has Australia's long-term national interests at heart. If it is not, then, after the Telstra debacle, this shipping legislation folly, the proposed public sector slashing and the expected cuts in health, education and welfare, the government will add coffin nail after coffin nail to its electoral fortune. Many on the other side will watch their political careers go quickly into disappearance mode.

The government will not get away for much longer with the slippery rhetoric of justifying its actions by blaming the former government when the truth is that this government simply put itself into a corner by irresponsible election promises. Make no mistake, the truth will prevail. The truth always prevails. Unfortunately, it takes far too long at times, but it is inevitable. It is as certain as night follows day. If members of this House are concerned with this nation's long‐term national interest, they will have the courage and the integrity to vigorously oppose this foolhardy legislation.

I conclude by mentioning part of a pamphlet prepared by the Maritime Union of Australia. It sums up how this nation ought to feel about a very crucial industry. It says that Australia has been a seafaring nation for over 200 years and that Australians are pretty proud of our maritime industry, which has a long history, a long tradition, and a lot of culture, and which has brought economic independence with it.

The plea from the Maritime Union is not to let a political agenda of hatred ruin a viable Australian industry. This House ought to support its shipping industry. It ought to support its country. It ought to have a long‐term view of Australia as a trading nation. This bill will bring disharmony, confrontation and a deal of angst that this coalition government will not have the ability to deal with. Mark my words, you are setting yourself down a path from which you will find it very difficult to return, and it will be to your great cost and to this nation's great cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Shipping Grants Legislation Bill raises more than just the question of the merits of the shipping industry; it raises some very fundamental principles regarding appropriate government. The fact of the matter is that neither a government, a company nor an individual can legitimately purport to retrospectively take away rights, commitments or contractual obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of any transmission of business, the new corporate entity is obliged to comply with contractual obligations entered into by the previous entity. Why? Because others have relied on those undertakings or contractual obligations, in many cases acted upon them, and in many other cases acted to their detriment. In this case, our shipping industry has contributed some billions—not millions, but billions—of dollars to developing our shipping industry on the faith of commitments made by the former Labor government.

This present government arrogantly, immorally and improperly is moving to take away those rights which have been acted on. If ever there was a demonstration of the need for a bill of rights, the actions of this government show precisely that. It is bad government, it is immoral government, and it will pay the price for it.

In terms of the merits of this legislation, one must remember that, just as a computer feeds out rubbish if you feed in misinformation, this government is producing rubbish because it is acting on the basis of its own propaganda. It is acting on the basis of its blind prejudices and its illogical biases, and it is not prepared to govern according to reality.

One thing that Australians hate and view with contempt is fanatics, and this government is demonstrating complete Thatcherite fanaticism and an incapacity to look at the real world. It is heading for disaster. The sooner the backbenchers—and I believe that many are competent; many are indeed small `l' liberals—start to realise the direction that they are heading in, the sooner they will stop their leaders taking them over a cliff, like Thatcherite lemmings heading to their destruction.

The bill is based on a false premise that the Shipping (Capital Grants) Act and the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Act are the result of a clandestine deal between the former government and the Maritime Union of Australia. The present government is wrong in that assumption because I personally am aware that, in addition to the MUA and shipowners, who obviously had a substantial input, there was significant impetus for the legislation from the Australian Institute of Marine and Power Engineers, which has been in existence since 1905 and covers some highly skilled and extremely competent workers.

This contempt and blind passion in pursuing the MUA are entirely misplaced. While one would not normally have regard to which unions are involved, this government seems to proceed on the basis of analysing who the parties to a transaction are, whether they fit on the goodie or baddie side of the government's ledger, and then acting accordingly.

The fact is that there has been significant reform of Australia's shipping industry. A number of speakers have covered this issue but I wish to point out some of the more significant facts. The average crew level on Australian ships is now about 18 and, out of 19 countries examined by the Bureau of Industry Economics, Australia has therefore improved its rating from sixteenth in the world in 1986 to second in 1994. Australian crewing levels are now lower than the world average crew size of 23.8 and the average OECD level of 22.

We are not talking about crewing on little cabin cruisers here; we are talking about massive structures, isolated in the oceans, confronting hurricanes and traumas of all kinds, being manned in many instances by 18 courageous Australians. And they are getting mud tipped on them by the fanaticism of this current government. In addition, there has been voluntary retirement of over 1,000 seafarers and retraining of 1,500 others.

Since 1988, with the introduction of 36 additional replacement vessels into the Australian fleet, representing a turnover of 45 per cent of the fleet, we are now looking at an average fleet age of 9.2 years compared to a world average of 17 years. In the last 10 years, 90 per cent of those ships which have tragically gone to the bottom of the ocean, resulting in loss of life and property and, indeed, causing significant environmental damage, have been 15 years old or more. Our ships are now half the age of the world average, and our shipping industry would, with support, prove and obtain the benefits of that fact.

To put reform in its context, between 1989 and 1996, despite inflationary trends, BHP's ship crew costs have been reduced from $2.78 million to $1.85 million—and that is an example using just one company.
In terms of the need for the Ships (Capital Grants) Act in 1987, it is worth referring to the comment of the Taylor report:

The current fiscal incentives permit Australian ship owners capital costs to be competitive with those enjoyed by international operators. Capital costs are by far the largest percentage of annualised time charter costs faced by Australian dry bulk carriers. The measures have been extremely successful in promoting the modernisation of the Australian fleet. There is a need for certainty that they will be retained. The capital grants legislation expires in 1997 and will have the effect of removing access to the lessened depreciation period.
This government is cutting right across that. They are taking a year off the commitment that the industry has given to itself until 1997.

Contrary to the government's wishes, the International Shipping (Australian Resident Seafarers) Act did not result from a clandestine deal. It was in fact the Taylor report, the report of the chairman of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority, to the government in 1994 which first recommended the removal of payroll tax burdens on the shipping industry because of the fact that the tax was not a burden on other competing companies.

The problem is that Australian seafarers in the international trades spend some six months away from home port, yet the shipping companies are obliged to continue to pay to state governments, because of our federal system, the payroll tax commitments. Those commitments are not replicated by other countries and the purpose of the legislation was simply to even up the playing field so that our industry could compete.

Those recommendations for that to occur came, as I said, in 1994 from the Taylor report. They did not come, as the government has claimed, from a clandestine deal done between the government and the MUA in respect of the restructuring of the ANL line. The analysis predated that and indeed the recommendations predated that. So, again, the government is acting on an entirely false premise.

If one wants to compare a success story and a disaster story, one simply has to look to the Canadian experience and the British experience. Canada in recent years has introduced a special exemption from corporate tax for income derived from international shipping operations. It is a conscious attempt on the part of the Canadian government to encourage the expansion of the Canadian international shipping service. It has been vitally important and indeed supremely successful in not only retaining shipping companies but attracting foreign shipping companies to Canadian shores. There has been a significant increase in employment and a significant increase in revenue raised for all Canadians from the progressiveness, the foresight, the courage and the rationality of the Canadian government.

BREAK.PARA: On the other hand, we see the consequences of blind Thatcherite prejudices. In 1984, England—and it has been mentioned—was one of the major shipping countries in the world. As a result of the removal of the special capital allowances by the Thatcher government in 1984, it is now significantly falling behind its regional competitors, Sweden, Belgium, France and Germany. It resulted in a decision by Shell Tankers to transfer its crewing operations to Singapore and P&O Containers to flag out five of its ships in order to reduce their respective crew costs. Indeed, P&O has put five of its vessels under the Bermudan flag and reduced its tonnage on the United Kingdom register so that it is now 0.5 per cent of total tonnage.

Industry leaders have pointed out that United Kingdom shipping has to compete with foreign fleets whose governments offer strong incentives for the employment of their nationals. What has happened is that it has not been able to compete. The shipping companies have been forced to go offshore, they have been forced to operate under flags of convenience, they have been forced to man their ships with foreign labour. That is what will inevitably happen if this government heads down the path which it is on course for.

The government makes token gestures towards nationalism by a proposal, for instance, to attempt to entrench our national flag in legislation. What about some realistic nationalism? Our products, as a result of this action, will not be carried by our ships proudly displaying our national flag. They will be carried by rust buckets displaying disgraceful flags of convenience.

The unfortunate reality is that at some time, perhaps within the next 20 years or the next 50 years, there may well be a situation where Australia is involved in further international conflict. It has occurred and, indeed, the unfortunate reality is that it will probably recur. A number of speakers have addressed the significance of the maritime industry to our defence. Again the government is throwing away that resource; again it is showing the hypocrisy of its false boasts of encouraging Australian nationalism.

The lack of trained seafarers is obviously going to be a future problem. The shipping companies, even if they themselves do not go offshore, but because they will need to make their contracts of employment in another country, will be engaging foreign labour. We will lose the benefit of some $4 million a year of training which our industry puts into its labour force and which flows those skills on to our industry generally.

If, particularly in the light of the November report, Ships of shame, the government is prepared to tolerate a situation where safety is significantly compromised, it should be prepared—indeed, the minister also should be prepared—to provide a personal indemnity to those involved in our tourist industry who will suffer when, inevitably, one of these ships of shame goes down off our coastline and destroys that section of our coastal environment.

If that were to occur in our Barrier Reef area, no amount of money could address the loss. That is precisely what is on the cards. That report on the ships of shame showed that one flag of convenience vessel traversed our coastline through the Great Barrier Reef unescorted and unpiloted. Luck—and it was only luck—prevented an environmental disaster on that occasion. Yet the government is forcing our industry into a situation where it will have no alternative but to operate through such flag of convenience vessels.

In terms of the environment, the shipping industry has made a tremendous input, improving its energy efficiency by 54 per cent in recent years compared to an improvement of only about nine per cent in the road transport industry. Generally, it decreases the problems of the road congestion, noise congestion and general road traffic our travelling public has to tolerate should they want to go away on their holidays.

A number of speakers have already spoken of the significance of the Australian shipping industry to our balance of payments. The government, because it predicts, I think one speaker said, a saving to the government of $54 million in total over the next four years, wants to risk about $4 billion a year in foreign revenue earned by our industry. The mathematics simply do not add up. The government is torpedoing this industry in a reprehensible and retrospective fashion when shipowners, as I have mentioned, have already committed not millions but billions of dollars to restructuring this industry and updating their fleet.

Let us look at the government's reasons for this legislation. One speaker got up and said that we do not understand how bad the MUA is. He purported to relate some factual circumstance where some individuals objected to a ship sailing because of a different coloured toilet seat. That is what it boils down to. This government is destroying our shipping industry because it believes people have stopped ships sailing because of different coloured toilet seats. There is nothing more logical in the government's decision making processes than that blind prejudice. It is a disgraceful act and it is one based on blind prejudice. It was 150 years ago that a union advocated the introduction of the Plimsoll line. One wonders whether this government would also have been opposed to it because employees were going to receive some benefit through not drowning at sea. It is an outrageous act by any government, but more so when this government puts the legislation on its agenda so early upon obtaining government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996, because it is a genre of legislation which I suspect we will see more of in this term of government. It demonstrates that, as a government, they just have no idea of the role that government needs to play in terms of effective industry development of key sectors of our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, in effect, a strategy that will scuttle the shipping industry in this country, and it will scuttle it just as it has emerged into a modern, competitive and world‐class fleet. But emergence into that modern, competitive, world‐class fleet was only achieved because the government of the day, the former Labor government, was prepared to develop the consensus approach to getting the needed reforms in the industry and to steering that reform. It did not, as some on the other side would suggest, see us providing misguided incentives to the shipping industry.

Whilst incentives were paid, which this legislation now seeks to knock off, they were incentives entirely directed to correcting distortions that existed in the nature of the international shipping industry. The fact is that a competitive marketplace does not exist in international shipping and, to the extent to which we do not have a level playing field, not only is the role of government important in setting the framework, in getting the parties together, in developing the networks, but also it is absolutely essential that, to the extent possible, it can use the policy arms, whether it be through taxation or other forms, to address the distortions, to correct that which the market is clearly not in itself capable of doing.

That was the Labor approach, but what is this government's approach? It is an approach built on two fundamental thrusts, one of which is to cause industrial mayhem by taking on a significant union in this country—not a union that has shown an unwillingness to cooperate, to embrace change, to support international competitiveness. The other thrust is built around ideology, a view that a union such as this should not have as much influence and that it would be better if it had no influence. Rather than a consensus approach, the confrontation approach is adopted in two major forms—not in legislation that is before us at the moment but there are comments clearly flagging it.

The first of the confrontational approaches is in the IR legislation which has been referred to and will be introduced in this House, I suspect tomorrow, with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) making great play of signalling out the MUA, the Maritime Union of Australia. If it is not enough to gut the safety nets, the fundamental protections of the trade unions and their members, we also see the second barrel effect, the ideological commitment to get rid of cabotage—against all the international trends. The government would dismantle another one of those mechanisms that is simply a response to what the major players are doing and the correction of a distortion.

BREAK.PARA: Industrial mayhem is one side of the government's approach. The other, which this legislation goes specifically to, is to effectively cut out the industry support, the sort of support and assistance that is necessary to deal with these distortions to try to level up the playing field so that no matter what you do in terms of internal reform you are not still behind the eight ball because of the way the international shipping industry is structured.

These two items—one of which is being repealed and the other is called an amendment but by changing the date it is effectively the same as a repeal—are essentially saying, `We won't give you that support any more. We will ignore the fact that the rest of the world is doing things differently and making it impossible for Australian flag shipping to compete. We're going to strip away the very basis of support for that industry'.

That is what this legislation is about. We oppose it in its specifics but we also oppose it in the broader context in which it is cast: the failed model of conflict, which is the ideological bent of the coalition parties, despite all of the progress that has been made under Labor and the consensus approach. Such a model maintains the stupidity of believing that, simply by asserting that the free market will function, a shipping industry can flourish. It will not and, under these measures, not only will we have industrial mayhem in the industry but we will also see the effective scuttling of what has been a hugely successful growth in this industry.

I do not know whether the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Andrew Thomson), who is at the table, is aware of the fact that, since the reforms that Labor has introduced into the shipping industry, we have seen $2 billion of investment into Australian flag vessels. That investment would not have occurred were it not for the reform strategy introduced and steered by the Labor government with the cooperation of all parties.

Let us just go to what this legislation specifically does. In the first instance it repeals the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Act from 1 July. This was an act introduced by the former government in response to a finding from a review set up into the shipping industry, a review which was asked to find out why it was that Australian shipping was uncompetitive in terms of international marketplaces.

What that review found—and this was the Rae Taylor report—was that as a result of the changed overseas situation the competitive gap between Australian ships and comparable overseas ships was about $2 million per ship per year. The main reason for that gap was that most of the shipping against which we had to compete did not pay taxes. The employees did not pay taxes when they were on the blue water. What this legislation that Labor introduced did was to provide a grant to the shipping companies.

I know that our then opponents tried to say that this was a perk for seamen, that what we were doing was cutting their tax. The advantage did not go to the seamen, the advantage went to the shipping companies. It went by way of a grant to make them competitive with those with which they had to compete.

So what you are doing is not getting at the employees—which I think some of you think you are, saying they were a protected species and why should they get what the rest of the work force does not get—you are getting at the companies. You are getting at them in one of the most stupid ways possible. After having investigated the reasons why it was difficult for them to compete and after recommending a solution where the benefit went directly to the companies to enable them to compete, you are now going to knock it off. I do not think that there could be a more stupid decision than this, especially coming so early in the life of this government. This will see the effective halting of any future investment in this industry, as will the decision, which is the next part of this composite piece of legislation, to bring forward the sunset provision applying to ships, the capital grants act.

Under that act there was a taxable grant of seven per cent of the purchase price provided to the purchaser of an Australian trading ship, an Australian flag vessel, subject to it complying with specified crewing requirements. In other words, it was leverage to ensure that the vessel built was crewed in accordance with internationally competitive crewing levels.

We have heard the argument that we are over-crewed, that Australia is uncompetitive. This was the very mechanism by which we made the new vessel competitive. This was saying, `You don't get the tax break unless you come to an arrangement that crews it in accordance with Australian standards.' Not only was it driving competitiveness, it was ensuring investment in the Australian shipping industry. These two pieces of legislation were vital components in a number of things that the Labor government put together to encourage the expansion of the Australian flag shipping industry.

Our approach was built around three interlocking components. One was the provision of an institutional structure through which change could be negotiated, and that reform goes way back to the early 1980s. The then Minister for Transport, the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), was actively involved in that. Labor has had a very large number of extremely effective transport ministers. The reform process went back to the implications of the Crawford report and culminated in 1989 in the Shipping Industry Reform Authority chaired by the person who is now the Lord Mayor of Melbourne, Ivan Deveson. I might add that I was privileged to be a member of that committee. In my previous role in the trade union movement I was part of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority. That became the vehicle by which we have seen, with the recommendations from all of those reviews and the strategy put in place post‐1989, this huge expansion in Australian shipping. We have seen $2 billion of investment in Australian vessels that would not have occurred, jobs that would not have been created, and services that would formerly have had to come from imports.

What that Shipping Industry Reform Authority came down with was a commitment to micro‐economic reform by getting an assurance from industry that, if we reviewed the crewing levels, if we got the crewing levels down, if we introduced multiskilling, industry, in turn, would invest. There is no point in doing these things unless what you can build is job security for the work force in question. We essentially developed an arrangement that said to the work force, `In return for the structural change and in return for you adopting new practices and new efficiencies, we will guarantee your industry.' It will be done through a combination of things that involve extra investment into the industry, a commitment by the private sector, the shipowners, and a commitment by the government of the day to develop this framework for consensus agreement on the reforms. There were also some important incentives, as I have said, aimed at correcting the international distortions in the shipping industry.

The other thing we did as part of this package was to contribute to the adjustment costs of the industry. Clearly, if you are going to downsize the crews that run the vessels, there are going to be people who can no longer be accommodated within the industry. Redundancy packages were necessary as were significant retraining costs. You cannot expect a work force that did single duties to become suddenly multiskilled unless you are prepared to invest in their training. That was part of the arrangement that the government was prepared to participate in together with industry support. Part of the arrangement was the fiscal support, the direct injections which are now going to be abolished by this new government. This government talks about the need to encourage success and growth in industry. But when it has got a $2 billion expansion in an industry that, effectively, was going out the back door—that was sinking—one of the first pieces of legislation it comes into the parliament with is something to sink that industry. That is not terribly smart, but I think it demonstrates that there is not proper understanding on that side of the House as to what is needed to get investment or industry in this country going.

Let us look at what the results have been from the reform package that Labor introduced and which is now going to be dismantled by the current government. What we saw were major reductions in crew complements. Before this package was put together the average crewing level on Australian vessels was around 35. We dropped that to 18—nearly halved it—by agreement with the unions concerned. Sure, there had to be these support packages put together but we got to that. The significance of 18 is that that is what the rest of the world does. We do not argue that we should not be internationally competitive. We simply say that if we are going to move to international competitiveness there should be assistance. We should not be kidding ourselves that those other countries are not helping their own industries. But what do we do now? This government comes in and says, `Thanks very much for all the pain so far as the work force is concerned, but we are going to cut away the commitments that were made by the previous government because we do not believe in them.' What you are trying to do is to unscramble the eggs. The reality is that you think that it is about taking on the unions when, in fact, you are going to scuttle the shipping industry in this country. We have seen, as a result of the package, not just the adjustments in crewing but a huge upgrading in the Australian fleet.

We have seen labour and capital productivity and fuel efficiency all significantly improve over the course of the last decade. Labor productivity is up 80 per cent; 1.4 million tonnes of cargo were handled per crew member in 1980‐81 with 2½ million tonnes in 1993‐94. Yet those on that side of the House say that that has not happened and that there has been no improvement in the shipping industry in this country in all that time and that we still get held up on the wharves.

What do you think those figures demonstrate? They not only demonstrate huge productivity growth but they also demonstrate that you can achieve it if you are prepared to develop a sensible strategy. Capital costs associated with building the vessels are now the lowest, according to the Bureau of Industry Economics, when compared with the eight countries with whom we have to compete.

Between 1986 and 1993 the average age of the Australian fleet has come down from almost 10½ years to a little over nine years, with the world average being 16½ years. This is a world‐class, modern fleet but it has only happened because of the strategy that Labor introduced. According to a 1992 study, the operating costs of Australian vessels are significantly below the OECD average. They may not be below the rust buckets, the ships of shame, but is that what we want to compare ourselves with? Is that the benchmark for competition? Is that what the government of the day is saying that we should compare ourselves with, the lowest cost possible regardless of the circumstances, the exploited work forces, the unsafe conditions, the ships that disappear and the lives that are lost? Is that the sort of comparison?

We are a civilised country. I would like to think we are. If we are going to make sensible comparisons, it is not with the lowest cost denominator. It is with those whom we think have also got a concept of civilisation in society. What these studies show is that we are well below the OECD cost. With regard to industrial disputes—the thing that the government says it has major concerns about—they are down from four per cent of ship days in 1982 to 0.19 per cent.

These results come about because of cooperation and a strategy that recognises that government has a role to steer the reform and to bring the parties together. Government has to contribute with the policy levers where it is necessary to get the commitment to investment. The present government's legislation today will dismantle that support. As a consequence of that dismantling we will see the scuttling of what has emerged as one of the great industry success stories in this country.

Why are you doing it? Because you do not believe in supporting industry and you think that your ideological bent can be served by taking on the unions. Time will show that you are wrong. It will be demonstrated that our track record proves that our approach is the correct one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this bill with some trepidation because there have been so many fine contributors to this debate, not the least being the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) earlier today. Of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have also heard from you as the member for Throsby and we know of your strong interest in this industry and your strong experience. I would like to make particular mention of the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) who, as you know, is a former minister in this area and a person who has taken particular interest in this industry. We hear a lot these days about more open and accountable government and bipartisan approaches and I can suggest to the Prime Minister that it might do him well to consider appointing the member for Shortland as the minister for shipping—there is nothing under the Westminster rules or traditions to prevent him from doing so. I would suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the appointment of the member for Shortland as the minister for shipping in this place might put a situation in place where we might see the retention of an industry very important to the economy, and we might see a commonsense approach to the industry rather than the union bashing exercise or the ideologically driven policy approach we are seeing from the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am appalled at the thought of the passing of this shipping legislation. It really poses the question, the same question that has been asked on a number of occasions by earlier speakers, of what this legislation is all about. Is it about creating a more efficient industry? Is it about promoting competitiveness within our own local industries? Is it really about this ideologically driven IR agenda we have before us? Is it about this squaring up approach of the government in terms of members of the Maritime Union of Australia?

The passing of this bill will sound the death knell for the Australian shipping industry. It will result in the loss of basic shipping investment and jobs, a general downgrading of the fleet and it will result in a situation of ships being registered in countries where shipping laws are less stringent than ours. Also, the environmental concerns associated with the poor standard of ships in our waters and ports should be of concern to us all. The outcomes of this legislation are horrendous and they remove Australia as a world shipping player.

The OECD endorses the worldwide practice of positive adjustment assistance in shipping. In real terms, positive adjustment assistance is about assisting industries to perform better. Australia, finally, has legislation in place which meets the OECD endorsed levels of positive adjustment and assistance for the shipping industry but now the coalition government wants to repeal this legislation and put Australia back a few paces.

What is wrong with a bit of government assistance? Thankfully, many industries in my electorate enjoy government assistance, including the rural sector. In terms of the role of government, that is certainly what government is all about. Even the most right wing economists understand the benefits of positive adjustment assistance and all the major shipping nations have packages in place. By taking this assistance away the coalition government will be taking Australia well and truly out of the shipping race. There will not be any need to talk about the forces of competition and the level playing field because we will not be in the field at all. The fact of the matter is that shipping is an international business and we must maintain assistance that is on a par with the assistance that is provided by our competitors.

A responsible government needs to continue to foster improvement in industry. We need to assist our industries to improve and compete. We need to protect our environment and our people employed in the shipping industry. We will not encourage a competitive shipping industry with this legislation; instead we will encourage a fleet of ships of convenience.

The problem with this bill is that it is taking away a scheme that has worked very well. In its 1992‐93 report the transport department said that an internal evaluation of the shipping grants scheme proved that the scheme had played a vital role in the reforming of our shipping industry. It had assisted the upgrade of ships which in turn meant lower crewing numbers and improved productivity and efficiency. In 1980 the average crew on board Australian ships was 33 because of the scheme and, in high‐tech ships, this number has dropped to 18.

The government argues that this legislation will force our shipping industry to be more competitive. This claim is simply a farce. This is a direct attack on the Maritime Union of Australia. It is a poor excuse for being able to stand here in parliament and attack under privilege our crews and their representative body. Let me suggest that if life as a merchant sailor was so good then why aren't some of the coalition members looking to give it a go?

Let us look at some of the absolute rubbish being trotted out by the government about the MUA. Firstly, they say that the reform package has not produced results. However, Australian crew numbers have dropped and they are as good as, and in some cases better than, those operating in other OECD countries. There is no demarcation. Australian seafarers are internationally trained and these initiatives continue. The MUA has accepted and begun industry enterprise bargaining on a ship by ship basis.

It is easy to see that the coalition have not been in government for a long time. They want to treat the unions as they would have done 20 years ago. Unions are not the obstructionist, self‐serving, greedy bastard clubs that the coalition make them out to be. Unions are professional and representative bodies. They have talented people and deserve to be consulted and made part of the decision making process.

The principles of international best practice are wasted on a coalition that wants to put Australia back on the industrial battleground. It is baiting the Australian unions into industrial warfare. The harmony which has been fostered and the measurable improvements which have been produced as a result of this legislation will be wiped out. How can you blame the unions for their aggression when they are being blatantly baited and defiled as an organisation?

In this place I have spoken at some length about regional development and, while I do not have a port or any direct participation in the shipping industry in my electorate, I do have close to my electorate the port of Newcastle. The port of Newcastle is the lifeblood of the Hunter Valley generally. Members do not need to be reminded of the efficiency gains that have been achieved in the port of Newcastle in recent years. It is a port of which we can be proud. We can also be proud of the Australian mariners who service that port and the role they play in the economic wellbeing of the Hunter generally.

The Prime Minister has described himself as the most conservative leader this country has seen. Let me talk about that conservatism and what it means. Conservatives believe that government descends from high to keep erring people from harming one another. Secondly, they do not believe that government should be involved in social change. They do not believe that social improvement can come about by positive and conscious action. Conservatives believe that it is an unfortunate fact of life and of human nature that some people are better than others and that such superior people should be entrusted with guarding the values of institutions and of society that are inherited from the past. This is the philosophy of the Prime Minister and his colleagues in the cabinet. It is also the philosophy of the National Party's squattocracy. It is not the view of government that I hold.

The member for Hotham (Mr Crean), speaking just before me, spoke a little about the role of government. The word `government' derives from a Greek word meaning to steer a ship. In the context of this debate that is most appropriate indeed. The implication is that the helmsman is in control. Only he has the knowledge and the expertise to ensure that the crew of the ship see their way safely to port. In this country, the people of our nation have entrusted the steering of the ship, the steering of the nation, to the people who are elected to this place. In this case, and indeed in many other cases of economic policy, this government is relinquishing that role. `Leave it all to the market,' they say, `It'll be okay. It is the level playing field,' they tell us, `It'll all be okay.'

As I said in an earlier debate, the level playing field really is a misnomer, and it is a misnomer particularly in the case of the shipping industry. How can we expect the Australian shipping industry to compete when all these other OECD nations are giving their industry the support they are? These other countries recognise the importance of the industry in terms of employment; they recognise the importance of the industry to our balance of payments account; they recognise the importance of the industry to our national security; and they recognise the importance of the industry to the economy generally. Why this government continues to relinquish this very important role—that is, the steering of this nation, the steering of its wellbeing—is beyond me. As so many earlier speakers have said, this legislation is really about a square‐up, this obsession the coalition has with what I describe as responsible members of the Maritime Union of Australia.

This industry is very much the lifeblood of our country. This industry plays a role within the environment. We cannot afford to open our coastal shipping, for example, to the ships of shame we have seen described in those reports that have been mentioned earlier in the day. I implore the government to reconsider their position on this. I implore the government to reopen the avenues of consultation with the Maritime Union of Australia.

Does the phrase `full access to family allowance' actually mean that migrant families will be restricted to $22.70 per fortnight for each child instead of up to $121.10 per fortnight per child, which is available to other low income Australian families? Was it always the government's intention, including before the election, to exclude migrants from the higher rates of family payments for a period of two years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I told the Leader of the Opposition yesterday, I believe that what we introduced in the legislation was consonant with what was contained in the policy document. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that, apparently unlike the Labor Party, the coalition makes absolutely no excuse whatever for making a policy change which will prevent a situation arising where people come to this country on the basis that they have been sponsored and, as soon as they get here, go on the unemployment list.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition may be happy with that arrangement and the Labor Party may be happy with that arrangement, but I can tell those members opposite that the Australian people are not happy with that arrangement. The Australian people are perfectly happy to support a measure which very clearly and very simply stops people coming to this country as immigrants on the basis of sponsorship and, after having that sponsorship undertaking immediately repudiated, going on the unemployment list. That situation is happening.

As those opposite will know, many of the immigrant communities have unemployment levels of 50 to 60 per cent. We do not regard it as acceptable that people can have a sponsorship arrangement but, when they come to this country, that sponsorship arrangement is immediately broken, and people can go on the unemployment list.

Labor members might think that is satisfactory, but I can tell you that the Australian community does not. The Australian community very strongly supports this measure. I will say to the Leader of the Opposition again that what we have committed ourselves to in the legislation is utterly consonant with what was in the policy document.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports today suggesting that the fairest way of ensuring that younger generations can afford to retire in financial security is to ensure that the federal government produces a balanced budget? Is the government taking action to ensure that it reduces its spending to match its income, or is the government prepared to spend more than it earns and let future generations deal with the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Boothby for his question. My attention has been drawn to a very interesting speech made yesterday by Mr Ian Macfarlane, the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. Mr Macfarlane assumed his position under the tenure not of this government but of the former government, so he cannot be regarded in any sense as being anything other than a completely neutral spokesman on these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Macfarlane made a number of very interesting observations about the ongoing debate about fiscal policy in this country. I draw the attention of everybody in the House to the following paragraph from his speech, when he had this to say:

Spenders are often seen in the public debate as compassionate and generous people, and those who favour restraint as Scrooge‐like accountants. One could, however, equally view it as a contest between those who are willing to take advantage of the next generation and those who wish to protect it.
I repeat this phrase. There is a distinction:
. . . between those who are willing to take advantage of the next generation and those who wish to protect it.

We are the ones who will protect it. This debate, with all of its bluster, will not alter that. This debate about fiscal consolidation concerns whether you are prepared to protect future generations or whether you are prepared to take advantage of them. If the opposition's track record in government is any guide, they belong to the group of people who are prepared to take advantage of future generations and not protect them.

BREAK.PARA: For five years, the Labor Party followed a policy of fiscal laxity. You failed to take advantage of the alleged economic upswing. You allowed public debt to accumulate. You left the fiscal position of this country in a highly vulnerable state. Instead of acknowledging that failure and recognising that you took advantage of future generations of Australians, you have sought refuge in trying to create an atmosphere of fear and loathing about the attempts of this government to achieve fiscal consolidation.
What Ian Macfarlane has done in his speech is expose the essential humbug of what you are about. He made a number of very pertinent observations. He said:
There are a number of ways in which fiscal policy decisions taken by members of this generation—
and that is all members of this parliament—
can impose a burden on future generations. The most obvious case is where recurrent spending runs ahead of taxation.

The Labor Party would know all about that, because that is the inheritance you left to the incoming government. In your craven desire to take advantage of future generations, you allowed recurrent spending to run ahead of taxation. You knew there was a problem, but you took advantage of future generations. You sat on your hands and now you have the gall to insult the Australian people and pretend that there is no problem at all. You are revealed as a humbug and a failure.
An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On my right, members on my right! I must remind members of the public in the gallery that, whilst they may enjoy the proceedings, their intervention is not appreciated.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will get on with his question.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister and follows my first question. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, can I perhaps preface my answer by saying that my exuberant reaction to your admonition to the gallery was not meant to be disrespectful to you. If it was, I apologise in deference to you.

ANSWER.PARA: I find the Leader of the Opposition very hard to fathom, I really do. I thought a little while ago one of his mates was on their hind legs asking: will you please explain the difference between what they were claiming to be the savings from this measure and what we allege the savings to be?
