BREAK.PARA: We are being invited to treat seriously a proposition from the Leader of the Australian Democrats that, at a time when you have an $800 million negative cash flow, at a time when you are paying a 55 rising to 60 per cent dividend, at a time when you have a $100 million special dividend, at a time when you are making large capital investments to extend the services of Telstra to rural and regional areas of Australia—including the very important ISDN and digitisation program which was committed by the coalition in my speech to the National Farmers Federation last year—and at a time when Telstra is delivering these benefits to the bush, we cut the archery of that support program by putting an unfair additional financial burden on Telstra.

PARA.BREAK: I have got to say, with all due respect to Senator Kernot, that that is not the solution to the problem. The only way the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia can be responsibly financed is out of a sale of one-third of Telstra. No amount of bobbing, weaving, wriggling around and proposing shonky alternative methods of funding, which amounts to noth ing more than imposing additional taxation and crippling the capital investment program of Telstra at the worst possible time, can alter the fact that the Australian Democrats on this issue are demonstrating their insensitivity to the environmental future of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's St Gregory's remarks in which he said of the two-year waiting period for social security benefits: `Of course it doesn't apply to family allowance and other benefits.' Is it now a fact that cabinet has decided that the waiting period be extended to a range of payments such as child care and family payments which have never been subject to waiting periods? In particular, have you now secretly directed the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to bring to cabinet proposals for cutting access to labour market programs and Austudy for new arrivals? Are you not, with this measure and denial of full access to family payments, now in breach of both the spirit and fine print of your pre‐election commitments?

—The answer to the last question is no. So far as the first part of the question is concerned, I repeat what I said yesterday in answer to an almost identical question from the Leader of the Opposition. The legislation we are introducing—the legislation that will give effect to our election commitment—is consonant, completely consonant, with the policy document—
—Nonsense! Absolute nonsense! What deceit.
—Might I also say—
—Who would believe you now?

—Careful. I also say to the member for Denison that the policy document was released the day before the doorstop that I gave at St Gregory's. I can only repeat to the honourable gentleman that this government quite unashamedly is introducing a policy that is in the interests of the Australian taxpayer. It is not a breach of our election undertaking. It is utterly consistent with the policy document that was released. You can fulminate as much as you like, but once again you are out of touch with the mainstream of the Australian community.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the government consider any amendments to its industrial relations package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be introducing its industrial relations package tomorrow, entitled the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. It will be a very important bill. It provides Australians with real prospects of jobs, high living standards in the future and one of the answers to the chronic economic problems which we inherited from the previous government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have already detailed to the House the extensive consultation process that has been involved in the preparation of the bill. I am very happy to say in answer to the honourable member's question that we see that consultation process continuing when the bill is in the parliament, both in the lower house, where it will be debated next week, and in the Senate. It is quite proper for the Senate to have a parliamentary committee review the provisions of this bill. We welcome that. That is sensible. The committee will presumably allow people to make submissions on the bill and various matters will arise as a result of that sensible and constructive appraisal of the bill in that Senate process.

We will receive further representations. I have no doubt that we will propose some government amendments. There will be amendments from the Democrats. There will be amendments from the other minor parties in the upper house, including the minor party on the other side in here. That is going to make a really good bill an even better bill. We welcome that process. That is a normal parliamentary process. There is a recent parallel on this issue and that is the 1993 legislation introduced by the previous government—the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. That bill went to the Senate and a Senate committee examined it on that occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I am concerned that you might wish to draw to the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations that he may be inadvertently misleading the House. Obviously, he is not aware that the Liberal Party changed the standing orders in the Senate after that time to ensure that that process of 1993 would not apply to bills such as this.
—There is no point of order.

—What happened in the Senate is that there was a committee which operated for just under a month, from 28 October until 24 November 1993. In that reasonable time span the committee was able to examine and appraise the bill. My response to that timetable is that, if that was a fair timetable in respect of the previous legislation and the Senate committee's consideration of it, then there should be exactly the same treatment for us with the legislation that we are proposing. There is an even stronger reason why we should get equal and fair treatment in the Senate—
—You will. You certainly will.

—A declaration of obstruction by the Leader of the Opposition! If you look at what happened in the 1993 election, there was no mention of a reform bill during that election. This reform bill in 1993 materialised out of so‐called `thin air' after the 1993 election and, as soon as we read it, it was clear what it was. It was a payback to your mates in the union movement. There was no consultation with the wider community. This was the ACTU sending its bill to the then government.

BREAK.PARA: What a contrast that is to the circumstances now facing the Senate; that is, we have a bill built on the principles and the policies which we took to the Australian people in an open, transparent, consultative way, policies which were endorsed by the Australian people on 2 March. So there can be only one fair treatment when a comparison is made to the previous passage of this matter in the Senate. It was a committee. We accept the committee—it is a good idea—and we will welcome sensible, constructive suggestions. Of course, we will not welcome obstructionism by the Senate.

This package is aimed at giving people a fair go, giving young people a chance of a job and giving small business a chance to operate their businesses in a way which is fair to small business and to the people working within them. On that basis, there ought to be a fair and expeditious hearing of this bill when it comes to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Did the forward estimates presented with the 1995 budget allocate approximately $350 million for additional land acquisition, planning and construction work at Badgerys Creek? Was a further $260 million allocated for roadworks associated with the airport? Is it not the case that the minister's recent policy initiative regarding a second Sydney airport is really just an attempt to delay and eventually eliminate over half a billion dollars worth of transport infrastructure expenditure over the next three years?

—If you are asking me to give you details as to what our budget position will be in advance of the budget, I can only advise the honourable member that he will have to wait until 20 August. If the second part of his question is whether this is a process of trying to delay anything, I can answer the question by saying no, it is not. It is a process designed to guarantee that Sydney will get a second airport without any further unnecessary delay, which is something that you could not have guaranteed if you were in government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: is the minister opposed to the appointment of people from a political background as Australia's diplomatic representatives or heads of mission overseas?
—I thank the member for Bradfield for his question. Members on the other side of the House will be pleased to hear, as I am sure members on this side of the

BREAK.PARA: House will be pleased to hear, that as a matter of principle the government does not oppose the appointment of former politicians to heads of mission appointments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can sit down now, thank you.

—You would like me to sit down now, wouldn't you, because you don't want to hear the rest of the answer, which is this: the previous government made three diplomatic appointments which are still in place and which were political appointments. The first was Dr Blewett as the high commissioner to London.
—A good appointment.
—As the Prime Minister says, that was a good appointment. Dr Blewett is doing an excellent job in London. Actually, he is doing a better job in London than he did here! The second appointment—
—And who is next? Come on.
—You are still talking, aren't you? You babble on. We should have a chamber for the Leader of the Opposition all to himself. He can ask the questions, he can answer the questions, he can interject—
—Mr Speaker—
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs will resume his seat. I hope the Leader of the Opposition has an honourable point of order.
—I thought I was making a kindly suggestion to the Minister for Foreign Affairs that he ought to follow Dr Blewett.
—There is no point of order.
—You can't stop talking. Really!

BREAK.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, Mr Speaker; I talk a lot, but not that much. The second appointment was the appointment of Michael Tate, who was the Minister for Justice and a senator from Tasmania and who is currently the ambassador in The Hague. He has asked that his appointment be brought to an end during the course of this year and we will accede to his request. The third appointment is that of the former President of the Senate, Mr Sibraa, as the high commissioner to Harare. I would have to say I think Mr Sibraa is doing a good job in Harare. We are very happy to keep him on in that position and he will do that.

BREAK.PARA: I do not have any objection in principle to these appointments but I would like to make another point. The Australian government has 81 Executive Council appointments around the world: ambassadors, high commissioners and so on. Only three of those 81 appointments are paid at the level of a permanent head. When I asked my department which three, I guessed they would be Washington, Tokyo and Jakarta. At a rough guess, I would imagine it would be the three biggest missions. Mr Speaker, I was astonished to learn that of the 81 the three who are paid the highest are the high commissioner to London, the ambassador in The Hague and the high commissioner to Harare!

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—At this dispatch box weren't we lectured by the former Prime Minister about the importance of Asia and engagement with Asia? But we pay our ambassador in the Hague more than our ambassador in Jakarta; we pay our ambassador in the Hague more than we pay our ambassador in Tokyo. That says something about the true priority of the previous government. It was not regional engagement or a strategic plan for foreign policy, but looking after their mates—and they sure did that. So, in conclusion—
—No, keep going!

—I have two more points to make—because the Prime Minister insists. The ambassador in the Hague and the ambassador in Harare each get paid $49,000 a year more than ambassadors in those posts would get paid if they were public servants. At the beginning of my answer I said that this government did not object in principle to appointing former politicians as heads of mission but I can give the House the assurance that, if this government does make such appointments, those people will be paid at the appropriate Public Service rates; they will not be paid on the grand scale the Labor Party paid its mates.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Is it a fact that you asked for the resignation of the board members of CASA and did not receive it? How can you then, as minister, have confidence in and have to take responsibility for people you obviously have no confidence in? How do you rationalise the Howard centralist coalition policy of cutting down on government when you intend to increase the numbers on the board of CASA by 40 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The House would be aware—and it has been well reported in the paper; it is nothing new—that the members of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority wish to remain in their posts. The House would also be aware that of the four members of the board who are appointed by the government to that board, only one has any aviation experience. That person is Mr Geoff Molloy who was formerly a Qantas pilot and an RAAF pilot prior to being in Qantas. Three of the four do not have any prior aviation experience. It was a stated policy of the coalition, in opposition, that we would appoint persons to the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority who had appropriate qualifications, skills and experience in the aviation industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In light of the fact that the current four members of the board wish to remain there, and in order to fulfil our election commitment—which is an important commitment to us in light of the importance of this organisation to the people of Australia—we are seeking to add an additional two members to the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. This brings the total of members of the board to six. Those new people will have appropriate skills, experience and background in the aviation industry in order to ensure that the people of Australia who use our aviation system can have confidence that people with the appropriate skills are running this very important organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is he aware of reports that the government's workplace relations legislation will remove restrictions on part‐time work? What effect will this have? In particular, how will it benefit women and people with family responsibilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the member for Gilmore for asking me that question. I foreshadow to the House that the workplace relations bill when introduced tomorrow will, amongst its objects, include the following:

ANSWER.PARA: Assisting employees to balance their work and family responsibilities effectively through the development of mutually beneficial work practices with employers.

I am very happy to say that one of the many hallmarks of this legislation will be that it will usher in a new and exciting era for both men and women in the work force to more effectively combine their work and family responsibilities.

I know that those who sit opposite, who over the years have been long and loud in their protestations on behalf of Australian women, are not only embarrassed at the pathetic representation of the number of women in this parliament on the Labor Party side but are also embarrassed that it is a Liberal government that is going to introduce a measure that thousands of women in the work force will applaud. For the first time some respectability will be given to the notion of permanent part‐time work. We are going to entrench in the legislation a regime that will enable men and women—particularly women—to combine their work and family responsibility.

You have raved on for years about how you have represented the interests of Australian workers but what you have done with your centralised wage fixing system, by becoming a footnote to the ACTU in these matters, is create a situation where many women are denied the opportunity of combining their work and family responsibilities. In many cases they have to make a choice between being permanently out of the work force and being a full‐time participant in the work force. Instead, so many women, when their children are young, want through part‐time work to combine their work and family responsibility. We are going to allow them to do that in a free, flexible and unfettered way, and in a fashion that you always denied them. You carried on as though you were their friend, but you were only the friend of the organisation that the member for Batman used to run.

I am very happy to say to the House that one of the many reforms that will be contained in the workplace relations bill will usher in a new era enabling the women of this country to effectively and beneficially combine their work and their family responsibilities. It will not lead, as one ACTU spokesman so stupidly said yesterday, to the casualisation of the Australian work force. What it is going to do in fact is enshrine as respectable the principle of permanent part-time work and it will give unparalleled opportunities to combine work and family responsibilities. It represents the modern, thoroughly contemporary approach of the coalition to allowing men and women in Australia to more effectively combine their family and their workplace responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. As the minister responsible for the family, and recognising the important role of women in the family, particularly where the woman is the sole provider, does the minister agree with the comments made by the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Sue Walpole, that the government's industrial relations policy will limit the ability of women to achieve workplace equality and, in particular, to achieve equal pay?
—Not even you believe that sort of stuff, John.
—By Sue Walpole; I certainly don't.

—I thank the member for that question. The fact is that the Prime Minister has just very adequately answered that question in his previous answer. Jennie George in fact acknowledged that under the accord women had suffered dreadfully.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh yes they had. Those figures are on the public record. All that the accord did was protect men in the community—male wages. Under the accord women were still earning less than the equivalent male wage, and that situation had continued. In addition to this the Prime Minister was quite right when he said that, under the rigidities of the industrial relations system that we had to suffer under a Labor government, there was no flexibility for women in the work force.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of major delays caused to the settlement of compensation and personal injury cases following legislation passed last year by the Labor government? What hardship has been caused by Labor's legislative mess?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the issue the honourable member raises. It relates to the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act, passed in the dying days of the Keating government. The act came into effect on 1 February this year. Under the legislation a person cannot receive a compensation settlement until the Health Insurance Commission has determined whether or not there are any spent benefits that it is owed. This is supposed to prevent double dipping. This is something the then opposition supported.

ANSWER.PARA: But the legislation has led to particular problems, and I will give honourable members three examples. A person in Canberra had a $300,000 payout delayed while the Health Insurance Commission determined that it was owed nothing. A Brisbane person had a payout of $1 million delayed while it was determined there was a $98 bill to the Health Insurance Commission. Another person in Brisbane had their payout of $442,000 delayed while the Health Insurance Commission determined nothing was owing.

Why are we having these sorts of delays? The very simple answer is that the previous government did not think to consult the Health Insurance Commission as to the logistics of going through the claims. It was predicted that there would be 25,000 claims in New South Wales. In the 3½ months, we have received 45,000 claims in New South Wales alone. There are extraordinary delays in people receiving their compensation payouts. The whole system is in chaos and people who have taken contingent liabilities, such as a mortgage on the expectation of a payout, are now risking losing their home. Because of a lack of consultation, no thought was given to how this would actually work in operation.

Yesterday I met with the Bar Council, the Insurance Council of Australia and the Law Society of New South Wales to discuss this issue. We have reached broad agreement as to how this situation might be fixed. It is going to require a legislative base. In the interim, the Health Insurance Commission has put staff on overtime and it will also take note of any special cases of hardship. But these delays are causing hardship to many thousands of people around the country.

It seems, though, that I am not the only person concerned by these delays. A kind person has passed me copies of the minutes of the ALP Left caucus meeting yesterday. I notice that amongst the attendees was the member for Dobell, the shadow minister for health. I did not realise he was a member of the Left; I always thought he was the anointed one of the New South Wales Right. Nonetheless, it is nice to see that he is a political chameleon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I hate to break it to the minister, but I am not a member of the Left.
—There is no point of order.

—It appears that the shadow minister for health had to go before the left faction to plead the case for a motion where the Health Insurance Commission delays were raised and whether they would consider doing a private member's bill—moved Lee, seconded Macklin.

ANSWER.PARA: I can understand why the shadow minister wants to do this. They do not want to wear the blame for the complete cock‐up that has occurred in compensation payouts right around Australia because of the previous government's incompetence and failure to hold consultations. But I say to the honourable member that there is no point having a private member's bill, because everybody from the Bar Council to the trade union movement knows who to blame: those people sitting over there, who will be doing so for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Minister, prior to the decision of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to include Holsworthy as an additional site for Sydney's second airport, what advice did you provide on the removal of unexploded bombs from the Holsworthy range? Will you table the advice that you gave to your ministerial colleague? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the honourable member's question, I was given advice, as the honourable member would know. That advice included quite a lot of evidence that I have no doubt the defence department will deliver to the panel of the EIS and—
—How many bombs?

—That has to be worked out, of course. As you and the honourable member know very well, this has been a firing range and bombing site on and off since the turn of the century. I did provide evidence to the minister for transport that there were, to state it quite clearly, a number of reservations which the department has. I have no doubt that they will accurately and honestly bring those forward to those two inquiries.
—Will you table it?

—No, of course I will not because it is marked `Cabinet‐in‐confidence' accross the top. You would not expect me to throw that stuff around as lightly as the member for Dobell does. I noticed yesterday that there seems to be some idea that, because the area—it is very large, being some eight kilometres wide and 24 kilometres long—has plenty of admitted unexploded ordnances, they cannot be cleared. Mind you I will say that all that clearing, as the long-serving ex-Minister for Defence, as he so often points out, would know, would not be without some, however minuscule, residual risk. That clearing is carried out quite often in Australia today for housing developments at the request of developers. It is carried out by contractors for the Department of Defence where those sites are identified.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, we acknowledge that clearing Holsworthy of unexploded ordnance would be a costly and consuming exercise. At this time we do not know precisely where the airport will be located. That is the job—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know where the bombs are.

—Of course you do not know, and that is why we have experts to go around and do it, as we do in Cambodia, Mozambique and everywhere else, as I have no doubt we will do at the continuing request of your ex-members in Queensland, where there are still some 670 sites of unexploded ordnance. Over time they will be slowly cleared—as will, I have no doubt if the EIS and the feasibility study comes out this way and if the government decides to go this way, the unexploded ordnance at Holsworthy.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of media reports in the United States commending the Australian government's move to ban the use of landmines throughout the Australian defence forces? Is the minister further aware of the recent US military's decision to put conditional bans on the use of landmines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Adelaide for her question. The member for Adelaide has shown a particular interest in the issue of freeing the world of antipersonnel landmines. It is an issue on which she worked very hard and with great sincerity before the election, and she has continued to pursue this issue since.

ANSWER.PARA: President Clinton, honourable members may be interested to know, announced on 16 May the outcome of the United States policy review on antipersonnel landmines. The new policy commits the United States to work for a global ban on antipersonnel landmines. This is a less qualified and more pro‐active commitment than has been the case before by the United States. The United States armed forces will discontinue the use of so-called dumb, or long‐lived, antipersonnel landmines immediately, except on the Korean peninsula and for training purposes. The rest of the US inventory of dumb APL mines will be destroyed by 1999. While the US has not gone as far as Australia in terms of its interim measures—it has not banned or suspended altogether antipersonnel landmines used by its armed forces—its new policy does bring the considerable power of influence of the United States behind the campaign for a total ban on antipersonnel landmines.

When I answered a question on this subject a few weeks ago, the member for Brisbane intervened by saying, `The Americans have come to you, have they?' I suspect the tone of that intervention was a tad sarcastic, but I make this point: the Americans have come to us and we have taken a leadership role in this issue. We are delighted that the United States has come a long way towards the position annunciated by this government. I am optimistic that in the fullness of time a total ban on antipersonnel landmines will be achieved. The significance of the change in the United States' position cannot be underestimated, given the vast influence of the world's only superpower on these sorts of issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are on the subject of unexploded devices, I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Minister, have you seen the noise maps for Holsworthy international airport released by your department and published today in the Sydney Morning Herald ? Are you aware that more than 20,000 residents in the suburbs of Wattle Grove, Holsworthy, Hammondville, Ingleburn, Minto and Macquarie Fields are within the deafening and lifestyle destroying 25 ANEF noise contour? Minister, by this test alone shouldn't you abandon your crazy unexploded plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —A weak ending, I can tell you! The government's initiative, which was announced yesterday, set as its first priority the development of Badgerys Creek airport. If the environmental impact study for Badgerys Creek airport gets a negative result, we will have, as our insurance against any further delays, Holsworthy as a possible alternative site. In the process of going through the environmental impact study, we will be following the guidelines set by the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise, and those guidelines require full public consultation and full industry consultation, and it will be a transparent process.

ANSWER.PARA: In doing that, all of the things that the member for Werriwa has highlighted will have the opportunity to be aired and to be judged as to whether they are factual or not. What you have seen in today's paper cannot be described as being exact because, firstly, nobody knows if Badgerys Creek will get a negative result and, secondly, if Holsworthy is to be developed as an airport, nobody knows precisely where the strips will be and therefore where flight paths will be.

We have a process of full public and industry consultation, and it is a transparent process. I ask honourable members of this House to compare that with the process that those opposite engaged in when they did an environmental impact study on the third runway at Sydney's Mascot airport—a process carried out by Kinhills, which was, by anyone's description, a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a disgrace.

—The honourable member for Prospect says it all for me. She says it was a disgrace. It is regarded as a disgrace, and the reason it was a disgrace is that you kept it in house and you kept it secret. You did not tell the people of Sydney the truth about the third runway. In the process of that EIS, you said that there would be 13 per cent of all aircraft movements to the north. The truth of it was that there were 29 per cent of all aircraft movements to the north of Sydney's Mascot airport.

ANSWER.PARA: When it comes to the track record of who can be trusted in dealing with matters like this—where important environmental impact studies are being carried out—we certainly know that we cannot trust the Labor Party. They proved in the course of doing the EIS on Mascot airport's third runway that they did not tell the truth, and that is something we are determined not to do. We will make this process transparent, and we will build a second airport in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to table the noise maps for Holsworthy that the Prime Minister would not release before 2 March. These are the maps he would not show to the people of Hughes and south‐western Sydney before 2 March. I ask for the maps to be tabled.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. As the minister is aware, consideration of the special needs of members of families of the defence forces is an important issue for the Howard government. I therefore ask the minister to inform the House of recent measures approved by the Howard government to enhance the conditions of service for defence personnel and their families.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. He is quite right. The Howard government is particularly concerned about families with special needs, particularly where there are children who have disabilities, where they have long-term requirements that need special attention—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: McLEAY

TALK.START.PARA: —Give her some water, John.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left will come to order.
—If you are not game to touch his glass, here is some water.
—Order!
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. You can see the kindness that is always available from the Prime Minister.
—Can we have a forensic analysis of the glass of water?

—This is not a matter for point scoring or amusement; this is a matter of families in the Australian defence forces who have children with special needs who suffer when there are postings. There is hardship for those families where children are in special schools, where they need wheelchairs and where they need special tuition, and it is very difficult when they are moved from state to state.

ANSWER.PARA: Last week at the Defence Force Special Needs Support Group—a volunteer group set up by a remarkable woman, Mrs Margaret Fisk—I was very pleased to announce that there will be funding for those parents to go to the area to arrange for those special needs in advance of the posting being taken up.

The second thing I was pleased to announce is something that is across the board—that is, where defence families are posted and have dependent children in tertiary education and they cannot move for the posting. Accordingly, because we are concerned about families and keeping them together, we have said the Commonwealth will fund two visits per year for those dependent tertiary students to their parents. Indeed, the Prime Minister and this government do have the welfare of families at heart, particularly those families in our defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Acting Treasurer. In the government's assessment, what contribution to national saving will be made by bringing the budget into balance or surplus over the next two years? Isn't it the case that national saving is directly correlated to unemployment and that a fiercely contractionary budget of the kind that you are contemplating will in fact have a negative impact on saving?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in the House yesterday, the deficit inherited by this government was explained by the honourable member as being a deliberate policy choice—$8 billion was a deliberate policy choice of Labor. Everyone knows that, when you have a deficit, you have to fund that deficit, you have to borrow, you have to pay the interest on that borrowing. What this government is about is reducing public debt. That will happen when we get rid of that deficit and bring in a balanced budget. If we can reduce that deficit, as we intend to do, and reduce our spending, our servicing of that debt, that influences the interest rates, and we all know that where there is a climate for lower interest rates that assists business. Business with lower interest rates has the capacity to employ more, to enhance, to progress. The initiatives of this government will ensure that that happens. That will lead to employment growth.

ANSWER.PARA: So the fiscal consolidation that we are undertaking will bring about a much stronger economy. It will bring about confidence for investment, and that will lead to higher employment in the days ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Science and Technology. Is the minister aware of a report by the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council on Australia's future research priorities? What will be the benefits to the Australian community of the government setting national goals in science and technology?

—I thank the honourable member for Parramatta for his question. In the short time he has been in this parliament he has shown a commendable interest in science and technology, and well may that continue because you will not get much interest from that side, if any at all. By chance I have seen this ASTEC report on future needs. In fact, I launched it yesterday, by coincidence. It is a very important report. It is the first study of its kind in Australia. The report identifies the problems that lie ahead so that Australian scientists and engineers can match their research to overcome those problems. ASTEC has used the processes of foresight to evaluate the science and technology needs of Australia through to the year 2010. Foresight, whilst not having been used previously in Australia, is being used overseas to determine research priorities. So ASTEC's report is a very important first step in assessing whether the processes of foresight can help determine Australia's research priorities.

BREAK.PARA: The report identifies four key areas which are going to be part and parcel of all Australians' lives into the future: global integration, sustainable environment, information and telecommunications technology, and biological technology. Needless to say, the world is changing rapidly and over the next 15 years we will be presented with many challenges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you keeping up with the changes?

—The member for Hotham interjects. He was the first of four science ministers from the Labor Party in six years. So what kind of stability, what sort of direction, did that give in the setting of priorities—this constant turnover? To give the member for Hotham some credit, he was the best of the four but it was pretty poor competition. Following him was Ross Free, if you remember. His ministerial period was characterised by inertia. Then came Senator Chris Schacht, shortlived. He was known for his destructive administration. Then we had the apathy of Senator Peter Cook. So you have no credibility in this area. This government is seizing the agenda.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The minister was reflecting on members of the other place, and there are forms of the House available for that.
—There is no point of order.
—I also suggest he sticks to the question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: McGAURAN

TALK.START.PARA: —To continue, Albert Einstein was quoted as having said that he never worried about the future because it was always upon him, but today very few people have the luxury of sharing Albert Einstein's sentiment. We have to plan for the future. We have to make the most effective and efficient use of our science and technology and engineering so that we meet the future and shape the future and not the other way around.

INTERJECT.PARA: So to realise the hopes and aspirations of our society, of our community, we have to first set clear directions for research. The government is determined to set a long-term strategic approach so that we maximise the contribution science and technology are making to our nation's social and economic prosperity.

On behalf of the government I wish to thank the chairman of ASTEC, Dr Don Williams, his Deputy Chairman, Professor Ron Johnston, and their fellow council members for the hard work and thought they have invested in the preparation of this report. It has been a Herculean task, first conceived and then drafted over several years. I also wish to thank and congratulate the members of the reference group, the key issues round table, and the more than 3,000 Australians who participated and contributed to the preparation of this report, in which this Labor opposition has not the slightest interest. The first time you start planning for the future and adapting to the changing realities, whether it be industrial relations or science and technology, you all revert to the practices of your past. I commend the report to all members of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Does the Deputy Prime Minister recall stating emphatically at the National Press Club in the course of the recent federal election campaign `EMDG stays'? Does the minister agree with the Managing Director of the Australian Business Chamber, Mr Phillip Holt, that the government's proposed abolition of the export market development grants scheme would be `a major backward step for small and medium sized businesses, the breaking of an election promise' and `would adversely affect job creation'? Can the minister explain to the House how the abolition of the scheme would enhance Australia's export performance?

—At long last the member for Perth has got it right inasmuch as he has finally found the right minister with regard to the export market development grants scheme, other questions having been directed previously to the minister for small business. The details will be revealed on 20 August. We are working through the process of the budget.

BREAK.PARA: What is hurting exporters far more is the $8 billion deficit imposed under the Labor government's economic track record, which added to the interest rate structure and to the distortion of the exchange rate of this country. That is hurting exporters in a way for which you should hang your heads in shame. This government is about setting a systematic agenda to put our exporters on the front foot and setting the right framework to facilitate our expanded export activity. You will hear and learn more about that over the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Trade. Are you aware that in 1994‐95 the Labor government allowed export growth to Japan, which is Australia's most important export market, to decline to 2.3 per cent, which was a significantly slower growth rate than the trend rate of 7.6 per cent over the past decade? What steps will you be taking to address this drift evident under Labor and promote Australian trade with Japan and the region?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FISCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —We are losing market share in Japan, our largest trading partner. I thank the member for Herbert for his very timely question, this being the 100th anniversary year of the establishment by Japan of a consular office in Townsville.

INTERJECT.PARA: As part of a hectic visit to Japan and Indonesia last week, I pursued a number of trade policy issues to seek to make further advances with trade liberalisation, some of which were commenced by the former Minister for Trade, and I acknowledge that. With regard to regional issues, I am pleased to advise the House that both the Japanese government and the Indonesian government have reiterated their commitment to the individual action plan process of APEC. Those plans in draft form are heading to the officers' meeting at Cebu which will take place this week.

With regard to multilateral issues, both senior officials and ministerial officials of the Japanese government and the Indonesian government again committed themselves to the process of liberalisation with regard to the WTO round. Australians have legitimate concerns over questions of backsliding on agriculture, on completing the unfinished agenda of the Uruguay Round. These are matters which I pursued at various levels and, indeed, obtained some clarification on as we build towards the December Singapore summit, the first ministerial round following the signing of the Uruguay Round at Marrakech.

On bilateral issues, as part of addressing the market share circumstance, a number of breakthroughs were achieved. Members opposite might like to recall that the Japanese economy is 14 times the size of the Australian economy. It has seven times the population and is 14 times the GDP size. It is one which offers very good opportunities for a very diverse range of Australian exporters in respect of rice, high‐tech ferries, expanding legal services and the like. All of these matters were pursued, including the opening of a home building model village which reflects the increase in building material exports to Japan and which I was very happy to promote during my visit.

The somewhat dismissive attitude to two of our key Asian trading partners marks the Labor Party down again in terms of their track record. During the visit I was able to announce, in liaison with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, a 38 per cent boost in air services between Australia and Indonesia. Once again we have it right in terms of spreading it around, away from Sydney, with 10 ports of entry being granted. In relation to that boost to air services, I also took the opportunity to officially open a new Qantas office in Indonesia.

All in all, the coalition government is about a systematic set of regional working visits to further boost our trading circumstance, our export performance and the diversity of Australian exports. Those opposite might joke about this but let me remind them that it was under their government that Australia started to lose market share in some of our key export trading nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. Having reannounced our initiatives in the area of support for members of the services with dependent tertiary students and also for those with special needs dependants, will she now commit herself to the initiatives extending to single members the removal and living entitlements similar to those for married members; the extension of home purchase and sale expenses allowance; an increase in the maximum amount available under the defence home loans scheme; the extension of child‐care provisions; the introduction of occasional care provisions; the introduction of family day care services; the introduction of an ADF spouse employment program; the exemption for ADF members from changes to superannuation preservation rules; the extension of compassionate leave provisions; the extension of education assistance provisions; the introduction of spouse emergency travel; the introduction of free posting travel for special needs people; the extension of remote locality leave travel provisions; and the removal of the anomaly in the tax rebate for United Nations deployments?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BISHOP

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference between this government and that lot when they were in government is that we actually do things when we say we promise to do them. You had 13 years in government to think about the needs of special children and kids who are in need because they, as individuals, are losing the right to reach their maximum potential. Many of the things, I would point out to you, that you just read out on your list were in our policy document.

INTERJECT.PARA: As different from you, I would cite the question of child care. I would cite the question of making it easier for people to get home loans. I would check with you as a former minister that you had 13 years to do something for these people. You are in opposition; you can bleat, whinge and whine all you like. The difference between you and us is that when we say we will do it we will do it—and it took my signature to implement what I announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a document dated 10 December, some three months before the government's policy documents came out.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Business people in my electorate of Cook are continually impressing upon me the need for skilled employees to boost the productivity of their businesses. In that light, does the minister agree that training is an important element for ensuring the job readiness in particular of young people?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: REITH

TALK.START.PARA: —The government certainly does believe that training arrangements are an important element for ensuring the job readiness of Australians—young and not so young—but particularly young Australians. We include in our legislative package a series of measures designed to help young Australians—one which has been referred to already in this House—and that is in respect of junior wage rates. That is a system in place now. Labor's system was to bring an end to that as at 22 June next year, which would have meant, if it had been implemented, that a lot of young Australians would have lost their jobs.

INTERJECT.PARA: In the training area, we see a particular need to make provision for Australian workplace agreements and certified agreements to incorporate new flexible training arrangements developed under the MAAT scheme. These provisions will ensure that trainees receive an appropriate rate of pay in conjunction with an approved form of training. Under these new arrangements, it will be necessary to identify the time actually spent in productive work vis‐a‐vis the time spent in training. A traineeship must be an approved traineeship, that is, it must be approved by an appropriate training authority.

The benchmark for the rate of pay will be the hourly rate of pay for the equivalent classification in the relevant award. So, for juniors employed under such arrangements, the relevant classification will be the applicable junior rate from the relevant award. For an adult trainee, the rate will be the rate in the relevant adult classification in the relevant award. That has been the traditional means by which trainee rates of pay have been set, and we will not be departing from that traditional approach.

Where a traineeship is a national wage traineeship, the relevant rate of pay will be the wage rate specified in the national training wage award. This will ensure that trainees under the federal government's new flexible training agenda will receive an appropriate rate of pay based on the applicable award rates in tandem with formally approved training conditions.

What that all adds up to for young people is a far more flexible system. It really does give young people the chance of training opportunities in conjunction with work that will secure them a better future—and that is why this bill will properly be known in many parts of Australia as the jobs bill, the jobs package, because we have been genuinely concerned about the high rate of youth unemployment in Australia.

For 13 years the interests of young people were put to one side whilst the now opposition were principally focused on their own political interest—a comment which has been made even by people on their own side. They were more interested in saving their own political necks than they were about the fact that a lot of young people were missing out on opportunities. It is a disgrace that we have such high rates of unemployment in Australia.

To make it even worse, they have, in the existing legislation, a proposition—until it is removed by us—that would cost up to 200,000 young people their jobs. We do treat this matter very seriously, and I say to the opposition that, if they are to have any credibility on this issue, they ought to, just for once, put aside their own political interests and think about the young people who deserve a fair go. These are far more flexible arrangements, but they are fair. They provide people with proper protection.

These agreements will have to be approved by a training authority, but it also takes us away from the very rigid constraints set up by the previous government which, of course, provided in part an opportunity for the training arrangements to be a basis of recruitment into the trade union movement—not in the interests necessarily of pursuing the interests of young people but actually pushing your own political agenda and the agenda of the trade union movement. As usual, you are more interested in your relationship with the ACTU than young people.
The opposition parties ought to support these measures. They are part of the many initiatives in this package which will provide young people with a chance of a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you were kind enough to send me a copy of your letter to the member for Newcastle concerning the interpretation of standing order 144 regarding anticipation of debate and points of order raised by the member for Newcastle and me on 7 May and thereabouts. In your letter to the member for Newcastle, you concluded by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I would not regard a passing reference in an answer as being out of order. Only where a minister was truly anticipating debate on an order of the day would the rule be transgressed.
I then referred back to the question asked by the member for Aston on 7 May, about which I raised the question of standing order 144. The member for Aston asked the Treasurer:
What is the government's strategy to reduce Commonwealth debt?

Mr Speaker, in a lengthy answer, the Treasurer made reference to only one thing—the part‐privatisation of Telstra. That tempts one to conclude that, if the part‐privatisation of Telstra does not pass through the parliament, the government has no strategy to reduce Commonwealth debt. If that is not more than a passing reference, what on earth is?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wills for his question. I do not intend to revisit or to canvass the decisions that were made then. You now have a very clear indication of how we are going to handle these points of order on interpretation and other aspects of the standing orders. It is a dynamic, viable challenge, and we make the best decisions we can on the day. However, I shall revisit it in the province of my chambers.
