Australian industry and our country as a whole cannot afford it. To that end, I urge honourable members to oppose this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton), I would like to express a number of concerns about the measures which the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has brought before the parliament. I want to begin by saying that from our perspective it appears that there is no rational basis for the government's bringing forward of these measures. We can have no conclusion other than that this minister is driven by an ideological obsession with the Maritime Union of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister has had many opportunities when in opposition to attack the MUA and look at ways he could try to undermine the previous government's attempts to improve efficiency on the waterfront and amongst Australian flag and crewed ships. The Howard government now having been elected, this minister is attempting to set out on a strategy that will have a number of very deleterious effects for the Australian economy as a whole and for many people who are concerned about the future of the Australian shipping industry. I would like to make a few comparisons between the quite modest protection provided to the Australian maritime industry and the protection provided to other industries in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Modest?

—The minister interjects sarcastically, implying that the assistance provided to the maritime industry is not modest. I can certainly say that if you compare it with the assistance given to the car industry or for textile production it is modest. Why do we on this side of the House think it is important to have a deliberate industry policy that encourages investment in motor vehicle manufacture, in parts production and exports, and in textile production? The answer is that we think they are an essential part of the Australian economy and that a lot of jobs and investment can flow and a lot of export dollars can be earned for Australia by having viable motor vehicle and textile production industries. That is why we have a special tariff protection scheme for those two industries. We have a special tax concession to encourage people to invest in research and development—150 per cent tax deduction for investment in R&D. We think it is good for the economy to encourage investment in scientific research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Labor government tried to encourage investment in lots of information technology industries, a policy I hope this government continues. The great irony for us, throughout this whole debate, is to see National Party member follow Liberal Party member. They represent rural electorates and on many previous occasions have been in this chamber arguing for special assistance for rural industries because, they argue, they are important for the Australian economy. Naturally, being the reasonable people we are, on occasions we are convinced that various important sections of the rural industry do need special assistance at certain times of international cycles and demand for commodities.

We say that the maritime industry is at least as important as the car industry, the textile industry or the agricultural industry and as important as the encouraging of investment in research and development. For all those reasons we argue quite strongly that the measures the government has introduced into the House will undermine for all time one of our most crucial service industries. It is going to be a backward step if implemented by the government. If it can persuade the parliament to agree to these measures that will be regretted for decades to come.

In some way the minister has tried to suggest that the capital grants provided to companies that invest in new ships is, in some way, special assistance to the Australian maritime industry. The Labor Party has argued throughout this debate that many OECD countries provide these capital grants. Even your conservative brothers and sisters in the United Kingdom provide grants to British shipowners when they go out and invest in new shipping.

BREAK.PARA: It has been very important for the Australian maritime industry that we have tried to encourage investment in new plant and equipment and in new ships and that we have tried to ensure that we move towards having the most efficient ships possible. That could only be achieved by encouraging the updating and modernising of our fleet. That went hand in hand with the reduction in the average number of seafarers on our ships. The number has fallen from an average of 31.6 in 1986 to only 18.4 in 1995 as a result of an investment of over $2 billion which has been committed to investment in new ships. As a result, we have an Australian fleet that is half the age of the world fleet.

Having that government industry policy has been good for Australia. It has encouraged investment in new ships. I have to say that the impression the minister for transport tries to encourage, that we have an inefficient shipping fleet, is just not true. Our manning levels have improved dramatically, particularly when you look at the LNG vessels carrying our LNG to markets in Japan. The Australian ship that is owned and staffed by Australian seafarers is able to provide a much lower cost structure than that provided by Japanese seafarers—no offence to our Japanese customers.

That is a clear demonstration of the fact that in Australia in the 13 years of Labor government we were prepared to implement reforms that allowed the Australian maritime industry to become more efficient. The fact that the minister for transport gives no credit to the sacrifices that have been made by people involved in the Australian maritime industry does him little credit.

PARA.BREAK: I say to the seafarers living in my electorate who have had to undertake new training and to change the way they work when they are on vessels at sea that it is to their great credit that they have been prepared to work, often in cooperation with employers, to help develop a competitive industry and to make these sacrifices over the last 13 years. But I bet that when this minister for transport sets out on an ideologically driven campaign to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia there will be no further reason for cooperation between sea farers and employers and no further reason for cooperation between seafarers and the Howard government. I am very concerned that it is going to result in stoppages and in disruption to Australia's exports in future years, because of this ideological obsession that this government and this minister have.

BREAK.PARA: I think there is a tremendous amount of confusion in the wider community about the former government's proposal to provide employers—shipowners—with a taxable grant equal to the PAYE tax, which would otherwise be paid by seafarers. The Liberal and National parties try to create the impression that in some way the seamen are no longer paying PAYE tax. They try to create the impression that in some way the seafarers are getting some tax concession, because of discussions that took place in the last parliament between the ACTU, the government and shipping owners. Every member of this House should understand that the grant was payable to the shipping owners, not to the seamen. The grant was payable to allow the shipowners to have a lower cost structure to allow them to be more competitive with other ships that are competing on the routes to and from Australia.

We think it is important that Australia does not have a massive deficit in services. We know that through the massive growth in the tourism industry in the last 13 years, and I hope it continues to grow, Australia has a services surplus. If this government and this minister seek to undermine the efficiency of the Australian maritime industry, we will no longer have all of those Australian flag and Australian manned ships generating export dollars for Australia. What will happen is that those ships will be replaced ship by ship by vessels that have foreign flags and by vessels that have foreign seamen.

All of us know that there have been a number of reports by committees of this parliament that have expressed great concern about the ships of shame and about the levels of safety that exist in some ships that have foreign flags. Despite the intensified efforts of people who are concerned about the safety of those ships, you can never ensure that foreign flag ships are as safe as Australian flag ships. You can never ensure that the seafarers who are working on those ships have the same very high standards of training that the Australian seamen have.

For all of those reasons, we can quite rightly be greatly concerned about the environmental threat that will be posed by more foreign flag ships plying their way around the Australian coastline in future years as a result of measures this government has introduced. For all of those reasons, those of us on this side of the House will strongly oppose these measures. The minister at the table, through this ideological obsession he has of trying to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia, is embarking on a path that will do Australia great damage in future years. He will have to answer to this parliament in future days about the damage he causes to industrial relations in this industry and in many others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to take this opportunity to thank all those members from both sides of the House who participated in the debate. It is obvious that I enjoyed listening to some sectors of the debate more than I did to others, but it has been an interesting debate. It has been interesting to see how members on the Labor side are trying to reinstate their trade union roots and their trade union credentials. The speech by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), was interesting. I have never heard him speak on maritime matters before in the parliament. There is nothing like having a marginal seat to focus your mind on some of these things, and I am sure we will hear more from him in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to hear him make a number of claims, of which he needs to be reminded are not necessarily correct. For example, he claimed that we have improved our Australian shipping industry dramatically over the last few years and that we have a world competitive fleet. It is worth pointing out to him that the Bureau of Transport and Communication Economics points out that the cost of operating an Australian flag vessel, despite the hundreds of millions of dollars that the former government poured down the throat of the maritime industry, is around $2 million over and above that of industry averages around the world each year—$2 million per ship per year in excess of industry averages around the world.

He also made the very interesting point that the maritime industry deserves its protection, because it is as important as the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, the motor vehicle building industry and the farming industries. Let me point out that the previous Labor government did away with all levels of support or protection, if you like, for the farming industries.

During the last 13 years of Labor government, it did away with a great deal of the protection for the textiles, clothing and footwear industry—much of which is in your electorate. It did away with a great deal of the protection that industry enjoyed. Indeed, it has been winding down towards zero those protection levels over a number of years. The same has been the case with the motor vehicle building industry.

So the previous speaker was making the claim that the maritime industry deserves all of its protection, because it is just like the motor vehicle building industry, or the TCF industry or the farming industry. Indeed, if that were the case, then the maritime industry's protection ought to be wound down, as was the case with those industries that the previous speaker highlighted in his examples.

Another thing the previous speaker alluded to—and this has been a common theme amongst a number of Labor speakers in this debate—was that this is going to see the end of the level of cooperation between seafarers and their employers and seafarers and the government. If their level of cooperation is anything to praise, then one has to look only at the levels of industrial disputations that occurred during the last 12 or 18 months of the former Labor government.

We had an extraordinary increase in the number of strikes from the Maritime Union of Australia. Indeed, the strike club, an international organisation of shipowners around the world, does an annual assessment of strikes that affect their industry. Australia went from accounting for around 11 per cent of all maritime stoppages around the world a couple of years ago to accounting for 25 per cent. The threat is that things are going to get worse. How could they get much worse than what we experienced in the previous 12 to 18 months of the Labor government? The level of industrial disputation in the maritime industry increased dramatically and was caused in many cases by disputes that did not occur in the maritime industry—for example, the Weipa dispute. The maritime unions decided to go on strike over the Weipa dispute. It had nothing to do with them, but they felt that this was a good opportunity to go on strike.

We have these sorts of threats of an end to what has been described as a cooperative relationship between seafarers and their employers and seafarers and the government. I think the people concerned do not realise that this is something which ended a long time ago. That is why we have had such a large increase in industrial disputation on the Australian waterfront.
I heard the previous speaker say that the maritime industry has received modest levels of support from the government of old. Let us just look at this. From 1989 through to today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the family trust.

—It is not nearly as good as some of yours, old fella. What about John Dawkins, my friend? Remind yourself of John Dawkins. You can hardly talk, my friend. Many people on your side of the fence had problems when it came to tax deals.
—You can have a look at mine any day you like, John.
—You can have a look at mine. There is no problem with it, I can assure you. You fellows on that side of the House can hardly claim to be lilywhite.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because your Prime Minister never tabled yours, did he? We are certainly not following any practices that are any less than what you had in office, my friend. If you people think that those things are so import ant, why didn't you do them when you were in government?

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about modest levels of support. Three hundred and twenty million dollars from the taxpayer was allocated to the shipping industry between 1989 and the present day. In addition, some $450 million was allocated to the stevedoring sector of the maritime industry between 1989 and 1992. If we then take into account the cost of appeasing the Maritime Union of Australia over its concerns about the privatisation of ANL, which the former government tried to sell in 1991, we would have to recognise there has been an additional cost of some $150 million in losses incurred by ANL as a consequence of the delayed sale of that government enterprise.

When we add all those together—$150 million for ANL, $320 million for the shipping industry and $450 million for the stevedoring sector of the maritime industry—we find that the former government has given nearly a billion dollars worth of direct financial assistance to the maritime sector since 1989. Do the taxpayers of Australia believe a billion dollars worth of assistance to be modest? Do they believe the investment this country has made in the maritime sector to the tune of a billion dollars has delivered a dividend? Has it given us a shipping industry that is internationally competitive? Has it given us a maritime sector that is industrially reliable? The answer to that is no, we still do not have a shipping industry in Australia that is internationally competitive and we still do not have a maritime industry in Australia that is industrially reliable. All that money was spent because it was claimed we would achieve these goals.

Honourable members will recall that, as part of the PAYE tax arrangements for seafarers, a deal was struck in September 1994 as a consequence of a strike over the sale of ANL. The former government struck a deal saying that it would pay the PAYE tax for seafarers on the basis that it got a number of reforms from that industry which would be equal in value to the amount of money—some $19 million to $20 million—that it was to allocate to the PAYE scheme each year. The maritime union said, `We'll do that. We'll provide you with those sorts of benefits.' What happened? We did not get any of those benefits from the Maritime Union.

Part of the deal was that the crew‐to‐berth ratio was supposed to come down. What happened? The crew‐to‐berth ratio went up. The crew‐to‐berth ratio in Australia is two to 13. What is the international average? It is one to seven. Again, what is happening in Australia, where enormous amounts of money were paid out by the previous government allegedly to make Australia internationally competitive? We have gone the other way.

I think many people in this country would quite legitimately raise the question: why did the former government pay out all this money to this sector? The answer to that is because they were dominated, influenced and, in many cases, controlled by unions like the Maritime Union of Australia. We only have to hear the sorts of speeches that were given by Jennie George and Bill Kelty last Friday in Sydney to realise just how much influence the Maritime Union of Australia has over the labour movement and the Labor government of old. That is how they got their billion dollars over that period, and that is why they were able to get it without giving Australia an efficient maritime industry. So all that money has gone down the drain for no particular gain.

I turn to the claims by the opposition that the early termination of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act is retrospective legislation. That is simply nonsense. The three shipowners would not have accrued any entitlement until the ships were delivered and registered in Australia. In other words, they would not have been eligible for that subsidy or that grant until the ships were registered here in Australia.

Those opposite may talk about retrospective legislation, but when we were in opposition we made it quite clear to the industry on many occasions over a long period—I recall making a speech back in 1989, when I first became the shadow minister for land transport and shipping, in parliament indicating this—that the opposition, as the coalition was in those days, was opposed to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act. Indeed, we had in our policy in 1990 the fact that we would end the Ships (Capital Grants) Act. We also said in our 1993 policy that we would end it. We said in our 1996 policy for the election just a few months ago that we would end it. We took particular pain to inform the industry that this was our policy position.

When we were in opposition, my senior staff member flew to Melbourne to brief the director of the Australian Shipowners Association, Mr Lachlan Payne, about what our policies were for the forthcoming election. He did that last year, and he made it quite clear what they were. Indeed, in many speeches that I gave over the years at shipping conferences, I reiterated our commitment in this regard.

Nobody in the Australian shipping industry can rightfully complain that this was a bolt out of the blue—it was never a bolt out of the blue. It was clearly laid out in our 1990 policy, the 1993 policy and the 1996 policy. It was also laid out in many speeches here in the parliament, at industry conferences around the countryside, and on occasions to specially brief executive members of the Australian Shipowners Association and, indeed, senior members of the industry. So nobody can claim that this was a bolt out of the blue.

The shipowners made their investment in the knowledge of the coalition's strong opposition to the grants being extended beyond 1989. In discussions with the Australian Shipowners Association they were well and truly informed of our position. All industries face the prospect of regulatory changes from time to time, just as they must face changes in the commercial environment. Prudent businesses—and I am sure the three companies that are involved in this issue are prudent businesses—will always factor in contingencies when looking at new investments, especially long‐term investments like ships with an operating life of at least 16 years, and up to 25 years in the case of Shell's oil tanker.

PARA.BREAK: The shipowners will still benefit from the accelerated depreciation provision. This benefit is worth more than twice as much as the taxable grant to a tax paying company. The benefit writes down a ship for tax pur poses over five years, commencing in the pre‐commissioning year. Effectively, that is a four‐year depreciation for a ship with a life of from 16 to 25 years, and that is worth considerably more than the grants were worth. Indeed, that continues for those three ships that are of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the ships capital grant and the Crawford scheme before it had served their purpose by 1992, when the grants scheme was originally scheduled to terminate. It was to serve as a catalyst to reduce crews from the mid‐30s to the late‐20s, and then the momentum of change would lead to further efficiencies and productivity improvements.

The coalition supported this timetable originally. The coalition supported the development of a strong Australian shipping industry. This government no less supports a strong Australian shipping industry now. All the money poured into the industry by successive Labor governments has not produced a strong industry. It is only three per cent bigger in carrying capacity now than when Labor came to office in 1983 and, indeed, we actually have a lesser number of vessels registered in Australia. In 1983 we had 82 Australian flag registered vessels; today we have 68. Despite all this—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the flood of Russian and Chinese competition.

—The world is real life; competition is real life. Despite all the money that has been injected into this industry, we now have considerably fewer vessels operating under Australian registration than we had in 1983. That is what 13 years of your government has done.

SPEECH.PARA: As noted in the shipowners' own report, the trend in OECD countries has been to wind back direct subsides and move to second registers. These countries have realised the futility of pouring in taxpayers' money, trying to sustain national flag fleets. Second registers create the operating environment through which advanced economy countries can compete with flags of convenience.

The member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) noted how Norway controls a major share of world shipping despite its small population, which is true. Did it do this by pouring more and more taxpayers' money into the industry? Of course not. It sowed the seeds and pushed the productivity reforms with the cooperation of the maritime unions and created its second register. Norwegian shipping flourishes because it has moved with the times, not because its government has poured unlimited funds into its national flag fleet. In Australia, by contrast, the pace of shipping reform has been abysmal as the unions have dragged their heels at each and every stage while the taxpayers dig deeper and deeper into their pockets.

I note that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) could not resist picking up the industry furphy about the defence support role. It is a pity he did not check on the facts. No Australian merchant ship is specially fitted out for a defence support capability. Some years ago a stern refuelling trial was carried out, but the project was abandoned.

Having presided over a ships capital grants scheme that had outlived its usefulness, Labor then saw fit to throw good money after bad with its international ships grants scheme. Labor took on board this scheme in a panic to pacify the Maritime Union of Australia and to settle the September 1994 national shipping strike. No thought was given to getting a proper productivity trade‐off. Instead, the unions were simply told to work up some sort of industrial package with employers.

That package—the maritime industry restructuring agreement—has been a failure. It has not delivered either the efficiencies or the cost savings promised by the unions. Where are the promised crew‐to‐berth ratio reductions? Where is the cooperation to reduce shipboard injuries and to cut compensation rorts? Where is the promised industrial peace accord? That lies buried at Weipa. Can you imagine any greater act of irresponsibility and sheer bastardry than the Maritime Union bashing the shipping industry over a dispute by other workers with CRA? This union, which pleads for the industry to be supported, is happy enough to give it a king hit as and when it pleases.

BREAK.PARA: Now the unions, employers and opposition are wringing their hands and claiming the industry will be decimated if the international shipping grant is withdrawn. That is complete rubbish. This grant has been a windfall gain, mainly to highly profitable companies like BHP and international oil companies whose ships were already in international trade.

The Australian shipping industry can become competitive. It can develop to carry a significant portion of Australian trade and it can make a significant contribution to our balance of payments. But this will only happen when the industry wakes up to itself and models itself on successful maritime nations like Norway and other second registered countries which have moved with the times, got rid of restrictive work practices and improved productivity.

This government will sit down with the unions and the shipowners to develop the conditions for a strong, viable shipping industry—not conditions which hinge on endless amounts of taxpayers' money, but conditions which give Australians the opportunity to compete on a level playing field with second register countries.

In concluding my remarks today on this debate, I think it is very worth while for members to note the fact that, through the 13 years of Labor's administration of this country, Australians heard a great deal of talk about reform of the maritime industry, be it on the waterfront or in the shipping industries. Indeed, whilst there was a lot of talk, there was very little action. To this day we are still not within a bull's roar of having an internationally competitive waterfront. Your crew‐to‐berth ratios are way out of line.

The costs, according to the BTCE, of operating an Australian registered vessel under the conditions that apply here in Australia are $2 million extra than it ought to be and what would be the cost in comparable ships in other parts of the world—

TALK.START.PARA: —With slave labour.

—And not with slave labour. This is one of the great furphies of the people on the Labor side of the House. You can make comparisons with other countries of like‐minded people that are very unfavourable when compared with the Australian maritime industry.

BREAK.PARA: It is a disgrace for Australia after so many years of a Labor government that talked up reform, that outlaid nearly $1 billion, to still find that Australia's ships cost $2 million a year more to run than ships in other countries such as OECD countries. We have not experienced the sorts of reforms that those countries have experienced, countries with like‐minded people, countries in many cases with strong unions, countries in many cases, though, with strong unions that are progressive and that are prepared to make changes in the interests of their industry and in the interests of the long-term jobs of those people who work within them.

We believe this bill deserves to be supported. I urge all members of the House to support this bill because in the end it will help to drive sensible reform that will lead Australia to have a competitive shipping industry and that will give long-term future jobs to those people in the industries. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Sharp) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION AND TRAINING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Dr Kemp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The most substantial part of the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill concerns the repeal of the training guarantee levy, which the opposition does not oppose. There are two other key aspects to the bill. The first seeks to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to correct a minor anomaly to enable expenditure of funds already allocated for open learning. I am pleased to say that the opposition also does not oppose that. The second aspect, which the opposition also does not oppose, goes to an amendment to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to fulfil the previous government's commitment to spend an extra $20 million on the non‐government schools capital program.

SPEECH.PARA: Having dealt with the outline of the bill, I think that I should also make the point on behalf of the opposition that the bill is in line with the direction in which the former Labor government was moving. In fact, the proposal with respect to the repeal of the training guarantee levy was integral to the Working Nation statement of 1994. In that context, I refer to the fact that we proposed to suspend the training guarantee scheme for a two‐year period from July 1994, having introduced the bill in 1990.

PARA.BREAK: As members of the House will recall, the training guarantee scheme was created in 1990 for one major purpose. That purpose was to try to help change the training culture within business. The objective was clearly to require a minimum level of training expendi ture, rising to 1.5 per cent of the payroll for companies with a turnover of more than $220,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The government of the day then thought that it was an appropriate response to the pressing problem that confronted the nation at the time. I refer specifically to the historical position all too often in Australia—that when businesses were left to their own devices they failed to invest adequately in the training of their work force. I would also say in passing, as has been borne out by the recent Karpin report, that not only did businesses fail to invest in the nature of work that is traditionally represented by the union movement in Australia, but they also historically failed to invest in management.

I would hope that the current government moves to implement some of the major recommendations of the Karpin report with respect to the need of business in Australia to invest to a greater degree in training management.

One of the key areas that needs attention, for example, is developing an export culture. In respect of the issue of trying to increase our performance on the trade front, there has been a large degree of agreement between the government of the day and the opposition of the day. I believe it is about time managers also faced up to the fact that they need to invest in their own training and pay adequate attention to ensuring that the management that we train in the future is properly aware of the need to have an export culture and to actually chase export opportunities for the future development of this nation.

I believe that the training guarantee legislation of 1990 was an appropriate response by the government of the day. There was a pressing problem at the time and very deliberate action was required by the government of the day to force this nation to invest in its greatest resource, its work force, and to ensure that they had adequate skills for the purposes of making Australia competitive and taking the nation forward, both within the nation's boundaries and at an international level in the light of the increasing globalisation of the economy.

BREAK.PARA: I would remind the House this evening that the coalition then consistently opposed the government's initiative. They suggested that the government's initiative in introducing the training guarantee legislation was an interference in business operations and that it was, in essence, yet another example of bureaucratic red tape. I believe that from time to time there is a very direct requirement for government to prod business to ensure that they face up to their responsibilities. As a former trade union official, I am well aware of the fact that all too often businesses in this country have failed to adequately invest in the training of their work force. In essence, whilst there are many good employers in Australia, there is a minority of employers who deliberately refuse to invest in the training of their work force and, if anything, act as parasites on other employers in the Australian community. They are not just my words; those words were also echoed by a number of business representatives at the time the training guarantee legislation was introduced in 1990.

Not only have they been parasites by their failure to invest in the training of their work force; quite often it was as a result of their failure to invest in the training of their work force that skill shortages emerged which also led from time to time to outbreaks on the wages front. I refer to the fact that, as a result of their failure to invest in the skilling of the Australian work force, rather than taking on apprentices and trainees they simply went into the market and competed against fellow employers to attract labour, and that in turn very much resulted in a wages outbreak. The real position was that other employers were therefore forced to compete in attracting and retaining labour. But once it occurs with respect to a specific area of employment, be it a particular trade in a given enterprise or a range of trades or semi‐skilled workers in a given enterprise, it normally results in the wages outbreak across the whole economy.

I would argue that the endeavours by the previous government under the training guarantee legislation of 1990 were not merely about the skilling of the Australian work force and making the Australian economy more competitive but also about ensuring that we faced up to some of the economic necessities on the all‐important issue of wages. On that front, I note in passing that the current government is not interested in wages policy. I also believe that they are not properly interested in placing pressure on the nation at large to ensure that there is an adequate investment in the training of the Australian work force.

I simply mark the opposition's position with respect to these issues this evening, as I am exceptionally worried about the fact that the current government does not have an adequate wages policy. The fact is that they are not prepared to sit down and work with the trade union movement, which has clearly proven over the last 13 years that it has a capacity to work with business, deliver improvements in productivity and changes in work practices and, at the same time, dramatically reduce the level of industrial disputation in Australia.

I might say something in passing on the level of industrial disputation—and I know these figures worry the government of the day, especially the former Treasurer in the Fraser‐Anthony government, now the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). When he was the Treasurer of this great nation, the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees due to industrial disputes was 591 compared with 194 days under the Hawke Labor government. In essence, as a result of having in place a reasonable approach to the important issue of training and a proper focus on best practice, improvements in productivity and changes in work practices, we achieved a dramatic reduction in the level of industrial disputation in Australia of the order of 60 per cent. I wonder whether, in a couple of years time, the government will be able to refer to a similar achievement in the level of industrial disputation as was achieved by the Accord period of operation.

In relation to the training guarantee legislation, I want to make the point that not only did the then opposition seek to misrepresent the true objectives of that legislation throughout the Australian community and especially the business community, but, more importantly, they were bereft of ideas. On no occasion when the bill was debated in the House, or when it was eventually passed by the House, did the then opposition advance any ideas as to how to address the run‐down of Australia's skill base in an unregulated market.

If anything, it was a little bit like the lead‐up to the election of 2 March. Again, the then opposition was bereft of ideas. Unlike under their previous coalition leader, Mr Hewson, in the lead‐up to the 1993 election, they were afraid to advance a comprehensive package of policy ideas and suggestions as to how they would take Australia forward. Instead, they ran away from a policy debate, as they ran away from a policy debate in 1990 on the training guarantee legislation. And, having been elected, they have merely taken out of their hip pocket their Fightback policies aimed at cutting to the bone the endeavours by Australia as a nation to ensure that all in the community are treated with some respect and dignity and that we go out of our way to make sure that, as a nation, we look after the more disadvantaged in the community.

I refer to the fact that, in announcing the decision in 1994 to suspend the levy in Working Nation, the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Crean, noted the increased commitment by industry in meeting its training obligations since the levy had first come in. In that context, I believe that the legislation was successful. It was on that basis that we, as a government, then gave a commitment to abolish the levy altogether if business would make a credible commitment to create an adequate number of new training places. That is what it was about.

The original legislation of 1990 was about prodding industry to ensure that they invested in the training of the Australian work force, invested in creating skill opportunities and career opportunities for both men and women in industry at large. On that basis, the introduction of the expanded entry level training and the new training wage was pursued by the government as part of a Working Nation package that provided an appropriate context for the suspension of the levy. Then in the lead‐up to the recent election, in accord with our statements of 1994 when we introduced the Working Nation statement, we gave an outright commitment to abolish the levy.

We nevertheless express concern this evening that the associated steps that we put forward in announcing the Working Nation statement of 1994 will be set back somewhat as a result of the change of government on 2 March.I refer specifically to the advances made in employment and training in Australia over the last decade and more. The reason the levy can now be removed is its success—the success of the Labor Party in government in generating increased expenditure by employers on training. The levy itself has been part of the broader success of the Working Nation strategy in bringing unemployment, and particularly long‐term unemployment, down. It has also been part of a wider revolution in training which the former Labor government brought about.

When we were in government we changed the outdated apprenticeship system, moving it towards a competency based system of training rather than purely time based, and making it more flexible to meet the needs of employers. One of our major achievements was the expansion in Australia, for the benefit of people of all ages who wanted to pursue it, of properly constituted competency based training opportunities, not only through individual training with a particular employer but, more importantly, through a group training company. It is interesting to note that one of the big successes on that front was with the ACTU and the Lend Lease company.

Throughout the length and breadth of Australia in a range of industries—importantly in the new industries—there are new opportunities for employment. For example, the service sector, the retail industry and the hospitality industry are creating thousands of opportunities for people in Australia. Access to competency based training will, in turn, guarantee them a lifetime opportunity to pursue a career in a range of new industries in the services sector of Australian industry.

We sought to ensure not only that training existed in the old blue‐collar trades oriented industries, but also that it was open and made available to as many workers as possible in the new growth industries in the services sector.We moved towards national frameworks for training and skills recognition. We did not want separate systems from state to state or from employer to employer. We wanted to make sure that employees who pursued a training course had an opportunity to move from employer to employer, from state to state and from territory to territory and have their skills properly recognised and accredited.

On the issue of apprenticeships it is interesting to note that we lifted apprenticeship commencements from their low point of around 34,000 under John Howard as Treasurer prior to 1983 to nearly double that level by the late 1980s. I know it upsets the opposition to hear from time to time about that particular achievement because they deliberately seek in this House to misrepresent the figures on apprenticeship enrolments now compared with the past when they had responsibility for training issues in Australia.

They fail to understand that the old system has fundamentally changed in character from when they were last in government. They ignore our achievement in bringing about this historic change and they wilfully ignore the huge increase in the number of young people staying on at secondary school over the 12 years of Labor government. I am quite proud of those achievements. When John Howard was last in government the then government failed to face up to the fact that we should properly invest in the education and training of Australians and especially our young.

In the early 1980s when John Howard was Treasurer our school retention rates to year 12 were abysmal; in fact, just over 35 per cent of the students stayed on to year 12. Today the figure is well over 70 per cent for students staying to year 12. We should be trying to improve on that figure, if not setting a target. Unfortunately, the current government is somewhat ashamed of setting targets because they do not like benchmarks as to how the community at large can measure their performance. Not only are they not prepared to set a target with respect to school retention rates but, more importantly, they are not prepared to set a target with respect to job creation.

On the question of job creation, I might say in passing that I think the performance of the Labor government was second to none. Three years ago we set a target of 300,000 jobs. At the end of the three‐year period 730,000 jobs were achieved. Why is the current government so afraid of setting a target? I and many others know the real answer to that question. It is because they are not vitally concerned with the issue of employment. If they were vitally concerned with the issue of employment they would not be sacking many thousands of public servants at this particular point in time. Unfortunately, the dismissal of those public servants will not affect just the nation's capital of Canberra. More importantly, it will have a major impact on metropolitan Australia and regional Australia.

Every loss of a government job in those regional centres will have a multiplier effect in the Australia community. The closure of a taxation office in one of the regional centres or the amalgamation of a CES office with a Department of Social Security office will have a consequent loss of jobs. There is no concern by the government of the day for those people and their families or for the impact on local communities. I suggest that their failure to set an employment target is really related to the fact that, under it all, they are really not concerned about the level of unemployment in Australia; they are merely concerned with looking after their mates at the top end of town.

I might also say that under Labor more funds were injected into vocational training and its status was boosted. We negotiated, for example, a new training wage. In Working Nation we also established the youth training initiative to provide 50,000 opportunities every year for 15‐ to 17‐year‐olds to find a job, training or education.

PARA.BREAK: The former government also promoted international best practice. It is strange when we hear the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) talk about workplace reform. I still have not heard him refer to the issue of best practice. Best practice is also related to training, changes in work practices and a change in culture at a workplace level, but unfortunately the Minister for Industrial Relations thinks that improving Australia's competitive position is merely related to passing a new act in respect of the manage ment of industrial relations in this country. It is not about a new act; it is about people sitting down and talking and facing up to their own responsibilities and working it out, as has occurred over the last 13 years and as is evidenced in the fact that the level of industrial disputation was reduced over that period by something of the order of 60 per cent. It is about the quality and quantity of training, a concern, I might suggest, which is now tending to disappear from the debate in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: With respect to Enterprising Nation, or the Karpin report, as it is best known, we also addressed the need to improve manager skills and not just focus on those of workers. That is about a holistic approach to workplace reform, ensuring that all aspects of a particular workplace are involved in the process of change and making individual companies, individual industries and individual states, regions and the nation at large more competitive—not just focusing on the training and the level of skills of people at the shop floor but also ensuring, through the recommendations of the Karpin report, that we pursue a holistic approach to training and workplace change in Australia.

I refer to surveys undertaken since the introduction of the training guarantee scheme. They have shown that employers' training expenditure has jumped dramatically. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, total expenditure on formal training by Australia employers rose by 18 per cent in the three years following the scheme's introduction, and particularly amongst small to medium size employers. Before the training guarantee, nearly 60 per cent of employers with payrolls over $200,000 unfortunately provided no structured training at all. Since the training guarantee, more than 90 per cent of employers over that limit provide structured training equal to at least 1.5 per cent of their payrolls—again according to data from the Australian Taxation Office. Yet unfortunately one of the first acts of the new government has been to undo much of the good work. They have ceased approval of any new labour market program commitments.

If members of the government have got any question in their minds about that, when they return to their electorates they ought to contact the local CES office and the Skillshare office and talk to some of the community organisations that have been involved in the area consultative committees who sought to go out of their way, for example, to create opportunities for the long‐term unemployed. Yes, they might shake their shoulders and suggest that it is not an important issue, but I think it is an all‐important issue that we continue to properly fund those initiatives which were aimed at ensuring that we did not create a long‐term pool of forgotten workers in Australia but that we created opportunities to ensure that all those long‐term unemployed were given opportunities to undertake training and to again get job ready so that they would be in a position to be taken up by employers and to obtain meaningful and long‐term employment opportunities again.

The government have frozen the intake of unemployed people into the jobtrain program. They have abolished NETTFORCE, despite the fact that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, herself said in the Senate that she was pleased with the performance of NETTFORCE. Employers, in association with unions and government representatives, have been going out of their way across all regions of Australia to break down the barriers and to ensure that traineeships were taken up as a primary opportunity to ensure that people get training and employment opportunities around Australia.

PARA.BREAK: The government have stopped the processing of new applications under the special intervention program. They are jeopardising the work of front‐line agencies such as the Salvation Army and its crossroads job scheme for the disadvantaged and homeless. They are holding up—and it is interesting that I refer to this, as Aboriginal Reconciliation Week is next week—the funding for the community development projects, or CDEP, the major employment program for indigenous Australians, and that will have a devastating effect on employment and welfare in Australia's Aboriginal communities. They refuse to give proper long‐term guarantees for the highly successful work of skillshares. They are leaving hundreds of contract case manage ment trainees in the hospitality industry in the lurch.

BREAK.PARA: These cuts which the government is making to the Working Nation labour market programs will have a very damaging effect on unemployment levels in Australia. I also suggest that they are a blatant breach of commitments given by the Prime Minister and members of the government during the course of the recent election campaign. The coalition said during the election campaign that it strongly supports the increased efforts to provide active assistance for long‐term unemployed people in recent years. John Howard, in his Damascus‐like conversion to Labor policies at the ACOSS conference last year, gave a series of ironclad guarantees: for example, the coalition would not place a time limit on the receipt of unemployment benefits, would not reduce the wages of young people and would maintain the real value of unemployment benefits. I believe that many of those statements will be proven to be false.

Because the Prime Minister likes to raise from time to time the issue of employment, I refer to his own performance on the employment front when last he was Treasurer. I recall that, by the time John Howard left office as Treasurer in 1983, the unemployment rate in Australia had rocketed to over 10 per cent. That figure, as we all know, is far higher than that which he inherited under Labor at the recent election. What did 10 per cent mean to John Howard at that time? He likes to refer to figures from time to time on the level of unemployment. When John Howard ceased to be Treasurer in March 1983, he had more than 700,000 dead men and women dangling from his shoulders—700,000 dead men and women dangling from his shoulders in a work force only three‐quarters the size of today's work force. John Howard is condemned by his own performance on the employment front. There were 700,000 unemployed when he was the Treasurer of Australia.

He also likes to raise from time to time the question of youth unemployment. What was the figure on the youth unemployment front when John Howard was last Treasurer? In 1983 John Howard had more than 164,000 teenagers looking for but unable to find full‐ time work, which is nearly twice as many as today. He seeks to suggest that youth unemployment is an issue that the Australian Labor Party refused to pay proper attention to in government. John Howard is again condemned by his own performance as Treasurer, not just on the employment front in general but especially on the youth unemployment front. Those 164,000 teenagers in 1983 looking for but unable to find full‐time work were nearly twice as many as today.

So much for the promise in the election campaign that coalition policies will move Australia back towards full employment. I believe that, if we pursue the types of initiatives put in place by the previous government on the Working Nation front—many of those initiatives having arisen from the prod given to Australian industry by the training guarantee legislation to urge and encourage employers to invest in the training of their work force—we have a capacity in Australia to further improve our performance at a local enterprise, industry and national level.

Although we do not oppose the repeal of the legislation, it in fact was a part of the partnership we put together for Working Nation—a commitment to invest in training and to create decent and targeted labour market programs. I wonder whether the coalition is going to rip away the legislation this evening and at the same time walk away from the commitment, the package, the understanding with the Australian community. I wonder whether the coalition will deliver on the requirement to actually invest, through proper labour market targeting, in the creation of training and employment opportunities for those people.

I understand that the current minister seeks to ridicule some of those programs and to suggest that they are not properly targeted. All I can say is that the minister ought to go out and meet some of those people, go into the community, look at the performance of some of those people, talk to them about how proud they are to have the opportunity to participate in some of the programs, examine their work and see the impact it has on their families and the community at large. That is what labour market programs and training are about. If the minister wants to refer to a particular example, I will give one.

I recently met someone in northern Melbourne who had been unemployed for 14 years. That person is now a new person because of the opportunities created. He is at Northland High School and I am prepared to take Mr Abbott to that college to talk to that person in order to see the impact of some of these programs and the pride that person now has in his work. He is job ready and will have the capacity in the near future to actually take up a full‐time or part‐time employment opportunity with an employer in industry.
As I said at the outset, the opposition will not oppose the bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, which is a bill for an act to repeal the Training Guarantee Act 1990, the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 and to amend certain other acts and for related purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Listening to the shadow minister just now, one would think that the Labor Party had just won an historic sixth term and that the shadow minister was in fact a minister of the Crown sitting on this side of the House telling the opposition what terrible ideas they had and what a wonderful job the government had done over the last 13 years and will continue to do over the next goodness only knows how many.

Let me give you the message, mate: you lost! And do you know why you lost? Because the people rejected you. Do you know why they rejected you? Because you failed. And there is no better example than this act that we are repealing tonight of why Labor went wrong, yet you have the audacity to tell people like me to go out and meet real people out in the streets. You tell us to go out and talk to skillshares, to area consultative committees, to regional development organisations, to DEET and to CES employees. You have the audacity to tell me to go out and talk to all of those people. You, an ex‐ACTU president who probably has never been to one of those things, come in here and tell us how to run the world—yes, from the viewpoint of an ex‐ACTU executive.

BREAK.PARA: The Training Guarantee Act 1990 was brought in to improve Australia's training effort. That was the intent of the act. At the time, I was less than happy with the mechanisms the government was using in order to encourage and promote the objects of increased vocational education and training in Australia but I agreed with the overall objectives. The then opposition never opposed the objectives because we well recognised—not only then but earlier as well—the desperate need that Australia had to increase its rate of skill acquisition if we were going to be able to compete in the international marketplace, to improve productivity and take our place in the world as a major producer of goods and services, quality education exports and all the other good things that we do.

There were really three sorts of objects within that overall effort that the act was meant to address. One was to improve the quality of training. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know of no‐one from any side of politics or from any side of the bureaucracy or in any position within the training industry or the training market who would be willing to tell you that the Training Guarantee Act improved the quality of training. In fact, there is some evidence to suggest that perhaps the quality of training in some aspects actually decreased as a result of the taxation act itself. Because that is what it was, Mr Deputy Speaker; it was a taxation act.

The second object was to improve the quantity of training; the quantum of the training effort in Australia. I suppose that that was really the major reason why the act was brought down. There is no question whatsoever that Australia was then, and still is today, in desperate need of a real substantive lift in vocational training, in skills training, and in skills acquisition in the work force and for those who would enter the work force in order to improve our productivity and our performance. It is absolutely required.

The jury never really came in on quantity. No‐one was ever able to prove that this act actually lifted the quantum of certified training. Certainly, we could say that one of the effects of the act, because it was a taxation act, was to cause companies to reorder their accounting systems to take account of pens and pencils and biros and paperclips and all the other things that went into the training, whereas before they had been part of general management overheads; but they had to segregate them out, so that effort did in fact produce some quantum information about the expenditure that went into structured training. But prior to that time there was one heck of a lot of unstructured training that always went on in Australia's businesses, and particularly in Australia's small and medium sized businesses. (Quorum formed).

I was talking about the quantum of vocational education and training not having been sufficiently addressed by the Training Guarantee Act. Mr Deputy Speaker, when John Dawkins brought in this act, it was the stick versus the carrot approach. Let me tell you that I think that this bill was as great an example of how not to go about encouraging people to do things as anybody has ever seen in this country. It was a punitive measure.

It was a taxation measure. It was a taxation bill. It required people to keep records for taxation purposes, rather than addressing the training needs of Australia by doing something in a structural sense to really encourage particularly small business to do more training, to hire more apprentices, to hire more trainees and to participate with the group training companies, which I note the shadow Minister who spoke before me reckons are great institutions, and I absolutely agree. You would not find a greater proponent for group training companies in Australia in this House than the honourable member for Latrobe, and that is a fact. I have supported them since early l990 in the strongest possible and tangible way, and I will continue to do so because they are a great mechanism and they work well. I agree with the shadow Minister that the ACTU Lend Lease Foundation has done a superb job—an absolutely magnificent job—no question about that.

What this act finally wound down to being was excessive regulation. This is an area where what is needed is encouragement. It does not really do much good to tell companies, `You must do this, do that, or do something else' and then ask them to use their resources in the best way they can to be as productive as they can, to be as profitable as they can, to improve their balance sheet the best way they can, to add to Australia's wealth and to employ as many Australians as possible. Every time we whack on another regulation, what do we do? We discourage more employment.

So, if you will, this was an unemployment act, and that in fact is probably one of the effects that it had. In l994 even Labor had given up on the act. It had been amended—I have forgotten now—two, three or four times. One of the amendments was to allow those companies which spent at least five per cent of their wages bill on structured training to opt out of the system. They did not have to report, but they still had to keep the records in order to prove the five per cent, and that was an onerous requirement.

It did not really let many companies opt out I can tell you. The act required that at $200,000 worth of wages one had to spend one per cent of the wages bill on structured training. I have forgotten exactly how much it was, but that ramped up to about 1.5 per cent of wages expenditure—a quarter of a million dollars—having to be spent on structured training. It was not the quantum of the amount of money that needed to be spent on training, it was in fact the onerous requirements to keep records.

This bill was really expected to raise lots of money. The early estimates were that it would raise between $10 million and $50 million a year, and some estimates put the revenue likely to be raised as high as $800 million. In l990‐91 it raised $3.2 million; in l991‐92 it raised $1.5 million; in l993‐94 it raised $2.3 million. The cost to the Treasury of administering the act and the program was greater than the revenue received. There is a good reason for that too, because if you actually paid the tax—the levy—then you got taxed on it as well because it was not tax deductible. So it cost you not only the amount of the levy but 39 per cent of the amount of the levy as well in income tax. That was a terrible disincentive to paying the levy, I can tell you.

So what happened? What happened was that TAFEs, private providers and new growth companies that got into the market to provide so‐called structured training, offered all sorts of packages to divest employers of their hard earned money, calling it training in order that they could prove that they had incurred the expenditure so that they did not have to pay the tax and saved 39 per cent.

It was a tax. The Labor Party loves taxes—absolutely loves taxes—and they will, I am certain, in the term of this parliament, propose taxes. They will be happy to propose taxes. They certainly will oppose our spending cuts in order to fill up Beazley's black hole, and they will instead want to raise taxes—all kinds of new taxes, because Labor loves taxes. That is in fact what the training guarantee levy was—it was a tax.

Another point needs to be made about that tax, and that is the fact that they brought in the tax at the beginning of the greatest recession since World War II, the recession that we had to have. There were companies out there struggling, going bankrupt, falling over one by one. What did we do? We put another onerous requirement on companies to spend and to keep records at a time when they were under extreme stress, when unemployment was ratcheting up, when corporate profits were going through the floor. At this time the Labor Party brought in another regulatory requirement.

Labor loves regulations. In the life of this parliament we are going to rid the statutes of one heck of a lot of regulation. We will free the market up so that small businesses in particular will not be required to keep all the records they have in the past. Small business will get a better break and get a chance to produce and be profitable and to hire some more people so that we do not have this continuing high unemployment.

You can come up with all the mickey mouse schemes in the world that you like. You can say, `Ah, this is the best one we ever devised, and that one was the greatest one that anybody ever had' but, fair dinkum, they are all just programs, are they not? They do not address the structural problem. The problem is that if there are not jobs then not everybody is employed. What we need is people who employ people.

You are going to hear a lot about that over the next couple of weeks when my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) introduces the new industrial relations bill. This is something that we have talked about in this place for so many years that it is not even funny. Finally it is coming to pass, and won't it be a great day? We will relieve industry of some of the onerous requirement of regulation. Labor loves regulation, but we do not like regulation so much over on this side of the House.

The records that the ATO required to be kept were very onerous for some out there in the real job land—for instance, for major retailers. This is direct evidence, shadow minister; you ought to listen to this. There is direct evidence about some of the big companies, such as Myers. They had to spend a great deal of money in dissecting the actual cost of training, because they were training people at this store, and in that department, and in another store and a different department, and all over the place. They had to try to put the training cost in a little basket all by itself, which was very costly. It cost so much that they reduced the amount of training that they were doing. They reduced the number of hours of real structured training in order to comply with the act. That is dumb.

Another reason why the act failed is that some companies spent so much on administration that they found they had to reduce training altogether. And there were other companies who, when they finally did the records, found they were spending five or six per cent of their wages bill on training. At the time of this great recession they decided to cut back on training expenditure because they were not spending what the bill required them to. The act said 1.5 per cent, but they were spending five per cent. They decided they might as well cut down on what they were spending. It makes sense, does it not? We did not exactly enhance the quantum of training through that mechanism.

TAFE and private providers touted for gifts so that companies did not have to pay the income tax proportion. They did. Do you know that TAFEs, which we are supporting—taxpayer dollars, federal dollars, are going to support the TAFEs—were placing ads in newspapers begging companies to send them gifts of money to satisfy their training requirements because that gift counted as if they had been doing training for themselves? (Quorum formed)

In the few seconds that I have left, unless someone proposes an extension, I just want to say that this bill was a failed measure by a failed Labor Party in order to accomplish something that really had decent and good objectives: they were to increase the amount of vocational education and training in Australia, to increase skill acquisition by people who really need it, to assist in the production process and to assist Australia to become a wealthier country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of legislation is pretty non‐contentious in terms of the substantive measures that it contains. I do not think that there is anything here that we are opposing. In fact, we are supporting all the specific measures in the legislation, including the repeal of the training guarantee and associated legislation and a couple of minor amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act and the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to spend most of my time talking about the higher education and schools implications of some of this legislation, but I would like to make a few brief comments about the repeal of the training guarantee. As the previous opposition speaker, the member for Batman (Mr Ferguson), no doubt pointed out, we believe that while it was in operation the training guarantee performed a very useful purpose in catalysing the significant change in the whole training culture in this country. It is demonstrable that there has been a substantially increased training effort since the introduction of the training guarantee. In particular, a very high proportion of many medium sized businesses that previously might not have had any training activity of any significance at all have in fact engaged in significant training activity sufficient to meet the requirements of the guarantee. So I think it is fair to say that there has been a significant improvement as a consequence of its introduction.

BREAK.PARA: In view of that significant culture change that has taken place and other associated developments—such as, in the context of Working Nation and other initiatives, significantly expanded entry level training opportunities, the introduction of the training wage and so forth—it was our view that it was appropriate in the first instance to suspend the measure for two years; and before the election, we gave an undertaking to abolish it.

While I think we agree with the appropriateness of taking that measure at this time, we do not resile from our belief that the training guarantee was an important measure to catalyse and bring about a substantial change in industry's attitude towards training. At the time it was an appropriate and effective measure.

I would like to make a couple of more general comments about the coalition's approach to training and labour market program assistance to the unemployed. For several years I was a minister in the employment, education and training portfolio with specific responsibility for delivery of labour market programs. I am concerned that the coalition, both before the election and since, has tended to deprecate the significance of labour market programs, particularly those sorts of programs which might be of shorter term duration and which might not fall within the mainstream training and education assistance. There has been a tendency to say that these are basically ineffective mickey mouse measures that really confer no real benefits.

I do not believe that that is the case at all. I think the evidence is very clear when you are talking about people who are particularly disadvantaged in the labour market. I refer to people with a long duration of unemployment, people with multiple sources of disadvantage—they might have problems with literacy or English language, they might have particular disabilities, or there might be a range of factors that make it very hard for them to succeed in the labour market without special measures to assist them. There is no doubt that to substantially cut or curtail access to labour market programs will be very detrimental for those people.

The evidence that I recall when I was minister was that, while participation in a labour market program may not guarantee that a severely disadvantaged person seeking a job will get a permanent job, there is no doubt that their chances of getting some sort of reasonable opportunity, and particularly a full‐time unsubsidised work opportunity, are greatly magnified through participation in these programs.

There has been some talk about the so‐called displacement effect that programs of this type might have. You cannot simply focus on the numbers getting jobs who participated. You have to take into account that they might be displacing some others who might otherwise have taken the same jobs. Obviously, there is a lot of truth in that displacement effect. But part of the approach of Working Nation, part of what we tried to achieve as a government, is to ensure that you do not get a large pool of people, hundreds of thousands of people, more or less permanently alienated from the labour market so that you have a situation where unemployment and all the personal characteristics and so forth that are associated with unemployment are passed from generation to generation.

I do not think there is a more significant social priority for us in this country than to avoid the entrenchment of that kind of stagnant pool of people who just are more or less permanently excluded from the labour market. Labour market programs, which, as I said, the coalition have tended to devalue, have a critical role in avoiding exactly that scenario. They do make some contribution to net employment creation, I believe. I think the evidence is there on that. There is a substantial displacement effect, but even that displacement effect is worthwhile if it avoids, as I said, this consequence of large numbers of people permanently unemployed—a permanent underclass of unemployable people. That is what we have to avoid in this country, and that is what these programs are very much oriented to doing.

PARA.BREAK: If you go back to the mid‐1980s and look at our performance in that area in comparison with other countries, particularly European countries, you will see that we were a rela tively poor performer in terms of the proportion of total program expenditure that was devoted to what you might term `active' as distinct from `passive' income support measures. Since then there has been a significant change in the balance, and I think the change has been very much to the good.

BREAK.PARA: We read speculation that the coalition are going to make major cuts in these programs; they probably think that there is not too much of a political price to be paid for that. Maybe they are right. Maybe there is not too much of a political price to be paid for it, but there is a very substantial and significant long‐term social cost associated with it, and that fact needs to be taken into consideration.

I turn now to the amendment to the Higher Education Funding Act. This, again, is obviously not controversial. It basically corrects an anomaly in an earlier piece of legislation so as to enable payments to be made in the calendar years 1996, 1997 and 1998 to support the open learning initiative, the open learning agency.

The introduction of the open learning agency was, again, something I was very closely associated with as Minister for Higher Education. One of the things that struck me when I entered the higher education portfolio was that in this country we had developed a very substantial strength in terms of institutions developing courses for distance type delivery. We had hundreds of courses which had been developed for delivery in this mode. It seemed to me that that was a great strength that we ought to try to do more with and in particular I thought there was merit in having some entity which would act as a brokerage agency and enable people to perhaps pursue a coherent course of higher education study that might bring together course streams that might have been developed in a number of different institutions. With the distance mode of delivery it ought to be possible for people to draw on the strengths of a variety of institutions rather than being constrained to the one.

That was a time also where there was great controversy about access to higher education. It was the period where we had high levels of so‐called unmet demand and there was also a lot of interest in the potential of new technologies to improve access to education and training, to free the delivery of education and training up from the constraints of time and space. There is obviously a variety of technologies there. The traditional methodology has been to use broadcast television, radio as well as print materials but my view at the time was, and now is, that the great growth area and the greatest potential lies in the development of computer based technologies that take advantage of the Internet and which provide that added element of inter activity that you do not get, for example, with the use of the broadcast media or the print media.

Interestingly enough, Mr Speaker, I have a home computer connected to the Internet and I have been looking at a number of web sites around the world. The United States has literally thousands of courses that you can now do over the world wide web which is a part of the Internet. I think that is very exciting and it seemed to me that we ought to be promoting that. So those two concepts of having a brokerage which could bring together courses from diverse institutions so that people could pursue coherent programs of study but without being constrained at a single institution and combining that with some of the new information technology seemed to open up a huge potentiality.

We did have a pilot program in this regard in the early 1990s. It was TV based and that was reasonably successful so on that basis a much broader concept was developed around the brokerage model and a number of delivery methodologies. The government in 1992, the former government, agreed to fund the open learning initiative. In effect, the key delivery agency was a consortium based around Monash University that set up the open learning agency, and that has been operating for, I think, three years now, and it has been a significant success I believe.

A couple of weeks ago I attended a ceremony to deliver the report of an evaluation team based at the Centre for the Study of Higher Education in the University of Melbourne. This report was an evaluation of the effectiveness of the open learning initiative. Frankly, it was very encouraging because there was some scepticism expressed at the time that this was introduced as to whether the amount of money available and the per unit costs that we were looking at could deliver a reasonable quality product that was comparable to on‐campus.
I just quote from the overview of the evaluation report and some particularly encouraging statements, and I quote statement 9:
The overall quality of course offerings in the opening learning initiative is equivalent to that of on‐campus and distance education subjects in the same fields.
