As I said, the relatively low per unit amount being spent on these courses is a pretty significant achievement. Then it also said:

In broad terms the benefits of the open learning initiative to key stakeholders in the initiative, the students, the unit providers, the Commonwealth, the ABC and the community generally have well justified the costs involved.
So it has been a very cost effective measure. The statement concluded:
The open learning initiative has had a significant influence on the broad Australian community, as well as specifically on the tertiary education sector.

At the ceremony to launch this evaluation report to which I referred, one of the key addresses was delivered by Professor Robinson, Vice‐Chancellor of the University of South Australia, soon to be Vice‐Chancellor of Monash University. He commented on how the initiative had affected his own institution. His view was that it had brought very major benefits, quite apart from the improved access directly provided, to the internal culture of the universities that participated. There are 21 universities that have now provided some 230 courses.

Professor Robinson made the point that it has pushed ahead the whole agenda in terms of credit transfer, that is, institutions giving credit for courses done in other parts of the education training system; that it has really moved that agenda ahead to an extent which would have seemed very difficult to imagine just a couple of years ago. So, apart from the direct impact of providing access to education to a whole raft of people, some 20,000 or so people who would not otherwise have had access to higher education, it has moved ahead a number of key agendas within the institutions that are involved, and that, I think, is very important, very significant.

I think it is worth noting that, to get off the ground with something like the open learning initiative, you really need the piloting phase. It is very important that you try a few things, on a small scale initially. This, I think, highlights the importance of what is now described as the discretionary funds component of higher education funding. That term is now used to refer to a number of components of higher education funding apart from the mainstream operating grants and the capital programs and targeted research.

There are now two main elements in the so‐called discretionary funding component of higher education funding. There is the national priority reserve fund and the money that was set aside for the quality assurance program. The national priority reserve fund was designed to have a bucket of money that the minister could use on a discretionary basis to support certain nationwide initiatives that were of significance to the whole higher education system, as distinct from one particular institution. The pilot program for the open learning initiative was a typical example of the sort of thing that was funded under that program.

The coalition said in their pre‐election policy that they would eliminate those discretionary funds. They seek to imply that, really, there is nothing much of significance involved in that and there will not be a significant cost associated with that. I believe there will be very significant costs. The quality program, which is the other main component of the discretionary funds, is something which undoubtedly has brought major benefits to Australia's higher education system. That is very clear from the introduction of that quality initiative back in l990—started in l994—in which a committee completely independent of government and the bureaucracy, people associated with the higher education system, systematically evaluated and reported on the performance of higher education institutions against a number of key benchmarks. That initiative has unquestionably brought about a major culture change within institutions in terms of their attitude towards quality assurance in teaching, in research and in respect of community service.

Getting rid of that is going to be a very major negative for the system. Getting rid of the discretionary elements in the national priority reserve fund will also mean that initiatives like open learning will find it far harder to get off the ground because there simply will not be those discretionary funds to go through the piloting process that you need in order to establish such a thing. Open learning has been a major boon. I do not think it would have happened given the kind of funding structure in higher education that the coalition are proposing to put in place.

On schools, again the specific measure in the bill is uncontroversial. It simply enables the payment of an extra $20.7 million to non‐government schools for capital purposes in the latter half of this calendar year. We obviously support that. It was something that we were going to do, so there is obviously no argument about that.

However, I note in passing that even if the coalition adheres to the promises and commitments they have made in the schools area—you would have to say that is doubtful given their performance in other areas such as higher education where we have seen iron‐clad commitments repudiated—it is a pretty unsatisfactory effort. For example, if you look at the capital program, the coalition pledged an additional $30 million over the next three years which, added to the base funding of $77 million a year, would mean capital funding for the non‐government sector of $87 million a year during that period.

PARA.BREAK: Taking into account the information technology initiative that was proposed by the previous government, the coalition will be spending $87 million compared with what we would have been spending on capital purposes over the coming quadrennium of around $120 million a year. In their pre‐election commitments the coalition proposed nothing extra in capital for the government schools. The Labor government at the time proposed an additional $120 million, all of which was to be incorpo rated in this initiative to facilitate improving access of schools to information technology. We regarded that as a very high priority—the establishment of EdNA—and also wanted to make sure that both government and non‐government schools each had computer centres so that the students would have access to the necessary hardware and could participate. We regarded that as a key part of the capital funding program. Half of that funding was to go to government schools and half to non‐government schools.

BREAK.PARA: The coalition is doing nothing extra for the government schools and substantially less than we were proposing to do for the non‐government schools. If you are making a comparison of the two parties' commitment to school education, it really is a lay‐down misere. Our commitment is far stronger and more substantial than the coalition's in that key area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in favour of the proposed amendments contained in the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, on two grounds: firstly, the failure of the training guarantee scheme to make a meaningful difference to the effective skills and management development in this country and, secondly, that it has been a regressive scheme for business, in particular, on medium to small businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with great interest when the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) mentioned that when the training guarantee scheme was introduced it was necessary but that if businesses were left to their own devices they would not train. I have been involved in the training game for over 18 years and I can tell you that businesses have been training for a lot longer than when the scheme was first put into place.

The member for Batman also raised the Karpin report as a justification for the training guarantee levy, saying that companies needed to invest in training. I do not disagree with that recommendation from the Karpin report. It is important for Australian companies to invest in training. After all, the No.1 asset of their businesses is their employees. Do we do this through an imposition on business? I will be arguing that we do not and its imposition has been very regressive.

He also spoke of the need to invest in companies dealing with the export culture. I do not disagree that companies need to look at their export culture. I certainly have seen quite a few examples of organisations that could improve in that area. But is it up to government to impose what an organisation's culture should be or is it up to the organisation itself? I cannot think of an example when an organisation's culture has changed significantly, if at all, based on the latest ideological fad of a government.

There is a belief held by certain members of the House that all that is required to create a cultural change is to introduce a new tax and then spend the booty—tax and spend. Never mind that the country is in no position to afford such expenditure. The training guarantee scheme is the point at which this theory is put into practice. In particular, business has had to cop the excesses of this overzealous approach to taxation. The logic is: business makes the money, so it can afford to give it back.

It is not unfair to assume from the actions of the previous government that members in the caucus were saying, `Look, we can tax business because, even if the business community does not vote for us, we will always have the support of the battlers.' On 2 March those battlers moved away in droves. If business is asked to share a disproportionate amount of the tax burden to fund programs, even those programs that were created with the best intentions, then at the end of the day there will be no jobs to offer the battler and the battler will turn against those who tax the business that employs them. That is exactly what has happened.

Let us look at the financial impact of the training guarantee scheme. To date, collections from shortfalls have totalled around $2 to $3 million per year. In other words, the levy imposed on businesses was inadequate to cover the cost of running the scheme. No doubt the shortfall has been swallowed by the $8 billion black hole.

Allow me to put such expenditure into context. The coalition stated quite clearly throughout the campaign that the tax burden placed on businesses—the paper and compliance burden—would be reduced by 50 per cent in the first term. This is not the political climate in which we would proceed with unproductive programs which are costing the taxpayer dearly. A constructive review of all job training schemes is necessary and, in the case of the training guarantee levy, long overdue.

No‐one is against the principle of developing and training that most valuable asset—the employee. The training guarantee scheme was created to increase the quality and quantity of training provided by industry—a noble endeavour. Let us examine the degree to which it has been successful and, above all, examine the cost.

The structure of the training guarantee scheme has never been appropriate. The setting of a minimum amount of expenditure simply did not work for business people in my electorate of Deakin, in Melbourne's east. The scheme was not administered in a way that suited the training needs of many businesses. It was expensive, time consuming and impossible to enforce to the letter of the law. In a last‐ditch attempt to improve the scheme before it was suspended, a rollover provision was introduced. The reasoning behind this was that businesses desperately needed a degree of flexibility, and that businesses run their operations not necessarily year to year but within a much longer term framework. But even that is of little benefit to employers.

In my electorate of Deakin there are approximately 8,000 small businesses, most of them built up through the hard work of owner-managers. When the former Prime Minister said, `This is as good as it gets', he was talking about such small business. He was asking them not to hope for much more. I believe we can make things a bit better for such people, and the abolition of this scheme is an important step in that direction.

The legislation which put the scheme into place is symbolic of the former government's lack of commitment to small businesses. The Labor Party—shackled by the residues of outdated, left wing, ideological norms—never recognised the importance of small business as a job creator, as the true engine room of employment growth. Financial demands are being placed on those business people who are struggling to survive. We are making huge demands on their time and resources.

Where are the managers of small businesses in my electorate going to find time to get through all the paperwork? In my constituency those business people often do not even have time to spend a weekend with their families. They are toiling, trying to survive in a tough economic environment. Why make things harder? At the same time we are urging businesses to expand into the global market, and we are telling them that they are the masters of their own destiny in terms of world trade. Let us help them to get rid of these anchors which are holding them down—anchors such as the training guarantee scheme.

I talk about small to medium businesses rather than large businesses because it is widely known that it is small business that is being hardest hit by this scheme. I speak with some authority and experience on this subject. As I mentioned yesterday in my maiden speech, I spent most of my professional life working in human resources. Training providers I have worked with and spoken to have indicated that major big business employers have not had to change their training programs as a result of this legislation, and major employers have not been at all affected by the decision to suspend the legislation. Amounts of 1.5 per cent, if not more, of companies' payrolls have been and are still being spent by these companies on their employees. Business and employers in general do not plan their futures based, as I say, on such ideological principles.

It should come as no surprise to find out that the scheme did not significantly affect the training expenditure of big business. All we need do is look at the ABS figures to get a glimpse of this. The ABS figures reveal that, of the 58 per cent of employers who claim to have increased their expenditure on training, 38 per cent reported only a small increase. It is my impression that expenditure increase was more prevalent among small businesses. Big businesses did not even notice the scheme. Small businesses, of course, increased their expenditure—but only because they had to. It was a forced compliance.

Before entering parliament I worked, as I say, as a human resource practitioner with companies such as Kodak, Repco and a number of other large organisations. I also acted as a consultant for automotive, printing and financial industries. So I believe that I know something about the training programs of large companies in Melbourne, and the failure of this scheme. And as a former member of the American Society for Training and Development and the Australian Institute of Training and Development, and a continuing member of the Australian Human Resources Institute as well as the Organisational Psychology Board, I am fully aware of the vital role of training and professional development in the work force. Without good training programs, a company, while it may not necessarily be doomed, certainly is taking a backward step in its growth.

But for the previous government to apply big business training standards on smaller businesses, which are less capable of meeting the challenge, is simply unfair. It is like a flat tax on business. It is as though Rupert Murdoch were being asked to pay the same amount of tax as a small manufacturing business in Melbourne's outer eastern suburbs.

For those who have never had a chance to see how the scheme was implemented in the real world, it is important to understand the kind of training which is being offered to young Australians with that 1.5 per cent of the payroll of every business. The training provided is occasionally worthwhile and worthy, but often it is not. Often businesses, when confronted by the 1.5 per cent requirement, will opt to put the employees on unnecessary or downright irrelevant training programs. Small businesses understand the cost of employing training staff or qualified training advisers; at $1,500 per day for most of these training advisers, it is not cheap for a small business.

PARA.BREAK: I have heard of an interesting example of how the scheme can go horribly wrong. I was discussing the issue with some of my con stituents and I came across what I call `the forklift syndrome'. A company needs to meet the 1.5 per cent quota fast. What does it do? It decides to spend some money building a training room—in other words, a type of conference room with a whiteboard, which will be used only occasionally. The company prefers to do this than give the government that 1.5 per cent which will not be put back into its business. More likely than not, it will pay for the wage of a bureaucrat who has been given the unenviable task of monitoring this mess.

SPEECH.PARA: But back to the forklift example. The following year the company decides to spend the cash on forklift training. It decides to spend that 1.5 per cent by giving everyone forklift driving certificates—never mind that only one or two employees will actually have the responsibility of using a forklift. I ask the opposition: how have we helped that company; and how have we helped Australia with the training guarantee levy when it is such an impossible scheme to enforce?
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the opposition may call it multiskilling. I call it a waste of resources that could be better spent creating jobs for young Australians. At the heart of the issue is: what do we mean by training—do we mean spending money or providing experience that will better equip Australians to tackle the workplace of the future? In many small businesses, the best training is in fact hands‐on work experience.

SPEECH.PARA: As if all of this were not evil enough, some of Australia's unions have decided to join the fray. Several group training providers have told me of their encounters with unions. I am appalled by what I have heard. The CFMEU has attempted to introduce a training levy into enterprise bargaining agreements. The deal is that companies pay their 1.5 per cent—or whatever the levy may be—into a union fund and the union then agrees to provide training in industry. To an outside observer it would appear that there is nothing sinister in this agreement, in the same way that to an outside observer the training guarantee scheme may seem like a good way of providing Australians with quality training.

Let us have a look at how the unions plan to put the scheme into place. In a nutshell, it is like a union super levy—a way for unions to accumulate power and to control money. There are no assurances that the company that coughs up the money, that coughs up the levy, in the first place will actually receive the benefits—receive their quota of the training dollars.

I will give you an example of how this works. In my electorate in Melbourne's east it is an issue of particular relevance. The Outer East Training Group in Ringwood took the ETU to the Industrial Relations Commission because the union was promoting its own training arrangements and then muscling companies into accepting only workers trained through their schemes. The companies that decide not to go along with the deal will then presumably be banned by the union. The Outer Eastern Training Group is one organisation challenging the ETU on grounds of restrictive trade practices. (Quorum formed)

I also rise to speak on this bill on the basis that it has failed to deliver effective skills. The findings of the Karpin report present us with a clear indication that the trainee guarantee levy has failed to deliver on its principle objectives. The scheme had the purpose of increasing the quality and quantity of training provided by industry. The Karpin report was commissioned after the March 1991 economic statement—no doubt as part of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke's grand vision of turning us into a clever country. We know how much of a noble vision that has become. All we need to do is to ask the former minister for science, Barry Jones, for his views about that issue.

Arising from this strategy, the industry task force on leadership and management skills came down with some findings—the Karpin report. The task force identified that imparting management skills is about upgrading the capability of TAFE and business support, harnessing the talents of diversity and achieving best practice management development. The training guarantee scheme is not the means to achieve these ends. I would venture to say that achieving best practice is a far more effective means of proceeding, as companies that embarked on the ISO 9000 programs have demonstrated.

It is through such competitiveness amongst the companies themselves to achieve these standards that we are finding companies investing money, finances, resources and time into training. They do not need the imposition of a scheme. I speak on this subject with some authority. Back in the 1980s when I was involved with Kodak, with Ford and Nashua it embarked on total quality management. I have seen, as part of that, other companies trying as much as possible to regain the competitive edge. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the opposition's position, as was outlined by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), on the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill. I will be speaking on the value of the training guarantee levy to Australian industry, relating to both the training and the employment of people, and I will also briefly refer to the need to continue a number of labour market programs that were started under the previous Labor government, for the same reason—their contribution to training and employment.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened very carefully to the two government speakers—the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) and the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Barresi). I was disappointed at their hardline approach. Certainly, I expected them to be critical of some aspects of the legislation; that is only natural. However, to suggest that there were no benefits whatsoever in the training guarantee levy and in the policies of the Labor government is quite unrealistic.

They talked about small business. Sixty per cent of the people that work in my electorate of Greenway work for small business. Small business cooperates quite extensively with a number of labour market programs that have operated in the electorate of Greenway. During the period we are talking about we have had a number of New South Wales state governments of all political persuasions—from the Unsworth government through to the Greiner government and the Fahey government. In all cases, these governments were cooperating with the federal government to create a training culture for Australian industry. So I find it very difficult when I hear members opposite being critical and putting their hardline approaches in opposition to what this legislation has achieved.

I rise in the debate to defend the principle of the training guarantee levy, even though this piece of legislation will remove it from the statute book. I recognise and acknowledge that in 1994 the Labor government suspended collection of the levy when the Working Nation programs were introduced. Nevertheless, I tell this House that the principle was a good one and, by its very existence, forced employers and their employees to come together to face the fact that in Australia none of them was doing anything constructive about the training and retraining of our work force.

This levy focused Australian industry for the first time on the need to train the work force to meet the demands of the 1990s and into the next century. If it achieved only that, then it was a success, and Australia will in time reap the benefit of forcing all parties in industry to put their money where their collective mouths have been.

Over the years there have been numerous conferences, seminars, workshops, et cetera—you name it, it has been done—but nothing practical had happened to begin the process of training. When moving the second reading on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990, the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, stated:

The figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in April this year indicate that there has been no significant growth in structured training from the levels estimated for the same period in 1988.

That clearly puts a lie to the statements that have been coming from the other side of the House that industry was training enough employees to meet their own demands. Clearly these figures disprove that fact.

This statement supported the generally held view that industry, on average, did not train sufficient workers for their own needs. Particularly in periods of economic downturn, training was seen as a cost and, accordingly, was one of the first items to be cut back to meet the cost reducing policies of industry.

The Training Guarantee Act was introduced to raise the level of staff efficiency and knowledge of Australian enterprises, both in the private sector and in the public sector. Many sectors of the Australian economy had become concerned that the skill base of Australian industry had been eroded, leaving firms increasingly less able to compete both internationally and domestically.

Surveys conducted by the ABS had shown that many firms did not undertake any training at all and many more provided only minimal training. The Training Guarantee Act was designed to improve the efforts of firms which did not invest in training or invested very little. The government favoured the scheme because it did not penalise those companies which did recognise the value of training and invested in it.

For firms that already trained above the required minimum level, the levy had no financial impact at all. There were some notable firms in this area, including Email whose record in staff training and retraining is a shining beacon for all industry. I am not here to attack industry and say that there was no training whatsoever. In fact, what I am saying is that it was unfairly distributed. A number of major companies did train and trained large numbers of people, but there were many others who did not train at all and actually stole the skilled people from those industries that were training people.

I had some first-hand experience, through my trade union activities, of dealings with companies such as Email. My union had a large number of members working in that establishment. I want to make this very clear because people on the other side of the chamber do not seem to understand the degree of cooperation that does exist in industry—certainly in the metal industry. One would think, if we listened to what comes from the other side, that we are at war with each other all the time, that there is fighting, but that is not the case. There is a large degree of cooperation.

BREAK.PARA: I was happy that my union was involved with the training programs of Email. In fact, I knew the director of training, Brian Jones, personally and was involved with him on a number of training programs and a number of training committees set up by the state government, including the New South Wales Board of Vocational Education and Training. I have nothing but praise for companies like Email, and there are many others which did train and trained very well. My criticism is of those industries that did not train but pinched people from those industries that were training people.

There is no question that Email did pull its weight. At that time, when there was a shortage of trades people, the New South Wales government, particularly the New South Wales railways department, also employed a large number of people. This was during a period of economic recession. To take up the slack that was out there, they employed more apprentices than they really had to. At one time there were over 600 apprentices at the Chullora Training College run by the State Rail Authority.

It is a pity that the downsizing of government organisations such as the State Rail Authority and others now prevents us from training the numbers of people we should be training for industry. I can only hope that this government will give some consideration to setting up group training companies such as those that were operated by the State Rail Authority with a view to training people for industry.

We have to accept the fact that, historically, industry does not train enough people in total for their own needs. This has been the case over the last 20 years. When there has been an economic uplift, there have not been enough skilled workers to fill the jobs required. So there is a need for governments to also become involved in training.

The federal Labor training policy was based on the need to increase the level of industry investment in training. There were at the time far too few firms shouldering responsibility for training. That responsibility should have been shared by industry across the board. The Training Guarantee Act was an integral part of the federal government's strategy to increase industry's investment in training. Its aim was to give Australia the necessary skills it needed to be successful on domestic and international markets. The government's aim was to develop a training culture.

It was clear that companies which did not provide structured training for their employees would eventually be disadvantaged compared with those which did make that investment. Again, it should be noted that there were not too many making that investment. They preyed upon the work forces of those companies which did and stole their best people. The training guarantee was designed to change the attitude of such predator companies and encourage them to regard training not as a cost to be avoided but as a long‐term investment in their most valuable resource, their own employees.

In spite of the federal Labor government's good intentions, they were unable to get any substantive commitment by employers to increase on a voluntary basis the level of training. With apparent widespread concern that training staff were being poached by firms not prepared to invest in training their existing staff, the Commonwealth government felt obliged to take action to bring about a training culture.

Another feature that was influencing the federal government was a significant move away from manufacturing industries and blue‐collar occupations. In the early 1980s there was a job loss of over 90,000 positions in the metal manufacturing industry. Since the late 1980s, however, a massive restructuring of industry has taken place, driven by increased competition, globalisation of production and trade, economic recession and technological change in the workplace.

PARA.BREAK: As a result of these changes, the skill content of jobs was undergoing continuous change and was becoming more advanced. Problems had also emerged in the latter half of the 1980s with further reductions in metal occupations as well as clerical occupations, resulting from retrenchments in electrical and gas industries, and government enterprises such as rail transport. This has resulted in a shift of employment opportunities to the ser vice sector and new growth occupations of tourism, hospitality and information technology. This shift in gross employment required a considerable industry response to training which was simply not there.

BREAK.PARA: It was against this background that the federal Labor government introduced the Training Guarantee Act. In order to meet the requirements of the legislation, employers were obliged to spend an amount equivalent to a proportion of their annual total payroll, if above the threshold, on eligible staff training each year. The designated proportions for 1990-91 were one per cent if the amount was over $200,000, rising in 1993‐94 to 1.5 per cent if it was above $226,000.

Eligible training included in‐house courses such as on-the‐job training—I am sure all companies would be involved in that type of training—office skills, computer training courses, external programs such as off‐the‐job apprentice training, conferences and seminars directly related to the employer's business activity and contributions to training institutions such as TAFE. Equipment to be used in training, such as whiteboards and overhead projectors, could also be claimed against the Training Guarantee Act. I heard the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) complaining about this fact, but if this equipment was not being used all the time for training it could well be used for other parts of running the business.

Firms which did not meet the training guarantee levy were obliged to pay to the Australian Taxation Office the shortfall between the amount determined as their proportion and their expenditure on eligible training. Self‐assessment applied. An employer needed to submit returns only if reporting a shortfall. Moneys collected by the Australian Taxation Office were to be distributed to state and training authorities, to be used for training activities and enhancement. It is important to have recorded the fact that moneys collected were very much lower than expected, indicating I suggest a general acceptance by industry of the need to enter into the spirit of the government's initiatives and to increase their commitment to improving the skills of their work force.

While there were much publicised examples of luxurious and imbalanced use of the training guarantee levy by management and workshop employees, these were few and far between. In fact, most of the participants were responsible and genuinely trying to make up for the years of neglect in the training area. In the main, this levy did succeed in helping to develop a training culture in Australian industry.

While the government might seek to make some sort of political mileage on the passing of this bill, let us never forget that the mere presence of the legislation has meant that in Australia today large and small companies now see training as a major part of their daily operation, not some unnecessary evil that was simply reflected in sending a couple of executives off to a luxurious hotel overseas, which was then called training and claimed as a tax deduction.

Having been involved in the training industry for quite a period of time through my activities as a trade union official, I am very proud of this piece of legislation, which I do believe served its purpose. It is and was a totally defensible piece of Labor legislation that I hope we never have to repeat, for it would be to our nation's commercial peril if we ever backslid to the days of almost nil training within industry, with parasite companies feeding off the few responsible and committed companies. Perhaps the new minister needs to consult those far‐sighted companies like Email and others to ensure that he does not create a return to the bad old days by a slavish commitment to an outdated ideological dogma.

I want to refer briefly to a number of the labour market programs carried out by the previous Labor government which I think in themselves also contributed to that training culture and proved the need for training and, more importantly, got the community involved in training. What it meant was that training was then carried out at the grassroots, close to where industry needs were, so you had a position where unemployed people were able to be trained for jobs that were actually available in the area where they lived.

Mission Employment, a Salvation Army organisation, brought out a report on a number of activities of their skillshare operation in western Sydney. The area itself runs from Sydney to Katoomba and out to Campbelltown. They refer to a number of courses that they had run under the Skillshare organisation: the headstart course, where they had an 88 per cent success rate; the wood trades, a 60 per cent success rate; desktop publishing, a 60 per cent success rate; other employment related services, a 90 per cent success rate; open entry‐exit computer courses, a 91 per cent success rate; food and beverages, an 87 per cent success rate; and overall placement from the centre, an 87 per cent success rate. The success rate relates to people being placed either permanently in jobs or in ongoing training.

There is no doubt that organisations such as the Salvation Army and other organisations that run Skillshares are now very concerned about where their organisations are going. In their report they make further reference to some of the federal government's labour market programs. The report says:

Exciting new work opportunity programs are developing which provide unemployed people with on‐the‐job training. The mission is coming up with creative ideas for training opportunities which fit needs in the employment market, and the new work opportunity program is flexible enough to fund them. Currently, there are programs training people to work in TV stations, in nursing homes and personal care and in building maintenance.

There is no doubt that the skillshare and other labour market programs under the previous Labor government were an outstanding success. But now, because the new government has underestimated the cost of their own promises and overestimated savings from their own cuts, we see an immediate reduction in the staffing of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Some 1,800 people will be retrenched in the first instance. Funds are going to be cut by $1.5 billion, leading to a cut, I feel and fear, in a number of these Working Nation programs that have become so successful for the people in the Greenway electorate.

The organisations running skillshare projects in the Greenway electorate, such as the Salvation Army, are very concerned and very worried about the future of these worthy programs. I ask the government to reconsider their policies towards these Working Nation programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking today in support of the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. This bill deals with three issues: repealing of the Training Guarantee Act 1990 and the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990; the continuation of funding of the open learning education initiative; and the provision of an additional $20.7 million in capital funding for non‐government schools, which was part of a 1992 commitment by the previous government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address first the issue of non‐government schools. One of the fundamental principles of Australian society is the right of families to choose state or private education providers for their children. In 1985 the Labor government set up bureaucratic hurdles which had the effect, if not the intention, of impeding the establishment of new non‐government schools. But, despite these hurdles, the number of students actually attending the independent or non‐government sector increased from 26.4 per cent in 1986 to over 29 per cent in 1996.

Non‐government schools have always provided Australian parents with a choice, in particular of non‐secular education. The majority of our independent school students have always been in the Catholic education system, and no‐one can suggest for a minute that those schools are elitist in their fee structure or are selective in their entrance requirements in all cases. So it is rather strange, given the philosophy of the Labor government, that these sorts of schools really were impeded in terms of their further expansion. The point about the non‐government sector schools is that they provide much‐needed competition within the education industry. In fact, much of the innovation and best practice in our schools in Australia has come from the non‐government school education providers.

PARA.BREAK: It was only six years ago, halfway through the Labor government's 13-year term of office, that we had the second lowest educa tion expenditure per student relative to our GDP compared with all other OECD countries. In fact, only Ireland was spending less on education than we were in that category. We are still struggling to overcome the problems of wanting to be a clever country but underfunding our education systems. So we should not discourage parents from choosing to educate their children independently, since these families save the states on average $1,800 per child in education spending.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Labor government's attempts to impede the schooling choices of Australian families suggest that it was grossly out of touch with the aspirations of Australian families. It misunderstood the freedom of choice, which is a very essential part of Australian society. I therefore very strongly support the effect of item 2, which amends schedule 3 of the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992. This provides already committed capital grants for non-government schools for 1996 and 1997.

I now turn my attention to open learning. The amendment to section 22A(3) of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 enables the minister to approve grants to open learning organisations for the years 1995 to 1998. It is quite obvious that open learning has added substantially to the educational offerings and opportunities in Australia. It adds flexibility and diversity to the offerings of our universities and TAFE institutions.

In particular, the off-campus modes can easily be adapted to the needs of our ever increasingly diverse student populations. Open learning assists the older students who perhaps cannot get out of their homes, those students who are less mobile and students who perhaps have young children and family responsibilities. In particular it helps regional Australians who, as we all know, have substantially less access to education when compared with their metropolitan counterparts.

Let me give an example of how less accessible it is for regional Victorians to attend an educational institution when compared with metropolitan Victorians. In 1990, about the time open learning began, the population of almost 500,000 people in northern Victoria had access to only 3,690 higher education places within the region. This was one place for every 140 people, compared with the statewide provision of one place for every 40 people.

In 1991, 71 per cent of the population lived in urban areas, but students from these same urban areas made up 79 per cent of the higher education population. While 25 per cent of Australia's population come from regional areas, only 19 per cent of higher education students come from these regional areas. So we have marked inequality of access and inequality of participation by regional students in Australian education. At least open learning goes some small way towards changing some of those disadvantages.

Let me draw particular attention to our problems with agricultural education. Not only do all rural students have fewer opportunities to study locally but also they are severely restricted in their choice of courses. I want to talk about that area of agricultural education. Eighty‐four per cent of all degree and postgraduate places in agriculture and horticulture in Victoria are in metropolitan Melbourne, while nearly 55 per cent of students actually enrolled come from rural Victoria. So it is a reality to travel outside your region for full-time education and training or part-time education and training. But that is a substantial cost to families beyond metropolitan Australia.

Even with our government's broadening of the access to Austudy for the asset rich and the income poor, whom you find in our agribusiness sectors in particular, too many of our regional families cannot afford to send their students away to train. The lack of regional courses in particular disadvantages our part-time and mature-aged rural students.

We have the studies. We know that in 1993 the Melbourne University's Centre for the Study of Higher Education evaluated the open learning education system and found that the system had been substantially successful. There was no evidence that students were receiving a lower quality of education compared with their on-campus counterparts. There was also a greater understanding of credit transfers as we progressed through open learning, after its first establishing years.

We found that students and staff in institutions became much more skilled in multimedia use. In fact Australia has been most innovative in multimedia use in its educational areas. About one-third of our open learning courses have broadcast television and/or radio components, and these rate very highly. In 1995, on Saturday mornings over half a million Australians watched open learning TV broadcasts.

Open learning students do not need to meet entry prerequisites when they enter into this formal education undertaking. For many Australians, that is a very important lowering of the barriers for them to enter into and participate in education. They can select courses from a wide range of providers. So, quite clearly, open learning education is quite excellent in Australia.

However, I am concerned that we do not go down the path of suggesting that open learning is ever seen as a substitute for face‐to‐face post‐secondary education in regional Australia. It is essential that we continue to have excellent, locally available, face‐to‐face educational offerings in regional Australia. It is essential for our regional development and for our peer group interaction amongst educational providers. Distance education and open learning must be seen as supplementary and widening the choice, not as an alternative delivery mode for rural people.

We should be further expanding our open learning offerings as an export earner for Australia. They could quite clearly further our interests in Asia and the Northern Hemisphere. They could promote an understanding of Australian society, its natural resources and its business potential. So I strongly commend this government's support for open learning through this amendment. I hope it will continue to flourish with the proviso that it is never seen as a substitute for face-to-face interaction and teaching in regional Australia.

Finally I come to the third part of the amendment: the training guarantee scheme. This was introduced in July 1990 by the previous government. The aim was to increase the quality and quantity of training provided by industry. These objectives were very worthy, given our comparatively low levels of investment in on-the-job training and the need for us to deepen our skills in particular as we tried to keep up with the ever evolving marketplaces in nearby Asia.

Unfortunately, the strategy adopted was flawed. Externally imposed requirements on business to divert resources to training did not help, especially during the recession `we had to have', and do not necessarily improve business culture in relation to training. They certainly do not improve the quality or relevance of the training provided by a business. Consequently, we all know of so many examples of mickey mouse courses and trainers who sprang up all around the country to take advantage of the sudden desperate urge for businesses to spend some dollars. Boardroom extensions were redefined as training rooms. In short, honourable intentions were too often defeated by inappropriate, naive tactics which put industry offside at the very time we needed a spirit of cooperation and a recognition from businesses of the costs of an underskilled work force and the productivity benefits of increased skilling.

Nor did this training guarantee levy address the chronic maldistribution of skilled labour or professionals such as we see hampering Australia's regional development. For example, there is an oversupply of health service professionals, engineers, law graduates and administrators in the cities and a clustering of urban businesses, and there is a chronic undersupply in regional Australia.

Let us look at a couple of our industries which, if this had been a workable, successful scheme, should have benefited and overcome their chronic lack of a skilled work force by now. Let us look at the food industry in Australia. It is amongst our three largest industries, employing more than 220,000 people and producing goods worth over $35 billion. Its exports totalled more than $10 billion in 1994 and its predicted growth rate is five per cent per annum over the next five years. It has very real opportunities for export growth, and the dairying industry is one of our best performers in the export market.

BREAK.PARA: But the food industry is currently undergoing a period of rapid technological change in primary production, processing, preservation, packaging and transportation. The industry has to use new and innovative technology and the most skilled marketing to capture and protect fast evolving markets. But despite these needs, the industry is chronically short of skilled workers at all levels.

In particular, in my electorate in the Murray, Goulburn and Loddon valleys, which include Australia's biggest dairy export sector, we are critically short of locally based skilled staff. The training guarantee scheme did little to address or encourage the local businesses in the food sector to change. In particular, let me talk about the fruit harvesting industry in the area. We have a chronic shortage of experienced and motivated pickers to efficiently harvest the fruit crops each year. This problem exists all around Australia. Between January and March we need a minimum of 8,000 people alone in my electorate, and harvesters' wages represent between 25 per cent and 50 per cent of the total production costs of each orchard.

We have found that only 10 per cent of pickers come back after each season. In 1995 a survey of the orchardists found that one of the industry's greatest concerns is the shortage of skilled seasonal workers. Pickers, when they were interviewed at that time, said there was little training provision in orchards or elsewhere. The harvest labourers who were interviewed said they had no awareness of the task or what was expected of them by the employers—the growers. The growers had no specific training for their orchard supervisors, and these gangers were expected to manage work teams of 15 to 25 workers effectively.

The Northern Victoria Fruit Growers Association responded to the money requirements, if you like, in the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 by developing a picker training course. However, only one orchard formally provided this course to its harvest labour. Quite clearly, the top‐down approach did not work when we faced the needs of industry on the ground. That is because the training needs cannot be addressed by such a levy. They are multifaceted. They need a multifaceted approach.

Fortunately, a new post-training guarantee levy era is now operating amongst the harvesters and growers in the Goulburn and Murray valleys. It is through cooperation between DEET, the CES, the Northern Victoria Fruit Growers Association, the processors and a whole host of growers that a local harvest labour office has been established. With only one full-time worker, last season there was a substantial improvement in training and in growers understanding the needs of their orchard supervisors. So by adopting a different approach, the industry managed to turn the situation around somewhat.

There are other problems associated with training which only the government can assist with, and they relate to enticing pickers to come and stay, especially the numbers of international backpackers whom we depend upon. At the moment the system relating to unemployment entitlements creates disincentives. If those previously unemployed who have become pickers work more than 13 weeks, they must wait longer to have unemployment entitlements re-established.

If you do not have a tax file number, after 28 days your tax rates jump from a minimum to a maximum—as they should. Too many pickers do not have tax file numbers and so the labour turnover is not helpful. For working international holiday‐makers—the backpackers—tax rates vary from 29 per cent to 47 per cent. It is not really worth while for them to do the work. We need a coordinated, cooperative approach with government. This government understands those problems and will work with industry. It will not simply impose a levy from above.

Let me talk about another local initiative—the Northern Industries Education Board—which has brought local food manufacturers together to cooperate in Australia's first program designed to attract and retain local students doing years 11 and 12. They want to keep them in the region to become our next generation of highly skilled food technologists. We have 13 students this year doing years 11 and 12 and they are being mentored by 20 or more of our biggest manufacturers in the region. They are being paid $100 per week while they do more than 100 days work experience each year. They will end up with a VCE qualification, TAFE accreditation, and they are on their way to obtaining a food technology qualification which we hope will turn around the future for young people and create a different perception about local industry work opportunities.

Again, this has come about through cooperation and not through a training levy imposed from above. The local dairy industry is now pursuing a similar path to substantially reduce the farm apprenticeship scheme to a number of months. (Quorum formed) (Extension of time granted) As I was saying, the dairy industry has had a major problem in attracting and retaining its dairy apprentices. In 1997 students will be able to complete six months of a proposed dairy operators traineeship while they complete their VCE. They can then go on to Dookie College in the region for two or so days a week. They will receive credits towards a Bachelor in Applied Science (Dairying) at Melbourne University. This will substantially improve future training; it is the opposite to what was offered in the training guarantee levy, which was a top‐down imposed effort which bullied individual businesses. This UDV local initiative is not the result of a training guarantee levy; it is the result of industry cooperation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was Working Nation, and you're going to knock it off.

—That's fine; I am talking about the training guarantee levy. This dairy industry iniative is an example of how training issues are multifaceted. They require multifaceted inputs and cooperation between numbers of different players. That is why the guarantee training levy failed so abysmally to address rural training needs. I have referred to the food sector. It is crippled at the moment with insufficient skilled workers from the primary producer through to food technologists and world best marketers. Thank heavens this amendment is now before the House and we will see no more of that nonsense where we wave a wand and say, `Unless a business spends X number of dollars on training, it will be punished and the money will be taken away anyway.'

BREAK.PARA: What we have now is a different system. In regional Australia, local business cooperation is now the order of the day. You do not have cooperation with government when you have to comply with bureaucratically complex requirements in accounting for the dollars you have spent on training, arguing that you will have an overhead projector put into your boardroom and that counts as a training room when, in fact, the week before it was your boardroom.

Businesses were forced to see the government as the enemy in terms of training. Now in this new era we see small business recognising that the government of the day is not the enemy; it is in partnership. It is creating an environment in which local initiatives are able to be developed. Therefore, we will see a real skilling of Australia, which is what it is all about. I suggested to the House earlier that rural Australia has a chronic shortage of skilled people. I have also suggested that we must ensure that open learning, while a great initiative, never replaces face‐to‐face interaction and education available to people in country areas.

I refer to the Labor government's past performance on independent school funding, particularly in regional Australia. In my electorate there are many ethnic minorities and they are extraordinarily concerned if they do not have access to non‐secular education. The Labor government made it difficult for people from a non‐Anglo background to choose, perhaps, a Muslim school and for people in impoverished rural areas to choose Catholic education if that is what they wanted. That is what you achieved through your incredible sense of independent schools being elitist.

This amendment—these three different initiatives—is a reflection of what went badly wrong for the Labor government. You had the rhetoric about mediocrity being where we had to be—that is, you politicised the state school system. People left the schools in droves, seeking independent education for their children. But you tried to block that exit by making it difficult for those poor struggling parents to find independent schools of their choice.

The statistics show that you did not succeed. Over those 10 years, enrolments went up in non‐government schools. Today we can make sure that the freedom of choice for the families of Australia remains. They are thanking us every day as they say, `We can go back to our small regional Catholic schools and colleges. In Shepparton we can have a Turkish school to serve the needs of Muslim students.' It is all about returning freedom, particularly multicultural freedom, to our Australians.

I am very pleased that I was given an extension of time. It has been useful to remind other members of the House what a problem we have had. Now we can solve it. I am pleased to strongly support the bill. I look forward to an industry‐driven cooperative training environment in the future where government is assisting, not hampering. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Murray (Mrs Stone) made some important positive points but, as the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) in his contribution will point out, many of these programs which she referred to are in danger because of the proposed massive cuts which the new government has foreshadowed in relation to education, employment and training programs. We have had a wide‐ranging discussion on these three issues in the debate to this point. I also want to range over them, but I want to make more general points which have not yet been made in this debate or indeed in the debates which we have had including, unfortunately, many of the maiden speeches by members opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: When listening to the maiden speeches I have tried to work out whether the new government has any general philosophy to speak of, especially in the area of social justice programs, employment programs, education programs and training programs. It has been widely reported that John Howard, the Prime Minister, won the election on the basis of going to the people and basically saying, `Well, trust me. I'm going to do a better job than Labor,' without putting forward any real concrete program. We have been waiting since the election to hear more about what sense of vision, philosophy and direction they are going to have for this country, but we have heard very little indeed from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —But support for the dairy traineeship.

—We have heard support for specific programs, as the member for Hotham states, but at the same time we have seen their single‐minded determination to cut, cut and cut key programs, especially those in the social justice area.

SPEECH.PARA: These programs were, of course, the hallmarks of what made Australia in the last decade a reasonable social democratic society. They were programs in the areas of unemployment, education and training which went to the heart of the sorts of things that we have to do in order to give people some sense of their worth, some sense that they belong in society and some sense that society is committed to giving them social justice.

What we have had from the Prime Minister and from the government generally is nothing more than opportunism. All we have had is the idea that they do not entirely agree with the Fightback package or with all the New Right measures. This is what they have been telling us. But, on the other hand, they do not tell us what philosophy they have or what sense of direction they have which is supposedly going to substitute for the Fightback measures.

They are using this fictional idea, this so‐called $8 billion hole, as an excuse in order to create a situation in which they bring back that same old New Right philosophy which they claimed to the Australian people they no longer believed in.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Fightbackwards'.

—Fightback and `Fightbackwards', as the honourable member says. If you look at the composition of the new government, what do you find? You have people who are committed to this New Right philosophy in a very strong way and you have the so‐called moderates who, although they call themselves moderates, do not have any particular philosophy to speak of, except that they are opposed to the New Right. Then you have the real extremists—the rednecks. They are the people we saw coming out of the woodwork in relation to the gun issue and the native title issue. Those people are very right wing in their philosophy and are really determined to crush—
—They must be further to the right than the right of the Labor Party.

—They are much further to the right than anyone in the Labor Party, I can assure you of that, mate. In fact, some of them were described as being to the right of Genghis Khan by a commentator I heard the other day. But that is another matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me contrast this lack of philosophy, this lack of direction and this idea of cutting here and cutting there for the sake of cutting programs rather than having any coherent framework or any coherent set of directions with the kind of direction which the Labor Party was committed to—and continues to be committed to—in this area. First of all, we should go back to a basic premise. The basic premise is that society is concerned not only with economic efficiency and economic wellbeing but also with social justice for all its people.

If that is the case, then there are certain very important principles that need to be put into place. In particular—as I have emphasised in my writings and in discussion and as was emphasised by the Labor Party at its last national platform—there are certain social rights that people are entitled to. These social rights include the right to employment, the right to be prepared and trained so that you can gain employment and, in addition, the right to a decent education. Of course, the other rights are the right to decent health care and the right to proper housing. These fundamental social rights are in addition to the kinds of human rights that we all agree with.

But these fundamental social rights are often challenged by conservatives and, if you look at the New Right tradition that arose in Britain and the United States—Thatcherism and Reaganism, which were the favourite philosophies of the current Prime Minister until recently—you will find that they present a direct challenge to these fundamental social rights.

What we have heard about the intentions of the government in relation to employment and education clearly shows that there are going to be serious cuts in these areas which will affect the government's ability to deliver on these fundamental social rights. Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say to you in relation to this matter that we are extremely concerned, firstly, in relation to the employment programs.

The Working Nation structure that was put into place was not put into place simply because, as the conservative parties have said, there was some manic desire on the part of the Australian Labor government to spend money on programs; that is a nonsense. It was put into place because there were recommendations to the government, stemming from a green paper on employment, which effectively said that the government had to put into place a job compact in order to try to secure employment for people who, even if there were an economic recovery, were unlikely to find employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The long‐term unemployed.
—The long‐term unemployed, as the shadow minister said. In fact, the authors of the green paper—I quote from the committee's report—had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic growth will continue to be crucial in stemming the flow into unemployment, but past experience shows that it is not enough to reduce the number of people subject to long‐term unemployment as quickly as we would wish. More must be done to assist them into worthwhile jobs through improved labour market programs including delivery responsive to their needs.

The labour market functions less efficiently when there are large numbers of people who are not strongly attached to the labour market and less able to compete for vacancies when they occur. Hence, for both equity and efficiency reasons, the Committee has proposed the introduction of a Job Compact.

So the committee's recommendations were taken up by the Labor government and, as a result of that, significant and very important programs were put into place—a whole range of programs under Working Nation which were intended to assist the long‐term unemployed through training, through further education, through vocational guidance and through assistance, even at the level of the Commonwealth Employment Service, so that people were looked after and cared for in terms of their employment needs.

And what do we find? What does the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) keep saying? He says that Working Nation is a failure, that Working Nation should never have been put into place, and that Working Nation is wrong. All of these things he has said and he continues to say, notwithstanding the evidence that, without Working Nation's expenditure and without all those many programs, we would have been in a position where the long‐term unemployed would not have been assisted in the dramatic way in which they were assisted in the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And now they have frozen the funds.

—And now, as the former minister, who was responsible for many of those programs and who did an excellent job in that role, says, they have frozen the funds. And they are now talking about cutting out dramatically all those programs. The question that has to arise is: how then are we to ensure that even if—and it is a very big `if', judging from the way this new government looks like it is organising the economy, because every time you ask a question of the economic ministers they behave as if they have not even understood an undergraduate lesson in economics and most of them do not even know the basic interconnections between economic factors—
—They lack a good Labor education.

—They have not had the proper education in economic theory to understand even the most basic matters. So whether they will do any good on the economy is a very moot point. In fact, one suspects that, whereas we should have had significant economic growth this year, we will probably be in a difficult position as a result of their endeavours. As a result of that, unemployment is likely to increase, unfortunately, and the long‐term unemployed, the people whom the job compact and the Work ing Nation programs were intended to assist, will be in a very difficult position indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have to ask ourselves: is it a fact that Minister Kemp and Minister Vanstone in the Senate, who seems not to know what the hell is going on, are going to bring in the same actions which they foreshadowed in the Fightback package—in other words, cutting out programs that assist the unemployed and cutting out programs that assist those workers? I believe, particularly given Dr Kemp's previous writings and his total embracing of the New Right philosophy for many years, that that is their agenda, that that is what they want to do and that they are simply trying to use this nonsense of the so‐called $8 billion hole as an excuse to bring back into the Liberal Party, into the government of this country, the philosophy which they claimed they had disowned at the time of the election.

What is going to be the consequence for real people? The consequence is going to be that those unemployed people will not have those programs available to them. As a result of that, we will be in such difficulties that we are going to become even more problematical as a nation in terms of poverty, in terms of the consequences of unemployment and in terms of some of the social problems that we have. I predict that we will have more and more social problems as a result of the agenda which the conservative government is putting forward.

But there is another matter which concerns the question of education. What have we seen in the area of education? We have seen further proposals for dramatic cuts in the area of education, plus total abdication of responsibility to the states. Already we know what has happened in some of the states—and most of the states are run by Liberal administrations. What has happened? Most of those Liberal administrations are actually cutting education. Look at what happened in Victoria, for example, under the Kennett regime, a disgraceful performance in education. And what are we going to do? We are going to hand more power, in school education particularly, to the states and we are going to get out of it altogether, according to this new idea of federalism being put forward.

BREAK.PARA: So what will happen to the education of our young people? The federal government is going to say, `Oh well, never mind, it's not our business; it's not our responsibility; it's somebody else's responsibility.' That will mean that the possibility of achieving a just society in which every person has the fundamental right to education, a proper education and an education that leads to the fulfilment of their potentialities, will not be occurring. So it seems to me that we are faced with a crisis in this area.

But then on top of this, as if this was not bad enough, what do we find? We find an attack on the higher education sector. We are now going to find an attack on our universities, on our TAFE colleges and on our other institutes of higher learning. We are going to find a massive cut has been foreshadowed against those universities and colleges.

What kind of a government believes that it can actually get away with a massive cut in the higher education sector when it is trying to tell us that it believes in a competitive international market and that it believes in the training of our people? We have heard so many speeches, even in this debate, from the spokespersons for the government saying that they believe in training and they believe in education. Yet we are going to see these massive cuts in those higher sectors of education. Or are we to suppose that the only training that people need is up to the end of high school and then we forget about them?
Mr Crean interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The former minister says, quite correctly, that when they left government last time we had a disgraceful situation in this country where less than 30 per cent of children finished year 12. Now we have a situation in which more than 80 per cent of children finish year 12—and that figure is going up.

BREAK.PARA: Now we have heard about the possible reversal of this in the school system, but even when people finish at year 12 they need additional training and education, they need the universities and colleges. This regime is going to cut out that factor.

There is another aspect to this. What about research? What about the advancement of learning? Australia has a very proud record in the sciences and the humanities in the advancement of learning. Our universities have participated in virtually all fields towards the advancement of learning in a very strong and important way. Many people have contributed to the total sum of human knowledge through their degrees, their research and their doctorates. What is going to happen to all of that?

If this massive cut comes through, will the research capacities of the universities not be affected? Of course they will. They will be seriously affected. We will find that our scientific endeavour and our work in the humanities—which, as I say, is internationally acclaimed—will be seriously hampered. In other words, as a nation we are cutting ourselves short.

Over the last decade under the Labor government, our nation has been committed to excellence in education and to assisting in the development of our culture and our sciences. All of that is going to be threatened by the proposed cuts. The Labor Party is committed to a very different philosophy. Not only are we fundamentally committed to the idea of certain basic social rights but also we are committed to resourcing those programs and ensuring that there are sufficient programs for the education of all our children, including higher education of our young people and, indeed, those people who want to go back to universities and colleges.

We are committed to training and employment programs that are going to assist everyone including the long‐term unemployed. Therefore, we are committed to building a better and fairer society in which the principles of social justice not only are words but are also manifested in concrete programs that assist the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me pleasure to take this opportunity to remind the House of the significant contribution that Labor made in its 13 years to developing the skills of this country. Essentially, it did that by recognising that it is the responsibility of government to invest in human resources—people capital. Clever countries are not clever unless they develop the skills of their people. Gone are the days when people could go into unskilled jobs. The simple reality is that young people who leave school before year 12 are twice as likely to be unemployed than those who complete year 12 or do better. There is a simple message in that: skill development enhances people's chances of employment. It is the passport to employment. The real issue is: how do we make training and skills development more relevant not just to industry but to the individuals who wish to pursue it?

SPEECH.PARA: Labor made a commitment to expand significantly the funding at all levels. In relation to the schools, we put in significantly more money in real terms but, sadly, over recent years we have seen state governments take that money and use it for other purposes. We have the disgrace in the Victorian situation where, since Jeff Kennett has been in office, we increased funding in real terms to schools by two per cent and he has cut it by 10 per cent. Yet this is the direction in which the new government wants to go—untying grants and no commitment to ensuring funds destined for education end up in it. We will see the demise of the school system if it is left to the states without any discipline to deliver.

Labor, in its 13 years, increased schools funding by 55 per cent in real terms—a huge commitment. In terms of the TAFE and other vocational sector, it increased funding by 56 per cent in real terms. It increased funding in excess of 60 per cent in universities, where we saw an almost 80 per cent increase in university places.

That did not come about overnight; it was a progressive commitment by this government. A number of initiatives developed during our term in office. The training guarantee levy, which is what we are debating the abolition of tonight, was introduced as part of a commitment, a leverage, to ensure a shared responsibility to lift the nation's commitment to skill development.

We had a position in which it was not only the government that was prepared to invest substantially more resources in education. The government took the view that industry should also contribute, and we believed that, if industry were to contribute, the individual also had a responsibility to make a contribution to higher education. It was from that concept that the HECS scheme, in terms of higher education, developed—a commitment whereby we said that people should repay the equivalent of 20 per cent of not the average course costs but the minimum course costs when they achieved a certain level of income, the principle being that university education gave them a better chance to a higher income. They were not required to repay this one‐fifth of the contribution until their income reached a certain level.

If we were expected to make students make a contribution to higher education, what was wrong with the notion that employers and industry should also make a contribution? That is what the training guarantee levy did as part of the package that saw HECS and as part of the package that saw the massive commitment by this Labor government when it was in power to increase VET funding, skills funding and higher education funding.

I remind the House that, before the training guarantee levy was introduced, nearly 60 per cent of employers with payrolls over $200,000 provided any structured training to their work force. With the introduction and implementation of the training guarantee levy, the Australian Taxation Office indicated that that 60 per cent went to 90 per cent. So do not tell me that this did not make a contribution to requiring industry to focus on its responsibility to make a contribution. It was not to bear the whole cost. In fact, it was a very small proportion of the cost. But it was to at least make a contribution—not moralise about government or individuals having to do it but be part of the shared partnership, the shared commitment. That is indeed what the training guarantee levy was about and what it was designed to achieve.

I accept that it was a pretty blunt instrument. I accept that there were circumstances in which certain courses qualified for training that were really mickey mouse operations. I accept that. I also accept that there was significant paperwork associated with satisfying the authorities that the contribution to training had been made. That is why, in the development of Working Nation some 2½ years ago, I took the view, as the responsible minister of the time, that if we could find a better way of getting industry commitment to training we would get rid of the levy.

Back in 1994, when Working Nation was announced, the levy was suspended. So the reality is that this levy has not been paid for almost three years. I made the commitment to industry at the time, because I spoke to them in the implementation of Working Nation, that if they were prepared to achieve the targets that we set for traineeship growth, which was something in the order of 35,000 traineeships, we would abolish the levy.
