Going into the last election we made a pledge to abolish the training guarantee levy because we were not only going to achieve the 36,000 total; we were going to exceed it.

All we are doing tonight with this legislation is implementing Labor policy. Let us face it: the training guarantee levy has not been paid for two, three years, and it was to be abolished if we were returned anyway. So let us not get carried away with the notion that this simple act will see a commitment by industry to advance the training agenda. You will only get that—and this is where I believe that the contribution made by the member for Murray (Mrs Stone) was spot-on—if you try to get an agreement with industry, a shared commitment to really develop the training agenda.

Let me just indicate what the position was when Labor came to power back in 1982-83, because I have heard the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) in this place parrot on about the numbers. The fact that he gets this wrong—just as he gets so many policy directions wrong—I think, is the reason that he is not the cabinet minister he thought he would be and responsible for this area of activity. The one thing I do have to give the minister credit or recognition for is his consistency—his ideological consistency—with the user‐pays principle of getting rid, effectively, of the role of government and making people do it on their own.

What we saw under the Howard and Fraser government when it lost office in 1983 was apprenticeships at 34,800 per year—and no traineeships. Traineeships had not even been thought of in the scheme of things under that government. So the total number of structured training places under that government was 34,800. What is the number today? It is 96,500, comprised of 60,000 apprenticeships and 36,500 traineeships. They are the figures.

We have seen not only a progressive growth in apprenticeships but also the fact that apprenticeships, as good as they are, are not attractive to employers, on the one hand—particularly small businesses—nor, on the other, to individuals because they do require a commitment in advance of three to four years. You expect young people to sign up to a program that they think they want to pursue and then get locked into it. What we have to provide if we are smart about getting the training agenda properly developed is flexibility: the opportunity for people to move in and out of structured training, or on-the-job training, with a proper system of accreditation and recognition—a national framework against which this can be judged.

It is interesting to see the huge growth that has occurred in traineeships, particularly over the last 12 months. Traineeship vacancies lodged in 1995—that is all of last year—were 23,707. That was double what they were in 1994. The year 1994 was when NETTFORCE was established, the vehicle under Working Nation to make the traineeships more relevant to individuals and more relevant to business. So you had a doubling between 1994 and 1995. But already this financial year, July to March, there have been 29,000 traineeship vacancies lodged compared with 9,200 in the same period last year. That is a trebling.

So we are not just seeing a quirk. We are not just seeing a statistical blip. We are seeing an exponential growth in traineeships. In the March quarter of 1996 there were 15,000 traineeship vacancies compared with 4,600 in the March 1995 quarter. They have more than trebled.

Why is this? If business is signing up, if business is demanding these things, if business is asking for traineeships and saying it wants people under them, that suggests we have the product right. If businesses were walking away from apprenticeships, especially in a recession when they were not prepared to take the long-term view, if they were not attracted to the old, structured and rigid traineeships, we got the product right and the demand followed.

But how did we get the product right? It was not by some bureaucratic exercise, as the member for Murray tried to suggest before. We set up an organisation that was closer to what industry wanted and closer to what the industrial partners wanted. That body was called NETTFORCE. It was chaired by Lindsay Fox. It comprised Bill Kelty, Bert Evans, Joan Kirner—a number of people. They were not bureaucrats. They were people who understood what industry wanted and went out to industry and said, `We're prepared to tailor a traineeship program to your needs.'

We heard before the member for Murray talk about what has been done with the dairy industry. The simple fact is before NETTFORCE came along there was not a dairy traineeship. I had not only the opportunity to authorise the one that the member for Murray referred to but also the pleasure to see another development of this approach up in the Northern Rivers area. Rather than try to get traineeships lodged in terms of the farm, we went to the dairy cooperative because of its links with the farm and its ability to provide training opportunities not just on the farm but in processing and marketing—all of those things. This was the clever approach to getting industry involved.

But the interesting thing is that, when you look at where the jobs growth has come over recent years, you will see that it is significantly in these sorts of areas. We are talking about general employment growth over 12 months in the order of 3½ per cent—agriculture at over seven per cent; libraries, museums and the arts at 10.4 per cent; health services at 5½ per cent; community services at 6½ per cent; accommodation and restaurants at five per cent; food retailing at 5.6 per cent; construction at 6.9 per cent; wholesale trade at 3½ per cent; sport at 11 per cent; and road transport at 11 per cent.

The interesting thing about that is not only was there growth in jobs far in excess of what the national average is but also before Nettforce came along in not one of those industries was there a traineeship. If we are serious about saying that training and skills are the passport to employment and these are the areas in which the jobs are but there is no training to develop the people in question, how are we seriously going to say we are going to meet the skill requirements of those industries? Yet it was NETTFORCE that came along and provided that opportunity.

What has the current government done with NETTFORCE? It has abolished it—this most successful program in terms of creating the traineeships, getting a trebling of demand, opening things up in all of these areas. Considering all the rhetoric the government goes on with about getting closer to industry, what does it do to the one body that has finally broken through, the one body that has delivered? It abolishes it. Why? Because it is a Labor institution, because we set it up and the government cannot bring itself to recognise the contribution, the significant change, that Labor has made. What gall! The minister, after abolishing NETTFORCE, had this to say in the final paragraph of a letter to the chairman and none of the other members of the board:

I would like to express my appreciation for your work and that of the other Nettforce board members. Your efforts have in no small way contributed to a considerable growth in traineeship numbers which we are now experiencing in 1996.

`Thanks very much. Thanks, NETTFORCE. Thanks for breaking through. Thanks for doing what we could not do before through the institutional barriers, but we are going to abolish it.' That is why I say this government has no real view about where the training agenda is going. It does not understand what has worked. It does not understand the dynamics that have occurred within the industry over recent years and it does not understand the significant contribution that Working Nation has made.

The government think Working Nation is a welfare approach. They think Working Nation is just about recycling people. Working Nation had two fundamental objectives: getting the long-term unemployed back into the work force and lifting the skills of the nation. It was micro-economic reform because it was saying that we should not treat the long-term unemployed as being out of the work force, we should treat them as being useful, but they will only be useful if we can build their skills. If we are going to build their skills, we will expand the labour supply.

It is important if we are to keep inflationary pressures down that there be a strong demand for jobs. Labor created 740,000 jobs in three years. That is far in excess of anything you said we could achieve. You laughed at the figure of 500,000 jobs, but we actually created 740,000. It was not just demand we created; we also created supply. That is the reason, for the first time in the history of this country, we achieved record jobs growth without inflationary pressure. We achieved that because we were able not only to get the long-term unemployed back into any program but also to engage them in the types of skills that the economy was seeking.

It is true that there have been certain areas of skills shortage. I am not trying to pretend that that is not so. But I think you do have to look at the facts—supply increased, compensating the demand. And what are we getting for the first time? We are getting a labour market that is truly functional. All that will be put at risk. The labour market programs will be cut by the government, university places will be cut, ANTA funds will be untied and school funds will be handed back to the states with no requirement for them to be spent in education. Everything that Labor built over 13 years will be put at risk. This is madness with which you are going on.

Whilst we do not object to the training guarantee levy being abolished, because it was our intention to abolish it, we do object to the philosophy, the direction, behind your training approach. I am sure that tomorrow we will see you also looking to cut into youth wages. You believe that the only solution to getting youth back into the labour market is to cut their rates of pay. The IR legislation will provide that opportunity. We will be using everything we can to expose that as well as to ensure that people understand the full success of Labor's commitment to training and skilling this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise not to oppose the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill but to point out that the new government's position is dominated by ideology in the area of education and training. That approach will have an impact not just on the overall economy but on my electorate of Grayndler, which is in the inner western suburbs of Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The current government has criticised Labor's approach. When Labor introduced the training guarantee scheme in 1990, the then opposition screamed about it. They said that it was placing an unfair burden on employers. The fact is that the Labor government would not have had to have done that had employers responded by providing adequate training for workers at that time. What we saw at that time was very much a lack of vision. Large employers were focusing on the situation today and tomorrow rather than the situation in one, two or 10 years time. This also applied to the work force as a whole. This levy was introduced with a time limit and in conjunction with a gamut of government programs. These programs related not just to the quantity of job creation but also to the quality of job creation, which was a major focus of the Karpin report, known as Enterprising Nation. In 1994, we saw that culminate in the Working Nation package, which was a tremendous success and achievement. In the 1993 federal election the Labor government promised to create 500,000 jobs in its next term in office. That promise was greeted with great scepticism, but the government went on to create over 740,000 jobs.

It is perhaps best to look at local examples, because when we talk about unemployment, we are not talking just about statistics, but about real people with real families and real needs. In the past few weeks in my electorate I have had much representation from people who are concerned about the government's ideologically driven approach. Someone who came to see me gave me a copy of a letter dated 9 May 1996 from a Mr Andre Kaspura of DEET to all regional managers in the Sydney eastern area. That letter was headlined `Approvals and payments of labour market programs'. The effect of that letter was that this government has put a stop to all those programs which will give the unemployed an opportunity to get work. The letter stated:
After considering the situation, I have decided that approvals will cease for the rest of the financial year for the following programs:
Special Intervention, including assessments for ESL, literacy, psychologist and disability group training and SIP other.
Jobtrain, contracted and individual approvals, immediate minor assistance—only to be approved with local purchase orders. (No more automatic $100 approvals)
TAP (for the Aboriginal community), work experience, skills development, non‐accredited training, formal training, post‐placement support.
In a great show of compassion from this new government, this letter said:
Please find attached a standard letter that may be issued to job seekers who seek assistance under the programs that are no longer approvable.

Under the previous government people could get a job after taking part in an English language program or after being provided by the CES with an automatic $100 worth of boots or some sort of work related clothing. They are now being told by this government, `Wait a moment, we have not decided what we will do in the area of education and training, but we have decided that we are not going to help the people of the eastern Sydney area to gain employment for the rest of the financial year.' The greatest indictment of that approach is that Labor's programs were actually working.

Just down the road from my office is the Marrickville Skillshare. Skillshare's funding remains under threat from this government. They are not quite sure whether the funding will continue until the budget is brought down or whether it will continue after that. But they know that there is no guarantee that they will exist after 30 June. Under the award, they have to give four weeks notice to their employees. So there is a great deal of uncertainty. People whose main task is to get others into employment are uncertain about their own employment.

What it really means is that the coalition is stalling for time. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) is not quite sure what she will do. She cannot quite get her head around what to do with labour market programs, so everything is just on hold at the moment. In their eagerness to slash the existing labour market programs, which were working, they are neglecting to recognise that there is a necessary cost in these programs.

Skillshares are one of most cost effective areas of labour market programs. The program is funded at $1,000 per head for each training and placement. Skillshare also has uniform national infrastructure, delivering the program across all regions and towns in Australia. If the coalition allows this infrastructure to be dismantled, it will be extremely difficult and costly to re-establish. The infrastructure which has been built up over the years will just disappear. The skills, the knowledge and the experience of those dedicated people who work in that sector will be lost.

It is important to recognise that Skillshares are, in effect, contractors to the Commonwealth government. Either the schemes get job seekers through the door or they go out of business. If they are not operating successfully, then the Skillshares simply do not continue to operate. The government needs to take urgent action to ensure that those Skillshares are not stranded without funding because, as I have pointed out, unless action is taken prior to 30 June, this valuable scheme will cease to exist.

Skillshare is certainly working in my electorate of Grayndler. So far in this financial year, Skillshare at Marrickville has already assisted over 750 people. It is not surprising given the nature of the electorate that 70 per cent of these people are from non-English speaking backgrounds, 60 per cent have been unemployed for over 18 months and 25 per cent have been unemployed for over four years. In finding those people real jobs, the success rate of people who have been referred to Skillshare at Marrickville is 60 per cent, and that is an outstanding figure.

There are a range of benefits and services provided to the clients in Marrickville. There is an intensive search for jobs, there is personal attention given to people who walk through the door, there is the development of new job seeking strategies and there is individual counselling for people so that they are treated as real individuals and their individual needs are considered and looked after. As you walk in the door, there is a phone available for anyone—many people in my electorate do not have access to telephones—to use. There are also the local and state newspapers so that people can get assistance to look up jobs that they might be interested in. People can also get assistance with language skills to ensure that their chances of gaining employment are maximised.

There is group support so that the long-term unemployed—who experience isolation—are made to feel that they are not alone. A lot of positive motivation is created in this environment. Most importantly, all the employers in my electorate know that Skillshare is there. If they want employees, they know they can go to Marrickville Skillshare to get them. There is real access to jobs in the local area, and that cuts down on things such as transportation costs and costs of living.

Marrickville Skillshare is about placing real people in real jobs. Let me give you some examples. The Marrickville community nursery was established under the LEAP program. Forty‐five young people worked on this nursery project, which was aimed at growing plants indigenous to the inner west of Sydney. They went to areas such as the Cooks River, got seedlings, made sure that they were planted. A space was provided courtesy of the assistance of Marrickville Council at the Addison Road Community Centre and at the end of that program the nursery is still up and running. It has been a big success because residents have appreciated its positive environmental impact.

LEAP has a 60 per cent success rate in finding participants full‐time jobs. Young unemployed have also gained employment through learning metalwork skills while assisting in the restoration of the James Craig sailing ship at the Sydney Maritime Museum.

But you do not hear the success stories of the young unemployed fighting hard to achieve employment, gain employment, continuing to look after their families while going on to get increased training and skills. It is a pity that the media concentrate so much on the minority. We saw the very disgraceful representation of the Paxton family, as if the young unemployed were happy about their situation. The overwhelming majority of young people are after training, education, assistance and long‐term real jobs.

One of most outstanding local Skillshare success stories might appear a little odd. It was a project to find employment for agricultural scientists who had been trained overseas. Through Marrickville Skillshare 21 overseas trained specialists—from Bangladesh, India and Thailand—found employment.

Skillshare organised a seminar, held at the Marrickville Council administration centre, to launch the scheme. They invited employers and people from university research institutions and government departments. Out of the scheme came real initiatives and those 21 people who had been trained in Asia actually found jobs in the industry.

The areas in which they found jobs were very diverse. Two of them are teaching at James Ruse Agricultural High School in Parramatta. One of them is working on a wheat farm at Gilgandra. Many of them are working in research institutions attached to universities. Many others are working in the food technology area in private industry, with one employed at Sara Lee. The sort of commitment and dedication to meeting a challenge—people would be aware that the electorate of Grayndler is certainly not an agricultural area—exemplified by Marrickville Skillshare is something that we as a country cannot afford to lose.

The debate about education and training should not be a debate about ideology. It should not be a debate which suggests that the free market will look after employment and that people will find so‐called real jobs if we just get government out of the way. That is just not true.

The government, and in particular the minister, have shown since the election that they do not really have a vision. The minister is bent on criticising our achievements but the criticism is purely ideologically based because we were getting it right. If you have a look across the spectrum of issues, particularly those aimed at young people, you will see why our achievements in education and training are ones I am very proud to be associated with. Three out of 10 people were completing secondary school in 1983 compared with eight out of 10 now. Look at the growth that was occurring in apprenticeships and employment. No amount of gimmickry, of buses travelling around the country, will change the fact that in youth employment creation we also achieved significantly more than the coalition did prior to 1983—and most certainly more than we can expect in the coming months.

If this government pursues its ideological agenda and its breaking down of labour market programs, it is not the Labor Party which will suffer; it is the people in my electorate of Grayndler who need those programs to get themselves into employment and the people of other electorates who will suffer. I hope there is a change of heart and the government resolves its confusion over some of these programs. I hope it gets rid of its ideological blinkers and recognises that creating jobs is something which government does have a role in. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to sum up the bill and conclude the debate. It has been a long and interesting debate, especially given that the bill itself, at least in so far as divisions are concerned, has been uncontentious. I suppose there have been three issues that have been touched on in the course of the debate. The first is the abolition of the training guarantee levy. The second is the provision of further funds to the open learning initiative, and the third is the provision of an additional $20 million for capital grants to non-government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: There is bipartisan support for the abolition of the training guarantee levy. All of us, in a sense, have come here to bury that particular Caesar—except for the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who came not so much to bury Caesar but to praise him. The member for Batman seemed to think the training guarantee levy was a great measure. It was so good that it was dropped by the previous government of which he was such a great supporter! The problem with the training guarantee levy was not the concept or the principle, but the practice. In 1993 the Good Weekend said:
Three years down the track, the act—
that is, the act establishing the training guarantee levy—

has spawned an industry in which absailing down a cliff is called team‐building; in which cosmetics demonstrations are training for receptionists; in which gym membership is written off as a stress management program; and in which the definition of a corporate classroom is a five-star resort with a flying fox.

That was the training guarantee levy that the member for Batman praised so much. In 1992, the tax office released the results of a survey which found that 70 per cent of companies said that the levy had served only to create more administrative work; 63 per cent said that they were spending the same or less on training as a result of the legislation. This is the work of the former Labor government of which they are so proud.

A survey by Monash University's David Syme, Faculty of Business, found that after two years of operation only four per cent of companies had anything positive to say about the training levy; 60 per cent said the levy was not effective or hardly effective; and nine per cent admitted that they had undertaken unnecessary training just to fulfil the requirements. I guess the most outrageous example was that of the New South Wales Employers Federation, which planned a four-day training seminar on a luxury river boat with four-hour lunch breaks and piggyback races in the afternoon. That is the kind of thing that the training guarantee levy created. It is no wonder that members opposite are so anxious to see this embarrassment dead and buried.

There are many labour market programs that both sides of this House could support. Like the member for Batman and members opposite, I, too, have seen labour market programs in action. I have seen the participants. I have seen the new hope, the new joy and the new exuberance on their faces; and, believe me, it warms the cockles of my hard, conservative heart to see it. It is splendid. There are many labour market programs that no-one would want to touch. We do not want, on this side of the House, to eliminate labour market programs; we simply want to make them work better, and they can work better.

As my colleague and leader, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, said, under these programs we have people going in as pool attendants who cannot swim and who are allergic to chlorine. We have, under some jobskill programs, the cost of $76,000 to create a single job. This does not mean all the programs are bad, but it does mean that many of them can be improved.

Members opposite have talked a great deal about cuts. It is interesting, if we are talking about cuts in labour market programs, to see that the 1995-96 budget allocated $2.1 billion for labour market programs. Do you know what happened, Madam Deputy Speaker? Two billion dollars of that money was spent prior to the election; $2 billion of that money was spent trying to buy votes in marginal seats. We have had to borrow $30 million from next year's allocation to keep the existing slate of programs going.

We are all in favour of training. The difference between us and those on the other side of the House is that we are totally committed to on‐the‐job training; whereas, as the rorts associated with the training guarantee levy made clear, those opposite are more committed to off‐the‐job training. Under the regime of the training guarantee levy an employer got no recognition whatsoever for taking on 100 apprentices; but if he sent 100 of his executives to Hayman Island for a week, it was a tax deduction. That was the ridiculous situation that operated under the training guarantee levy. I am not saying that it was a complete failure. I am not even saying that it did more harm than good. What I am saying is that it was not worth all the trouble.

PARA.BREAK: We want people to have faith in government on this side of the House; but we want people to have more faith in themselves. We want to build a better training partnership. We do not want to build a bigger training bureau cracy. We all know—because it happens to all of us every day in our constituencies—that people come to us and say, `I'm desperate; please help.' How can government refuse? It is so very difficult to refuse. But the tragedy is that if we always say yes, not only do we create a government which grows into a monster out of control but also, in the end, we totally destroy the self-respect of those people whom we are trying to help. Last week I went down to a youth conference at Mildura organised by the Sunraysia Area Consultative Committee of the Commonwealth Employment Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I hear the member over there, an excellent member who is well and widely regarded by his constituents. The slightly upsetting thing about all those lovely kids at that seminar was that kid after kid stood up and talked about how someone else had to help them. I agree that we do have to do something for those kids; but not a single one of them used the words of President Kennedy, who said—and they are words worth repeating—`Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country.'

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with our young people and our labour market programs is not so much financial and it is not so much organisational; at the end of the day the problem is cultural. What this government needs to remind people of is that every single person in this country is good at something, that every single Australian can do well at something and that every single Australian should have a dream; but government cannot give it to them. A dream is the gift that each man or each woman gives to himself or herself. This government is determined to give the Australian people a hand up. But what we must do is break the handout mentality that the previous government, often with the best will in the world, did so much to foster.

The former government, now that they are in opposition, are obsessed with money—money that they constantly say we are not spending. But it is important to realise what money cannot do. Money cannot bring about a change of heart, a change of morale, which in the end is the best solution for our unemployment problems. I want to quote from a report to the federal government by the Schools Council. It said:

The Commonwealth government has never had any substantive evidence as to whether the resources which it has put into schools over the past 20 years have been effective in raising educational standards.

That is a very sad situation. There we have the Schools Council telling us that for all our spending we cannot be sure it has actually raised educational standards. The trouble with the union‐dominated approach of members opposite is that they are always telling us that standards are rising when the union members in the schools and the universities are calling for a wage rise, and they are always telling us that standards are falling when they are asking for more money to employ more teachers or academics. The fact is that money is not the answer—a better attitude is. That is something which no amount of money by itself can solve.

We cannot have training for training's sake. I applaud the fact that policies of the previous government helped to raise retention rates from about 30 per cent to about 70 per cent. That is a very significant achievement, and the previous government deserves considerable credit for it. But let's be honest. If those kids leave school to go on the jobless queue, does it really matter whether they leave at year 10 or year 12? I applaud so many of the labour market programs that the previous government put into place. But, if at the end of them there are no jobs for those kids to go to, are we simply raising their expectations only to dash their hopes?

Sadly, notwithstanding so much good work by so many tens of thousands of people—some in the private sector; some in the public sector—at the end of 13 years of Labor government we have so many programs doing so much good work but we also have, at the heart of it, an alphabet soup of muddle. There are something like 80 separate programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. We do not know just how much good most of them are doing. There is a blizzard of acronyms that people must wade through to try to understand exactly what is going on. I want to stress the good work that is being done by the department, by state governments, by local governments and by people in private business—many of whom are giving up hours of their time to help our people. What this government wants to do is ensure that there is a better return for all that good work.

The sad thing about much of this debate is that speakers opposite have been living in the past. They have been trying to defend the record of the previous government. There was some good and some bad in that, but it has gone. It is a government which has gone. This government has hardly begun, yet listening to members opposite you would think that the world as we know it has come to an end. We have not had time for that. The fact is that we are getting on with the job of trying to ensure that the money we put into these programs is getting the result the Australian people deserve.

A few particular points were made by speakers opposite, which I would like to take in turn. Wages policy is one example. The member for Batman, leading off for the opposition, attacked the wages policy of the new government. We all know what the wages policy of the previous government was. The former Prime Minister boasted day after day at the dispatch box that he had kept wages down. That is no answer to the Australian people. Our policy is to allow people to earn the best wages of which they are capable. It is to allow people to strike the best deals they can between themselves and their bosses.

Members opposite, such as the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), talked about university cuts. There have been no university cuts. Let me just refer you to some facts. Here I have Macquarie University announcing today an $8.8 million surplus or profit in 1995. That is not a bad result, and I applaud them for their work. I also have, from one of today's newspapers, North Queensland's James Cook University admitting that it is $20 million in the red. That is no good at all but, notwithstanding that, they say that they could manage a federal funding cut of up to seven per cent. I am not saying there are going to be cuts; I am not saying that at all. What I am saying is that, whatever happens, it is hardly going to be the end of the world as we know it for those universities.

The member for Batman talked a lot about wages policy. I have great hopes for the member for Batman. He is a fine man, but even the previous Prime Minister had a certain basic honesty. The previous Prime Minister knew that the real author of the 1982-83 recession was not John Winston Howard; it was George Campbell. It was George Campbell of the metalworkers union who had those 700,000 unemployed people hanging around his neck. What is the Labor Party doing to George Campbell? They are making him a senator. That is what they are doing. That is how they reward the author of the 1983 recession.

We all know that wages fell under the ALP. We have all heard their claims about an unprecedented explosion of jobs. Yes, there was a great splurge of job creation. The tragedy is that most of it was part time.

I heard the member for Batman attack at the beginning of his speech what he described as coalition plans to amalgamate the department of social services and the Commonwealth Employment Service offices all around Australia. I am sorry the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) is not here to hear this, but the Manly CES office in my electorate is closing down. An announcement, if such be the word, was made just the other day by way of a letter from the CES area manager to local members of parliament. Do you know what it was about, Madam Deputy Speaker? The Public Service made a decision to rationalise that office late last year. They did not give a brief to the then minister because they knew that he would be too embarrassed to make a decision in the run-up to the last election, and the Public Service have closed it down. I do not want to stand up here as some kind of poor man's Bagehot, but that strikes me as a grave dereliction of normal Westminster principles and it is something that needs to be sheeted home to the previous government.

The member for Batman talked about the rich mates of the coalition. That was a bit rich. Obviously, he is just a bit jealous that Bill Kelty never invited him along to Solly Lew's place. The fact is that the member for Batman's contribution, wordy in parts all too often, sounded like an election speech, which no‐one believed even before the election.

The open learning initiative, which is to be supported by this bill, involves a $30 million investment by the Commonwealth. As a result of that money, we have about 9,000 equivalent full-time student places. That is a good value initiative in anyone's language. I am pleased to say that 75 per cent of those students are passing their courses. It is a splendid way of making degrees available to all.

Finally, the capital grants for non-government schools are, I suppose, the latest chapter in a long Australian saga known once upon a time as state aid—something that was first given in this country by the Menzies government. State aid has been a magnificent social development. It has been, if you like, the final solvent in the Anglo-Irish divide which for so long bedevilled our country. In conclusion I would like to say that, if there is more money to be had, it should go on such a good cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, with legislation like this, there should be more members in the House for the second reading vote. I call your attention to the state of the House.

—I like to give my reason.
