SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loan Bill proposes to authorise borrowings to be undertaken and payments to be made from the loan fund to supplement the consolidated revenue fund, if necessary, to use the borrowings to pay for defence related expenditure and to pay the costs of undertaking the borrowings.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the issue of defence related expenditure to which I turn initially in my remarks. I noted yesterday that the government is proposing to spend at least $360 million in relocating the Holsworthy army base near my electorate and, in its place, constructing Sydney's second international airport. I would expect that the estimate, which is some 10 years old, of $360 million worth of expenditure is, in fact, a gross underestimate.

Members, including my colleague the member for Fowler (Mr Grace), would appreciate that in recent times the military has spent a considerable amount of funds at Holsworthy constructing a modern school of military engineering, and new warehousing and logistics facilities. My estimate, rough as it is, on that type of expenditure would be that it would cost at least a billion dollars to relocate the Holsworthy army base from south‐west Sydney. It is quite likely that loan bills would be used at some future time to raise the borrowings to meet that substantial expenditure.

I express my disappointment that these matters were not raised during the election campaign. In the substantial debate in Sydney about aircraft noise and about the future of airports there was no mention of any plan for Holsworthy and no mention of any need to relocate the army base to build Sydney's second international airport. There was a large amount of debate in Sydney about these matters. The coalition produced a substantial policy, but there was not a word, not a whisper, about their plan for Holsworthy.

The electorate of Hughes was keenly contested. The former member, Robert Tickner, lost his seat. To my understanding, the new member for Hughes (Ms Vale) made no mention in her campaign manifesto and material of any need to allocate defence expenditure to move the Holsworthy army camp and to replace it with an international airport. I express my disappointment that just two months after the election there is a plan to this effect, and this Loan Bill will have to cover a substantial amount of defence related expenditure.

Just two months after the election we find that the government has a plan to construct two 5,000 metre north‐south runways and also an east‐west runway. The plan is well summarised in the Sydney Morning Herald of this morning. It outlines the effects, particularly with regard to noise pollution. I note with great concern on behalf of my constituents that the suburb of Ingleburn, with some 10,000 residents, and large parts of Minto, Minto Heights and Macquarie Fields are within the 25 ANEF contour. That is, they will be severely noise affected by the construction of the east‐west runway. In fact, according to the map that has been produced in the newspaper, the east‐west runway points exactly at the suburb of Ingleburn. It is well and truly in the firing line.

It is of great concern that none of these issues or impacts was raised during the election campaign. My opponent in the seat of Werriwa, Mr Thorn, made absolutely no mention of the Liberal Party's intention to build an east‐west runway which would point directly at the 10,000 residents of the suburb of Ingleburn. He made no mention of the fact that that runway would be without a curfew, and that there would be a 24‐hour operation of flights in and out of south‐west Sydney, with a severe impact on lifestyle.

I express my disappointment because I believe in transparency. I believe in parties doing what they promise to do if they win the election. You can understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, how local members in the south‐west of Sydney are severely disappointed with the announcement yesterday. They are disappointed that an airport is to be located next‐door to the south‐west Sydney population corridor. That corridor encompasses some 500,000 residents throughout the south‐west in the arc from Bankstown to Liverpool and Campbelltown local government areas. It is looming as a lifestyle nightmare for them.

I wish it was true that on this bill the government would not require extra defence expenditure funded off loans, that in fact they could maintain the Holsworthy army camp as it has been planned, as it has been envisaged by a number of reports, as the main logistic facility for military purposes in Sydney. It should stay as a defence facility, not an airport. That, of course, would be to the lasting benefit of those 500,000 residents, particularly the families that have just moved into the suburbs of Holsworthy and Wattle Grove. They have moved in in good faith—as part of the defence housing scheme, in fact—to purchase at the lower end of the housing market in Sydney, to settle their families to enjoy a pleasant lifestyle, and now they find this extraordinary prospect of being purchased out. Their properties would need to be acquired for the construction of this airport. Again, in the metropolitan media this morning there are reports of residents saying that their reaction is to sell and move out, their lifestyle and ambitions shattered by this ill‐conceived plan announced yesterday by the Minister for Transport (Mr Sharp).

I would be interested to hear what Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) has got to say about this plan. It overturns the Dibb report, it overturns all the planning that his department has undertaken for many years for the future of Holsworthy and indeed the future of the national grid of defence facilities in this country. I would also be interested to hear what he has got to say about the prospect of the unexploded bombs. The Minister for Transport told the House yesterday that it is possible to defuse the bombs, but I raise the prospect that it is probably not possible to find them. They do not bounce across the artillery range like golf balls on a golf practice range; they implode into the ground. They are grown over, covered with vegetation. There are literally thousands, if not tens of thousands, of unexploded bombs on that army range, and to find them is hard enough, let alone to defuse them.

Beyond that, we know that the terrain is treacherous. It is covered with ravines and gorges that lead into the Georges River. While it is true that the Badgerys Creek airport site is not like a billiard table, is not completely flat, it is relatively flat, supremely flat, compared with the Holsworthy site which is now under active consideration.

BREAK.PARA: So I would plead with the government on this Loan Bill to reconsider this unnecessary defence related expenditure of at least a billion dollars to relocate the army out of Holsworthy. I plead on behalf of constituents of mine in the suburbs of Glenfield, Macquarie Fields, Ingleburn, right throughout the Campbelltown corridor; on behalf of all those people who have moved into the suburbs of Casula and Churchill Gardens and related areas; and of those in the new release suburb of Prestons, which is in my electorate. They will all be affected by this east‐west runway which points directly at them and by the sweep of aircraft which will affect their families and their lifestyle. I would ask the government on this matter to reconsider the cost.

There is no need to proceed with an environmental study. It will merely confirm the findings of the report 10 years ago. In fact, I would expect things have got worse in terms of population growth around Holsworthy. We have seen the new suburb of Wattle Grove. We have seen the redevelopment and population explosion of Holsworthy itself. We have seen the development of housing estates in Casula and throughout Campbelltown. I suspect there has been some medium density infill development to the north of the airport throughout the Bankstown local government area. So, if the reports 10 years ago said that too many people lived too close to the Holsworthy site, that has probably been multiplied now with 30,000 extra residents moving in over the last 10 years.

All these things are well known to the locals and I wish there had been some consultation where the Minister for Transport could have spoken to the local communities, councils, environmentalists and community activists to get their feeling before he announced this plan, a plan that has already upset so many people. It really is a tragedy to see families in the south‐west of Sydney who have established themselves in good faith now leading a stampede to get out because they weren't told about these things prior to the election and they weren't consulted after the election. It is a very sad day for people in the south‐west of Sydney.

I refer to that 1985 report about aircraft needs in Sydney. There was an assessment made of Holsworthy. It pointed to the large and growing cost of relocating the military facilities and it ranked Holsworthy ninth out of 10 options. It classified it as a site with severe liabilities. One of those was the problem of the unexploded bombs. Another was the issue of the ravines and gorges, which would lead to huge landfill costs for the projects. The site preparation and the army relocation at that time were estimated at a combined cost of $800 million. That would since have blown sky‐high because of the additional cost of residential acquisition and the additional facilities that the army has built at Holsworthy in the last 10 years that would now have to be relocated.

So not only would there be the waste of public money in building the facilities and having them moved, but there would be substantial public cost in acquiring sites in other parts of Australia to which they could be moved. This is not good planning; it is not good transport planning; it is not good urban planning, and it is not good lifestyle planning. I think that the advice the Minister for Defence will be getting from his officials is that it is not good defence planning. It is not good for the defence needs and logistical requirements of the nation.

Again, I ask the government to reconsider these things and to note that so many residents—I would estimate at least 10,000 residents just in my electorate—would be within the 25 ANEF corridor. They are going to find a lifestyle similar to that which has been experienced in the suburb of Marrickville just north of the new third runway at Sydney airport. Those sorts of things should not occur without substantial planning and consultation. That has been the lesson at Mascot. Let us not revisit those mistakes in the south‐west of Sydney. There has been substantial population growth and those residents face a whole series of problems.
Let me just quote the 1985 airport assessment on Holsworthy. It said:

Holsworthy has severe weaknesses in terms of airport operations and cost, and its ranking on environmental factors is mixed when compared with the sites in the closer group . . . The use of Holsworthy would create irreconcilable airspace conflict with aircraft movements at Bankstown Airport.

So out of this there are not only the costs of moving the army and building an airport, but of having to close Bankstown airport. Where is it to go in the Sydney basin when the area is already at capacity? The major general aviation and light aircraft movement airport in Sydney is to be closed and relocated; a new site purchased, and a new airport built. It is snowballing into a fiscal nightmare for this government.
The assessment report in 1985 went on to say:

To this extent, selection of the Holsworthy site as a second Sydney airport could be seen to be in conflict with the basic objective of the Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme—to increase runway capacity in the Sydney region.
There is no need to proceed with Holsworthy. The report mentioned that this site had severe liabilities. Let me quote again:

In the analysis of the characteristics of the 10 sites, three sites displayed one or more severe disadvantages in comparison to the other sites. These three sites were Darkes Forest, Goulburn and Holsworthy.

This was not treated 10 years ago as a serious proposition. Why would it be resurrected by the government now when the circumstances have grown much worse in terms of public impact and public cost? There would be public impact on nearly 500,000 residents throughout the south‐west Sydney corridor, and the public cost of the extra army expenditure at Holsworthy in the last decade.

In the ranking of potential sites, Holsworthy came second last. Badgerys Creek was ahead of it, as were Wilton, Bringelly, Londonderry, Scheyville, Warnervale, Somersby and Darkes Forest. The only one that Holsworthy could beat home was Goulburn, and no‐one treats Goulburn as a serious proposition, given its huge distance from the Sydney basin. So you have Holsworthy among the Sydney basin options ranking last, and only getting ahead of Goulburn by virtue of that centre's supreme disadvantage on distance. This is not a proposition which any sensible, caring and fiscally responsible government would entertain.

I repeat my call on behalf of those 500,000 residents. I know that I am joined by the member for Fowler, the Labor candidate for the seat of Blaxland, naturally enough, and the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham). I hope that I am joined by the Liberal Party member for Hughes in saying that this is an ill‐conceived, ill thought out announcement by the government and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development.

I would hope and in fact I ask the honourable member for Hughes through this debate to join us in saying that it should not go ahead. The interests in south‐west Sydney are more important, on such a basic lifestyle question, than are party politics. She has been elected without a mandate for this project. She would know that every single resident in east Liverpool, from Moorebank, Chipping Norton, Hammondville, Holsworthy and Wattle Grove, would be dead‐set opposed to this idea of an international airport on their doorstep. She should join with us in saying that it is a bad idea, and use her lobbying capacity within the federal government to change the mind of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development.

Beyond that issue, on this legislation, I note that the bill seeks to finance the 1996‐97 budget and, as such, it is directly relevant to the fiscal position of the Commonwealth in speculation about the underlying fiscal deficit for 1996‐97. In this regard, talk of a budget black hole is simply an attempt by the coalition to construct an alibi, to manufacture a crisis for party political reasons. They are seeking to construct an alibi to manufacture a crisis on this issue for two basic reasons. First, they wish to break the promises that they had no intention of keeping. The coalition made promises at the last campaign that were made only to be broken and now they seek a reason, an alibi, to manufacture a crisis by which the breach of those promises might be judged acceptable to the Australian public. It reflects on a basic contradiction in the philosophy and political intent of the coalition.

We all know that the things that the conservative side of politics in Australia believes in are called Fightback. That was clear at the 1993 election. Dr Hewson thought he could not lose it so he put forward the things that his side of politics strongly believed in and they were called Fightback. But of course Fightback was not acceptable to the Australian people. So, for the 1996 election, for a narrow cynical electoral reason, the coalition put forward different policies—policies that they do not really believe in, and policies that they wish to junk now that they have won the election.

It is often said that, and I think it is true, the coalition won the last election on the basis of Labor strategies. They adopted all the Labor policies. It was quite remarkable that even on Medicare they were advertising—as if it was their own initiative—that Medicare was going to be maintained and that bulk‐billing would be maintained. The coalition needed to find an alibi. They needed to manufacture a crisis and that is the political use to which they are putting this bogus argument about a black hole.

It also reflects, of course, that the coalition have no answers of their own. Smaller government has been tried in various parts of the world and it has failed. The only answer is better government. Winding back the welfare state is not a legitimate response to questions of economic and social insecurity arising out of globalisation. In other parts of the world they have tried the competitive advantage paradigm. All the micro‐reform and competition policy under the sun will not produce full employment in Australia. There are structural imbalances in the labour market and in the regions of the nation that necessitate an active role for government on both the supply and demand side of the labour market.

We saw in Australia, in the late 1980s, the use of the twin deficits theory; the belief that a lower federal deficit produces a reduction in the current account deficit. It did not hold true. It did not hold true in the late 1980s and it is unlikely to hold true in the mid‐1990s now that it is being tried by Treasurer Costello. We have seen in other parts of the world, indeed some of the state governments in Australia, a supply side fetish—that is, blind to one side of the economy, the demand side, and focussing only on the supply side. Again, that is a basic imbalance in the way in which good reformers, good policy makers would run an internationalised economy.

So with all these areas—smaller government, winding back the welfare state, the twin deficits theory, the competitive advantage paradigm and the supply side fetish—the policies are not only wrong but they have been tried elsewhere and have been shown to have failed. The policy is not only wrong in theory but in practice. Other parts of the world, and some parts of Australia, have tried these remedies and they have failed, failed fundamentally. I would urge the coalition not to carry on with talk of a budget black hole but to construct answers to relevant issues, to questions of globalisation, economic insecurity and social insecurity, and not to fall back on things that have been tried in the United Kingdom, the United States and Western Europe over the last 10 years and have basically failed.

The allegation of a black hole is a weak alibi. In fact, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) gave himself away when he put his hands up and confessed on the Sunday program on 12 May. Laurie Oakes asked him this basic question: `If Treasury revises growth forecasts again, will you change your $8 billion target in the budget?' This is what the Treasurer had to say: `Yes, I just wanted to make that point, the black hole was the non‐disclosure.' A non‐disclosure, that was the point. What can we tell from this stunning confession? We can tell two things. If Treasury changes its forecast, the allegation dissolves. If they revise their growth forecast upwards, the Treasurer no longer has an $8 billion target. He was asked that and he said yes.

If they change their figures, if the economy is forecast to grow stronger and there is a flow‐on positive impact on the budget, his $8 billion target dissolves. He said he would change the target. If he changes the target, the allegation dissolves. It just makes the point that this is a forecasting exercise. The coalition is not talking about things that are happening in May 1996. None of these budget issues are happening now. They are forecasts about what may or may not happen in the fiscal framework, the fiscal outcomes between July 1996 and June 1997. It is a forecasting exercise. They are not talking about present circumstances.
You only need to read the detail of the Treasurer's press release on 12 March to appreciate that. This is what it said in the detail and the truth:
. . . nevertheless, the database for 1996‐97 estimates is entirely forecast and hence subject to substantial revision.

So he not only gave himself away on the Sunday program, but in the detail of his own press release he is saying that the estimates are entirely projected and hence subject to substantial revision. The best summary of this was made by BZW, the merchant bankers, in their bulletin on 22 March. This is what they had to say:

Everything to do with budget numbers is slightly suspect so beware of some tricks. Most of the deterioration in the budget outlook reflects changed economic assumptions. The headline budget balance for 1996‐97 was revised from a $3.4 billion surplus to a $4.9 billion deficit but only $446 million of this was accounted for by policy decisions. In other words, most of the problem could disappear as quickly as it appeared if the economic forecasts are revised.

Don't just take my word on that question of the accuracy of forecasts. Take no less an authority than the Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). This is what he had to say in the April 1984 issue of Quadrant magazine:
The problem with long‐term projections is that very often they turn out to be incorrect.

How true! The long‐term projections about what might happen in the fiscal outcomes up to July 1997 could turn out to be incorrect. So there he is—damned, exposed. He has blown his alibi with his own words.

We all know that if the economy grows, or if it is forecast to grow, by just half a per cent of GDP, there is an impact—a fiscal bonus—of nearly a billion dollars from that change in forecasting. And, indeed, the policy changes of the former government account for less than half a billion dollars of this alleged $8 billion black hole. Less than one‐sixteenth of the allegation actually relates to policy changes. The entire remainder of the allegation relates to parameter changes in the forecast—and we know how quickly economic circumstances change in an open economy. From day to day, week to week, month to month, these circumstances change and the Treasury takes account of them.

The Treasurer wants us to believe that after he was elected on 2 March within 48 hours he had a new set of forecasts and that on 4 March the world had changed. That is when he found out about the new budget figures and the new growth forecasts that were producing 90 per cent of the fiscal parameter changes.

There was an instance just recently of how the government's own policy is changing the parameters. The mere act of contracting the budget knocks half a per cent off GDP. Knocking half a per cent of growth off the economy has the impact of blowing out government outlays and tightening revenue. It is like a dog chasing its own tail: they are contracting the economy, which reduces the forecasts for growth in 1996‐97, and they need to respond to that by tightening their fiscal policy even further. This is the Keynesian framework of a dog chasing its own tail. It just underlines the point that this is a forecasting exercise, unrelated to what is happening now and in the past. Less than one‐sixteenth of this allegation relates to actual policy changes and spending decisions of the former government.

The second thing we can tell from that confession by the Treasurer on the Sunday program is that, in his opinion, `it is an issue of non‐disclosure', that is, it is not an issue of fiscal legacy, it is about the disclosure. It is a problem of not what he found when he became Treasurer but when he found it. It is not a fiscal issue related to the actual dimension of the budget but it is a non‐disclosure issue: it is not the substance of what he found on 4 March but the fact that he found it after the election. That seems to be what he regards as the essence of the so‐called black hole.

Of course, this reveals the Treasurer of Australia as the Gomer Pyle of Australian politics. He has walked into the Treasurer's office and it is surprise, surprise, surprise: the economy has slowed and the fiscal position has weakened. Why should he be saying surprise, surprise, surprise when for 18 months every public and private forecaster in the nation has been saying that growth was slowing and that would have a weakening effect on the Commonwealth budget?

Of course, we all remember the member for Bennelong, then the Leader of the Opposition, during the election campaign talking about the prospect of a negative growth quarter for December 1995. When the figures were announced, he was saying, `This could be a negative growth quarter'. The Prime Minister, who was then the Leader of the Opposition, was acknowledging that the economy was slowing. In fact, the Treasurer said it himself in November when Access Economics—his shadow Treasury—had given him advice that the economy was slowing to a point where the budget would be substantially weakened.

During the election campaign, we had Two Neurone Tim, the Deputy Prime Minister, saying that the fiscal position had weakened. We had Jeff Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, blowing the whistle—at a very inopportune time in the federal campaign—on what was likely to be the budgetary position. DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND ABOLITION) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is identical to that which was presented by the former government and passed by the House on 24 October 1995. That bill lapsed in the Senate due to the election. The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established over 30 years ago to overcome a structural deficiency in the highly regulated financial system. Its main purpose was to assist low income earners with small deposits to obtain housing finance. It did this by insuring lenders against the cost of mortgage defaults. Since then, other insurers have entered the mortgage insurance market, thereby reducing the necessity to maintain the corporation in public ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the former government decided to transfer the corporation to the private sector. The transfer process itself has been difficult due to the lack of competitive neutrality of the regulations under which the corporation has operated. The corporation's liabilities are guaranteed by the Commonwealth, giving it an advantage over the other participants in the market. In addition, the corporation was exempt from supervision by the industry regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Consequently, it did not have to comply with the capital adequacy arrangements applying to its competitors.

To overcome these problems, the former government decided to abandon the privatisation option but to restructure the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation along the following lines. Firstly, the corporation will be re‐established as a company incorporated under the companies law and subject to the regulations of the ISC, as well as those of the states and territories. The new company will be fully capitalised in line with the requirements of the ISC, drawing on part of the present capital and reserves. The Commonwealth guarantee on borrowings for the new company will be removed. However, traditional arrangements will be implemented to allay uncertainty arising from the restructuring and to ensure that the new company attains the appropriate credit rating required by state legislation without the need for further capital injections. The corporation will cease writing business on the day before the new company comes into existence. The then existing insurance policies, the so‐called old book, will be directly taken over by the Commonwealth and the balance of the corporation's capital and reserves in excess of $100 million will be paid to consolidated revenue. Finally, the Commonwealth will then contract with the new company to administer the old book insurance obligations, with the Commonwealth making any payments arising from this old business.

These arrangements will considerably improve the competitive neutrality of the mortgage insurance market, continuing the strong record of the former government in achievements in the competition policy area. To achieve this restructuring, the bill proposes to allow the Treasurer to transfer the assets and liabilities of the corporation and to enter into any agreement with the new company to make provision for the payment of claims that may arise. The transfer of staff from the corporation to the new company will be achieved with the maintenance of the existing conditions and entitlements such as leave entitlements, superannuation and workers compensation.

Finally, the bill proposes the winding‐up of the corporation and the repeal of now redundant legislation associated with the corporation. The bill, by my assessment, represents good policy which simultaneously improves the competitive neutrality in the mortgage insurance market, in itself an important reform, and improves Commonwealth finances by around $100 million. It maintains the conditions and entitlements of staff, thereby guaranteeing industrial harmony during the industry restructuring process, and lessens the contingent liabilities of the Commonwealth into the future—another good, shining example of the sound financial management of the former Labor government.

The bill represents good economic management. Labor is proud of what it achieved in government across the board. We introduced this legislation and, naturally enough, we find no reason to oppose it at this point of the parliamentary cycle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews, Kevin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) pointed out in his remarks on the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1996, this was a piece of legislation which was introduced by the previous government in the previous parliament and was not opposed when the bill passed through the House of Representatives on that occasion by the then opposition, now government. Accordingly, the bill has been reintroduced, and one would expect that the opposition would not oppose it on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established in 1965 to insure lenders against losses arising out of the making of loans for housing. The original bill authorised the corporation to put into effect the then government's promised housing loans insurance scheme and empowered the corporation to insure loans made for the erection of homes, the purchase of existing homes, additions to homes, the repair and improvement of homes and the discharge and refinancing of existing mortgages on homes.

The main purpose of that scheme, which is now 30 years in duration, was to assist people to obtain as a single loan and at a reasonable rate of interest the money they needed and could afford to borrow to buy or build a home. As the amount borrowed may at times have been a high proportion of the value of a house and land, there was a risk that the lender might lose some of the capital and might not receive all the interest due. The offer by the corporation to insure against the risk of loss due to failure to recover the amount outstanding on the loan, together with accrued interest, enabled lenders to protect themselves against such losses.
As the then Minister for Housing, Mr Bury, said when introducing the legislation and the scheme:

BREAK.PARA: The scheme aims to assist people to borrow, by means of a single loan secured by a first mortgage, the difference between available personal savings and the cost of a home suited to their requirements. The amount of the loan would, of course, be related to the ability of the borrower to repay it over a reasonable period. It is our hope and intention that this scheme will progressively remove the present need for many creditworthy borrowers to obtain a second mortgage loan, frequently on oppressive terms and conditions.

It is quite clear that this scheme, which was introduced by the Menzies government in 1965, was one which was aimed, at the time, at improving the opportunity for home ownership of ordinary Australians. Many working‐class and middle‐class Australians who would have had difficulty in raising finance in those years without having to obtain a second mortgage, were able to afford homes as a consequence of this scheme, which has worked successfully since its introduction.

It is the issue of the affordability of homes that I want to address briefly today. It is also clear that the corporation has been successful. In fact, it became a clear leader in the mortgage insurance market and it is responsible for close to half the estimated $130 million in premiums written each year.

In the second reading speech when this bill was introduced by the former government last year, the then Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, said that prevailing conditions in the mortgage, insurance and finance industries now differed considerably from those when the corporation was set up in the mid‐1960s. In the home market, the number of people falling behind in their payments over the last few months of 1995 has leapt by some 37 per cent. Over the period of most of 1995 the number of home repossessions in Australia actually increased by 20 per cent—a situation which is very relevant to the terms of this bill.

It is interesting to look back on the original bills and the debates that occurred in 1965 when this bill was introduced. It may be of interest to the current member for Werriwa that one of his predecessors, Mr Gough Whitlam—later to become Prime Minister—made reference to housing affordability when this bill was introduced. In his speech he said that if a person wished to buy a house for £5,000, which he indicated was the average price for a house and land then, it would have required a weekly income in those days of £31 to be able to afford that house.

If one then compares housing affordability between 1975 and 1995 and looks at the report of the Urban Development Council, a report which was endorsed last year by the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, then there are figures in there that relate to the affordability of housing in this country. For example, that document says that in 1975 the median price for a first home in Australia was $25,500. In order to be able to meet a loan on the median house priced at $25,500 in 1975, an annual income of $9,955 was required. That was calculated taking an interest rate of 10 per cent over a 25‐year loan.

If one goes forward 20 years to 1995, then the median price for a first home was $137,900: an increase from $25,500 in 1975 to $137,900 in 1995. In 1975, to meet the repayments on such a loan required an annual income of $9,955. By 1995, in order to meet the repayments on a median home in Australia—we are not talking about something at the top end of housing affordability in this country—according to the council an annual income of $60,184 was required.
If one considers the average level of income in this country, then it is far below $60,184. In addition, there are all the other living expenses that are involved in maintaining a house and family.

So what we have seen over the 20‐year period from 1975 to 1995 is this huge increase in the amount which a person or family requires in order to be able to make the repayments on a median priced house in this country—namely, from an amount of $9,955 in 1975, to $60,184 in 1995.

The huge increase in those figures is borne out in a number of factors which I will come to, and which, I believe, ought to be of concern to all honourable members and senators in this parliament. Indeed, it ought to be of concern to all the people of Australia.

First, we are told by the Housing Industry Association that it expects a continuation of a slowdown in housing over the remainder of this decade. The association predicts, for example, that spending on new dwellings will fall from an annual average of $13.6 billion in 1990‐1995, to $11.1 billion between 1995 and the year 2000. And if one then looks in terms of what is happening with household incomes, one can see that there are huge changes occurring in Australian society.

For example, the business commentator, Phil Ruthven, has pointed out recently that the proportion of households with incomes of more than $72,000 had risen from 15 per cent in 1976 to 30 per cent in 1992. There has been a doubling of the proportion of those households with incomes in excess of $72,000.

On the other hand, the proportion of households with an annual income below $22,000 had also increased from 20 per cent in 1976 to 30 per cent in 1992. So we have an increase in the number of households in Australia at the top end, with an annual income of over $72,000—in fact a doubling of the proportion. We also have an increase at the bottom end, where the household annual income is less than $22,000, an increase from 20 to 30 per cent of households. And of course, as commonsense and the ordinary experience of Australians indicate, for those in the middle there has been a continuing squeeze over the last 20 years. Whereas previously, there were 65 per cent of households in this middle‐income range, between $22,000 and $72,000, we find today that that has now been reduced to 40 per cent.

So when ordinary Australians talk about the squeeze on middle Australia, the so‐called middle class, if one looks at these figures one can see that borne out in terms of the household income. That is a concern, and of course it relates to housing affordability which is significantly related to the subject matter of this bill.

There are other statistics which bear out a similar story. If we take the research undertaken by Professor Bob Gregory and Mr Boyd Hunter at the Australian National University's Centre for Economic Policy Research, we find that there has been a significant increase in the geographic polarisation of household incomes across Australia. Their research, which was released last year, found that in the top five per cent of areas ranked according to their socioeconomic status, household income increased by $12,555—that is an increase of 23 per cent between 1976 and 1991—when measured in constant 1995 prices.

Yet in the lowest five per cent of areas, household income fell by $7,589. That is also 23 per cent but in this case it is a decline over the same period. So for the top five per cent of households according to this study there has been an increase in income of 23 per cent over that period of time, yet for the bottom five per cent of households in this country there has been a decrease in income by 23 per cent. Again, these figures support what Mr Ruthven had shown in his studies—that there is a widening gap between the rich and the poor in Australia.

In 1976, the weekly income gap between the average household income in the bottom one per cent of census collector districts and the average household income in the median census collector districts was not very large. A census collector district is a small area of 200 or 300 houses. So we are talking about an area of a few blocks, less than the size of a suburb. We can actually define small areas of suburbs right throughout Australia by reference to census collector districts. In 1976, an additional part‐time job, for nine hours a week at $12 an hour, could have closed the gap. Yet, by 1991, it required not nine hours a week of additional income—for example, a part‐time job—but, in fact, 19 hours a week to close that gap. That is evidence from yet another study showing that the gap between those who are well off and those who are less well off in this country has been increasing over the last 20 years.

If one looks at the other end of the scale—that is, the gap between the median census collector districts and the top one per cent—one sees a widening of that gap as well. In 1976, it required an additional weekly income of $442 to close the gap, which is a considerable amount of money. Yet, by 1991, the amount needed to close that gap had risen to $885. So again one can see the stretching out of the gap between the those on the middle level and those on the highest levels of income. In fact, in 1991 it required, in annual terms, $44,489 to bridge the gap between the middle and the top one per cent. So we see an increase in the gap between the middle and the top levels and we see an increase in the gap at the other end, between the middle and the bottom levels. Again, that study points to the fact that housing affordability for many Australians is something that has become increasingly precarious in this country over the last couple of decades.

As the social commentator and researcher Jeanne Strachan pointed out last year—and I think this is a matter which all honourable members should be aware of and something which ought to concern us in terms of the future of this country—

Young couples today are the first generation since the war to face the reality that they often can't obtain, even with two full‐time workers in the house, what their own parents saw as fair and reasonable reward for their hard work.

What she is hearing from hundreds and possibly thousands of focus groups which she and her associates have conducted across the country is young people saying that today, to be able achieve what their parents regarded as fair and reasonable—that is, essentially, to be able to buy a house and to pay it off—even with two full‐time incomes, is becoming increasingly difficult.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is my belief that it is the intention of all members of parliament ideally to be able, through their efforts, to, in some way, contribute to making this country a better place. I think that these sorts of trends which are occurring ought to concern us all. It, therefore, gets back to questions about the essential and fundamental problems with the Australian economy which have developed over the last 20 years and our need to be able to address them. We need to be able to address them if we are going to hand on to the next generation of Australians a country in a state at least equal to, if not better than, that in which it has been handed on to us. But all the trends are increasingly suggesting that, in fact, the state of the country, as it has been developing over the last two decades, is going in the opposite direction, and that is a major challenge for government.

I do not wish to add any more to that. This bill has given me an opportunity to say something about those trends and to place them on the record of this committee. If they continue, it is not just the question of housing affordability and the economic problems that arise from that—and they are manifold—it is also the social and personal trauma that flows from these sorts of trends in this country. Therefore, if we are looking ahead to the next century and asking what sort of country we are going to hand on to the next generation of Australians, then it is incumbent upon us to try to address the fundamental problems of this economy.

If this bill can make the corporation more competitive, if in some small way it is able to return some amount of money to the government—which it will—from the reserves that are there and therefore deal with some of the deficit and the debt that this country has, then that is one small step towards actually dealing with the problem that we have at the present time. I, with other members, commend the bill.

Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister)(11.26 a.m.)—in reply—I would like to thank the members who have participated in the debate. It has been a very bipartisan debate because the bill was introduced by the previous government and is now being picked up by the Howard government. The details of that bill have been adequately covered by the previous two speakers here this morning. I would like to pick up on the opportunity, which the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) took, to expand a little on the importance of housing and families in Australia. The affordability of owning a home is a very important issue.

When this was first introduced under the Menzies government, Menzies had a concern for families and home ownership. As a government today, we are concerned about the same things. The debate here today has been a bipartisan one, one in which there is a sense of people working together for the benefit of Australians. I do not want to delay the time of discussion any further except to say thank you to those people again for their contribution and particularly to note the extra information which the member for Menzies provided to the House. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another bill that the previous government had prepared for introduction, so it is of no surprise that we have consensus across the parliament for the process of this legislation. It seems to be this little hiatus of pleasurable relations that come not long after the changeover.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to reiterate some of the points that we had in mind, and then make a couple of observations, particularly for my good friend the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who will pick up on this now that he sits on that side of the House, I am sure.

One is a basic proposal. This is an omnibus bill and it has a proposal to ensure that, when there are changes in either the research data or the physical structure—through erosion, or whatever—of the marine boundaries around Australia, the exploration licences that have been granted to the mining and resources industry may lose their validity because of those structural changes in the geography. Or, as in the case of the waters off Western Australia, we have areas where the data is so old—it is 19th century marine data—that now, with modern technology, we are actually changing the boundaries and the maps, so some of these licences may no longer be valid. This legislation ensures that those licences remain in place.

There is a bill to change the arrangements in the poultry industry, which Michael Lee, our shadow spokesman in the health area, is going to speak about as well. The changes represent an advance in the arrangements for the industry, particularly in making provision for an extra contribution to research and development, which is something all of us would encourage for product development and better marketing of the product.

There is a very interesting step forward—I guess we would call it that—in relation to Wool International, in that the bill provides for the wool tax to be modified from 5.5 per cent down through 4.5 per cent to zero. That reflects the fact that the industry has come through the crisis of the mid‐1980s, with the stockpile, the collapse of prices that occurred at that time, the oversupply in the industry and all the things which we all worked our way through. I note that such problems are around again. That is just the cycle of the market for this product, but the industry is now better equipped to deal with it.

I note with some passing interest that the government has seen fit not to change the provision we made that would prevent cashed‐up wool growers from buying up greater equity in the stockpile by making additional contributions. The purpose of the provision was to ensure that well‐off producers would not be able to increase, at the expense of other eligible wool taxpayers, either their equity in a privatised Wool International or their share of the distribution of grower funds derived from wool stockpile sales.

Taken down to its bare bones, you would say that that is the social equity objective. I am not in the least surprised that those on the other side who represent primary producers—who have always, we have felt, subscribed to a policy of agrarian socialism—have seen fit to leave intact that provision. But it does represent, I guess, the final steps in a massive transition for the wool industry, which has been around for almost 200 years and which has developed a heavy reliance on government management and support. It is now in that final stage of weaning itself and being like any other private sector industry: responding to market changes, to the need for product development and, very fortunately, to opportunities which now exist in Australia for downstream processing and value adding. A lot of that investment has taken place in the last five years.

Five, six or seven years ago, farmers told us that they would not consider selling their wool to local manufacturers under any circumstances. Instead they railed about the need for reform on the waterfront in order to get their products exported offshore. At the same time, they railed against Australians who were not buying Australian made products, such as other primary products. Those farmers and primary producers now have opportunities to supply a domestic market. It is not a big domestic market yet, but life has been breathed back into value adding in Australia. Therefore, there is the opportunity to supply a domestic market which can turn it into a product and sell it both as import replacement and export development. This is something that was not there before and I am sure it is well regarded by all as a factor in easing our reliance on, and in weaning ourselves off being completely dependent on, the performance of overseas buyers and their commercial ethics. At various times overseas buyers have, if not held to ransom these industries, at least placed our producers at a severe disadvantage by a whole range of buying techniques.

BREAK.PARA: The change of government gives an opportunity for many of us on this side of the House to reflect on the efforts of the past, on the task of the new government in this field, and on our task in opposition as we watch these developments. I reflect on the many days and nights we traipsed around Australia on the Prime Minister's country task force. I reflect on all those meetings with primary producers who thought the world was coming to an end as they were forced to face changed international market conditions as a Labor government went about internationalising the Australian economy. It did not matter whether they were sugar growers, wool growers, wheat growers, beef producers, meat producers or cut flower producers. They were being weaned off a situation where a central body bought whatever was supplied at a price that was sufficient to sustain the industry domestically. In many cases, this product was sold offshore with taxpayer assistance—often at a loss. It did not make a lot of sense but it was comfortable for primary producers.

I remember coming into parliament one night around 1985 and the minister at the time, John Kerin, said that we would be there until 4 o'clock in the morning. This was very common then; there were about 300 primary industry bills. There was this levy and that levy, this management fee and whatever else. There were all these arrangements throughout the industry as the government tried to prop up what at that time was Australia's major export industry in all its various facets. That is what we inherited. That was the way the conservatives in those days managed primary industry and especially the export task.

As these things were refined and culled and as people became aware of alternative ways of doing business, Australia has modernised. I have said publicly on many occasions that I think primary producers in Australia have been among the fastest to learn and to respond to these changed conditions whether in my own electorate or in other parts of Australia. We have seen people, when exposed fully to the operations of international markets, change their ways of doing business, change the nature of their investment in their assets and, through the whole process, become very responsive to changed opportunities, not the least being the new opportunities which Labor opened up, particularly with our near neighbours.

I am sure my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Holding) will enjoy this story. I remember going to a meeting with dairy producers in the early 1980s. They told me that there were no prospects in Asian markets because the people did not like milk; it was against their religion to drink milk that came from sacred cows. It is okay to laugh, Mr Deputy Speaker. Only 10 years ago, this was serious debate, put to us until midnight at countless meetings in countless areas.

At the same time, the CSIRO had come to the conclusion that the real problem was lactose in the milk and that if you changed the product a bit and removed the lactose you would, perhaps, have a new market. In fact, the CSIRO took out a patent for a machine to do that, and it was produced, but no‐one in Australia was interested in investing in it. The patent was taken up offshore and an offshore manufacturer began producing these machines that Australian dairy producers began buying, and now they have markets all over Asia with lactose‐free milk.

So, piece by piece, it has been an education process. It has been one very much of opening up opportunities. It has been one of tough times, from our point of view, having to make changes that people did not understand and did not like, and taking them through. But the whole point of what I am saying here, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that what the new government inherits in primary industries and energy is a vastly different scene from that of 10 years ago. It is now an industry that is responsive to the problems that ministers confront relating to them; it is an industry that is now prepared to accept, without dissent, changes such as this. The task now is very much one of managing well a completely new internationalised structure that has been put in place.

Everybody's turn comes around the circle, and our turn will come around the circle again—sooner rather than later, I hope. All I ask is that you manage well what we have presented to you, after the dramas we have gone through over these 13 years. Do it well, manage it well, and do not let us have to revisit this whole task when we come to it again. I am happy to support the legislation, Mr Deputy Speaker. We do not have any problems with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to some of the comments from the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). I must say that it was very interesting when he started to talk about the fact that he had had time to reflect. I think he will need a little bit more time—in fact, quite a lot of time—to reflect on some of the very serious failures of the Labor government. But we are debating here today the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, and I would like to concentrate my comments particularly on the wool industry. In so doing, I will first declare an interest. I am a wool grower and I am also very proud to represent one of the premier wool‐growing areas of Australia. I have to say that the last five years, probably with the exception of one year, have been the worst years the wool industry has faced this century.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to come back to that because the member for Burke was talking about the fact that, under the Labor Party, wool growers over recent years have had a heavy reliance on government management and support. I am not sure that there was a lot of support there; I think it was mainly growers being taxed to support themselves. I think the fact that he talked about reliance on government management really does leave the Labor opposition wide open to someone's memory going back a little bit more than just five years to some of the things that the previous government has done. If we look at the origins of the crisis that the wool industry has faced over the last five years we find that the previous government has much to answer for.

This crisis, I might add, is not just impacting on wool growers; we are seeing a very serious impact on their families and on the country towns. It really is quite sad to go into many country towns these days and see what has happened because of the decline in the fortunes of wool growers and the associated industries, which are very significant in country areas and all of which have suffered greatly. The problems that are being faced today obviously go much further than just what is being seen. There has been a very serious lack of reinvestment in many parts of the industry and in local communities. One of the saddest parts about it is that many young people have left the towns and the communities, probably never to return. I think Labor really does have to answer many very serious questions about what has happened.

I would like to go back to 1987—a bit further than the member for Burke would care to—and the wool marketing legislation that was brought in by the then minister for primary industries and member for Werriwa, Mr John Kerin. I think that represents the turning point for the whole floor price scheme; it represents the time when, through a very serious mistake in legislation, the government—maybe not wittingly, but nonetheless—made changes which have turned out to set in place events that subsequently have caused such enormous heartache and financial difficulties and have seen an industry literally brought to its knees.

BREAK.PARA: I am talking about the government changes to the wool marketing legislation that allowed the floor price to be pushed up to 870c. The former minister has to accept responsibility for that decision—he had the opportunity to stop that increase at the time and he did not; he chose not to. We subsequently saw the massive growth of the stockpile and the cash reserves of the then Australian Wool Corporation fall from $1.8 billion to a debt that ultimately exceeded $2½ billion—a massive loss of capital and increase in debt.

Then we saw the minister step in and say, `Well, obviously the 870c is unsustainable. I will cut it to 700c.' When he did this, he gave an ironclad guarantee that that was as low as the price would go and the next time the price was changed it would go up. He travelled around the world and used the words, `This is an ironclad guarantee. We will not reduce it again.' It only took seven months for that ironclad guarantee to be broken. Not only did that lead to a massive loss of confidence in the wool industry but it also led to buyers of wool who had already bought some stocks losing tens of millions of dollars. In fact, one major consumer of Australian wool claims to have lost more than $50 million as a result of that one decision by the then minister.

Is it little wonder that the confidence of the consumers of wool was shattered, that the confidence of the growers of wool was likewise shattered, and that those who have continued to grow wool, either because they believed in wool or, in many cases, because they had little alternative, have suffered mightily because of what the government has done? So when the member for Burke talks about more recent events and a heavy reliance on government management and support, I do not think that management was too good in the past. One could argue about whether or not the more recent management was anything more than a face‐saving exercise for what would have to be one of the worst decisions of this century in agricultural marketing terms—a decision that was taken by a member of his government.

One could go on about the performance of the former government but a couple of other things stand out. One is that when legislation on wool was being debated, more often than not it was being debated under a guillotine, which I think showed the level of importance that the Labor party placed on wool. The final insult, in terms of taking cheap political points from the whole thing, was when this decision to remove the wool tax—the 4½ per cent from 1 July this coming year—was announced, it was announced right in the middle of the election campaign because the government of the day thought it could gain some political kudos. Well, as events have subsequently shown, that did not work.

The task is now very much ahead of the new government and I would like to look at a couple of points in this legislation. In his second reading speech, the minister made a very sensible statement when he said:

The government believes that the industry's long term future lies in it continuing to move towards a market driven approach, closely attuned to the needs of customers and end users and free from unnecessary government involvement.
I think those words are indeed very appropriate and they show very much what the approach of the new government will be.

I have mentioned the question of the removal of the wool tax. As the second reading speech points out, this will be done in such a way that the 4½ per cent tax will enable a setting of the wool tax payable to Wool International by regulation; by doing this, in turn, it can then be set to zero.

Next I would like to touch on the marketing activities of Wool International. This is a very interesting approach, which is somewhat different from the approach that had been proposed by the previous government. The then minister, it would appear, was willing to give Wool International the opportunity to take up to $24 million of what effectively was wool growers' funds to operate in a futures market, or in setting up a system to allow wool growers to try and look at ways and means of hedging against future price variations.

It is important to note that the changes to what was proposed by the previous government are, firstly, that Wool International will require the prior approval of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy before it can commence trading in this program through Wool International Holdings. Furthermore, it is important to note that this approval will be tabled and its making advised in the government Gazette, so either house of parliament will be able, during a period of three sitting days, to disallow this approval. Furthermore, the provision will be subject to a sunset clause so that if approval has not been given by the minister by 1 July 1997 the provision will no longer have effect.

That is very important to note. The parliament has a responsibility to ensure that a statutory body such as Wool International, even through one of its subsidiaries, is not able to go off willy‐nilly and start speculating in the market on the whole question of futures and options and anything else it may see that could be of some assistance to wool growers. As we all know, this speculation is high risk and I believe that there is a duty to ensure that wool growers' funds are properly and responsibly accounted for.

I would like to get back to a couple of things about the wool industry itself. It has been quite encouraging to see that at long last, after some very serious falls in the price of wool over the last few months, there has been a gain in all categories in the last week, particularly at the fine wool end. I believe that if we are going to see a recovery in wool prices it will be led by the fine wool end.

However, I do not think these gains to date are really anything to get too carried away with. For 23 micron wools and stronger we are really only seeing their prices make up for the losses in prices since Easter. To put it in perspective, 21 and 22 micron wools are back to January levels and finer wools are back to the levels of September last year, well below what the market was a year ago and well below the long‐term average—I might add, for the vast majority of growers, also well below the cost of production.

Before I conclude I would like to say something about where I see some of the future directions for the wool industry heading and the areas that have to be looked at. I believe the new government does have a very big task ahead of it in assisting wool growers to rebuild their industry, and it may well be that there is an opportunity for some outside work to be done. The whole question of how the wool chain operates and how some of the statutory bodies themselves operate needs to be looked at. In particular, the whole question of the way the promotion of wool has been carried out—notwithstanding that there are many changes—could be looked at. The way the International Wool Secretariat operates could very well be assisted by some views from those outside the organisation.

I think the second area that the wool industry has to look at very seriously is the level of skills amongst the growers themselves. While there are some very notable achievements being made, overall there is still a lot of work to be done to assist growers to upgrade their skills both in production and in marketing. Clearly, as we go into the second half of the 1990s, those skills are going to be absolutely essential for growers who are going to stay in the industry and succeed.

The minister's comments about reducing the role of government are timely. It is obviously very important that the more government can get out of the wool industry the better. I recognise that if you are going to have statutory levies to work where there is a market failure for research or, indeed, promotion then government probably will have some role.

The other area that does need addressing by the industry is the question of the quality of the product. I think the wool industry has in the past developed a very high quality product, which really makes it something very special. I have some concerns that in recent years there has been a tendency, in some sectors of the industry at least, to blend down the quality of the better parts of the clip instead of promoting the better parts as a specialty product and not something that can be just blended into the lesser qualities to make more of an average type product.

In supporting the moves by the government, I put those qualifications particularly on the operations of Wool International Holdings and I believe that is something we have to watch very closely. I believe that the industry will turn itself around. I believe that demand will improve as this year progresses and, indeed, as the subsequent year comes along. I find it somewhat curious that there is talk of increasing the level of promotion and at the same time concerns are being raised that there could be a shortage of wool within two to three years. I would just mention this in passing because I do think that the industry still has a long way to go to get itself back on its feet and in a strong healthy position where it can withstand the ups and downs of the market as it always has in the past. I again emphasise the point that many of the problems the wool industry faces today can be traced back to the fateful decision in 1987. I think that while the member for Burke might be doing some of his reflection he might reflect on that too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to participate in this discussion on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. I will be confining my remarks to those elements of the bill that deal with the health of the poultry industry in Australia and, in particular, the amendments that deal with the changes to the way levies are placed on the industry to allow commitments to the Australian Animal Health Council, and the change in recognising the new industry representative organisation for the egg industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments that I want to make today are in the area of cooked chicken. It is an area that is of great concern to the future of the poultry industry. I acknowledge that the measures that are included in this bill are ones which some elements of the industry would recommend, but the issues that I want to speak about today I am sure are of direct concern to large numbers of people who are involved in the poultry industry in Australia.
My concern was triggered by an article in the Australian Financial Review of 16 May, headed `Howard in trouble if chicken ban lifted'. It read:
The federal government is likely to accept a recommendation that the import ban on cooked chicken meat be lifted in a move that looks set to enrage both chicken farmers and its own backbench.
It went on to say:
The ban on chicken exports was a key issue in some marginal seats during the election in March, such as the seat of Paterson, where chicken farmers lobbied heavily for the ban to be maintained.
It went on to mention that the industry employs 16,000 people in Australia, with retail sales of around $1.7 billion. It said:

BREAK.PARA: The National Party, of which Mr Anderson, the minister, is a member, has in the past vigorously defended the export ban in parliament—
that is the ban on the importation of cooked chicken meat—
on the basis of production subsidies from potential competitors such as the US and the EC and cheap labour and tax incentives in Thailand, which is now a major exporter.

The reason I am concerned, is that there is a large number of people who live on the central coast of New South Wales whose direct livelihood depends on the future of the Australian poultry industry. The central coast branch of the Chicken Growers Association, which represents 90 poultry farmers on the central coast in the Gosford‐Wyong area, supports a continuation of the ban. They have recently put out a statement saying that it will be a big threat, not just to the future of the poultry industry, but to Australia's native wildlife, if cooking protocols are not followed overseas and we increase the risk of newcastle disease making its way to Australia.

Mr George Sidiropoulos, the president of the central coast branch of the Chicken Growers Association, has made the point quite strongly in my own local area about the importance of making sure that the risk of newcastle disease coming to Australia is not increased by measures which the government is currently contemplating, if it has not already implemented them.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I think we all acknowledge the economic importance of this industry. I would like today to touch on just a few of the concerns I have about the government's proposals in this area. This consideration has been triggered by applications from the United States, Denmark and Thailand for permission to import chicken meat to Australia. I acknowledge that Australia, as a country that depends on exports for a significant proportion of our gross domestic product, has to be a country that plays fair in the international trading game. But I think we have to be very careful about opening up Australia's markets in a way that exposes our domestic industries to the risk of imported disease. One of the countries seeking to export chicken meat to Australia is the United States. The US is a great believer in talking about free trade, but if you ask people involved in the meat export industry of Australia they will tell you that they do not exactly have free trade with the United States in exporting meat to that country. There are any number of products that we in Australia cannot export to the United States because they do not exactly believe in a level playing field as far as trade is concerned in many products that affect their rural industries.

With Thailand, we know that there are significant import duties and restrictions placed on many Australian manufactured goods so that they cannot be exported to Thailand today. I am not saying that means that we should not allow any imports from those countries. Far be it from me to argue against such a restrictive trade policy. But I think that Australia does have the right to say that, if countries are demanding that we open up our markets for cooked chicken imports, we should be allowed to look at the performance of countries such as the United States, Thailand, and Denmark, for that matter, as to how open their markets are for other Australian products.

The reason why I have concerns, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that AQIS, the Quarantine Inspection Service, quite freely admits that there is a concern about avian influenza and newcastle disease in Thailand. The United States also has difficulties with avian influenza. Also, the US has not yet completed its eradication program for salmonellosis, a particularly virulent version of the salmonella virus. These concerns also extend to some elements of diseases that affect the poultry industry in Denmark. So, for all of these reasons, I think it is fair for us to ask AQIS to ask the government what risk we are exposing our domestic poultry industry to by importing cooked chicken meat into Australia.
I would like to refer to an AQIS pamphlet on newcastle disease that says the following:

Newcastle disease, the most feared avian disease in the world, has penetrated into most countries. Australia so far is free from the pathogenic forms of this disease. When the disease first enters a country it can cause havoc in the bird industry. Commercial flocks, fancy birds, pet birds and native wild birds are all susceptible. Thousands of birds may die. Those that appear to recover can pass the disease on to healthy birds and may themselves remain chronically ill for the rest of their lives. There is no known cure for Newcastle disease. The disease is caused by a virus, so drugs do not help. Birds continue dying even if heavily medicated.

That is what AQIS says about newcastle disease. While AQIS might think that there is an acceptable risk in allowing cooked chicken imports from these countries, my concern is that AQIS always acknowledges that there is no such thing as zero risk when you are importing products from these countries.

I would like the government to explain to us how they have tried to weigh up the balance between the risk of damage they are exposing the Australian poultry industry to as a result of these diseases and the benefits they believe will flow to the Australian economy by allowing these imports. I can certainly remind the House that members of the coalition have in the past raised a number of concerns about the import of cooked chicken meat.
In a speech to the House in 1995 the current Chief Government Whip, the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), made the following remarks:

In the chicken meat industry, the economic gain to consumers is said to be about $3 million a year. The cost to the industry if there were an outbreak of newcastle disease is estimated, on average, at about $30 million a year. So if we get one outbreak in a 10‐year period, any economic advantage is lost immediately.

So Mr Cadman certainly had concerns back in 1995. The member for Maranoa and current Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Bruce Scott, made the following remarks in 1994 when speaking on behalf of the then opposition in a debate on primary industries:
The possible relaxation of Australian quarantine regulations relating to imported chicken meat is of great concern to the domestic industry.
He went on to say:

Naturally, there is concern for the impact on local producers, but just as important is the concern for the possible introduction of the world's most feared disease in the poultry industry, the newcastle virus.

I might also add a local flavour by bringing to the attention of the Main Committee the views of the state Liberal member for Gosford, Mr Chris Hartcher. He was reported in the local paper this week, under the headline `MP warns against meat trade', as saying:

Gosford MP Chris Hartcher claims the Federal Government proposal to allow cooked chicken meat to be imported into Australia would jeopardise the Central Coast's multi‐million dollar poultry industry and threaten Australia's native bird populations.
He goes on to say:
While there would be certificates saying the product complied with health regulations there is no doubt that there would be abuses and forgeries.

This is in places such as Thailand. Those are comments by Chris Hartcher, the Liberal state member for Gosford, attacking the federal government over this decision. Mr Hartcher also claims the introduction of cooked chicken meat would provide a perfect opportunity for newcastle disease to find its way into Australia to infect native bird species.

All those concerns expressed by Liberal and National party members of parliament in the past demonstrate that the Labor Party is not the only party concerned about the risk that newcastle disease poses to the Australian poultry industry. The former member for Paterson, Bob Horne, the current member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) and even you, Mr Deputy Speaker (Mr Adams), when you are wearing another hat as the member for Lyons, have expressed concern about this issue and the impact it might have on Australia's native birds and the Australian poultry industry.

You can understand why the former member for Paterson has been so concerned about the impact on the poultry industry because 2,000 people are employed in that industry in the electorate of Hunter. It is an industry that is very important to the central coast.

I am pleased that my colleague the member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) has joined us in the Main Committee. I understand that at this stage he might not be able to speak, given that he is to make his maiden speech within the next day or two. If he is not able to speak today, he might make some remarks at a future time of his choosing.

The point to make about this is that it is an issue of vital importance to the central coast and the poultry industry and one that I hope might have continuing bipartisan support, given the comments that have been made by Mr Hartcher and by Liberal members when they were in opposition.

I will turn very briefly to the last point I would like to make, and that is about some remarks that were made this week by Senator Parer, the representative of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in the Senate. After mentioning a quarantine risk assessment into the potential impact of imports of chicken meat from the USA, Thailand and Denmark, he said that this could be looked after by having the AQIS staff carry out prior inspection of the Thai processing plants. He made the following remarks:

Importation from Thailand would be subject to prior inspection by AQIS of the Thai processing plants. AQIS will publish a statement within a few days setting out the detailed arrangements under which the importation of cooked chicken meat from these countries will be allowed.

But my colleague Senator Bryant Burns asked Senator Parer whether there would be a continuing presence of the AQIS officers to ensure that the quality of the process was maintained after the production process started and that there was a continuing inspection process. Senator Burns asked on 20 May:
Given that there are reports in the press from time to time about the lack of integrity of some people in Thailand, will there be a presence of AQIS to ensure the quality of that particular process?
Senator Parer says this:

I understand your concerns on this matter. I think that you probably missed what I said in the response. What I did say was, in regard to Thailand, that anything to do with that area in regard to chicken meat would be subject to prior inspection by AQIS of their processing plants. As I also indicated to you—
