and then Senator Burns interjects:
Continual.
Senator Parer responds:
Yes. There will be a statement in a few days setting out the detailed arrangements.

That is contradictory. On the one hand, Senator Parer says that there will only be prior inspection by AQIS. Yet, in response to Senator Burns's interjection asking whether there would be continuing inspection by AQIS, Senator Parer says that there will be continuing inspection by the AQIS officers. At the very least we are entitled to have that matter clarified. If the AQIS staff are only going to carry out these inspections once at the very beginning, there is no guarantee whatsoever that tough standards will be maintained and that we are minimising the risk.

My preference—and this is the strong view of people involved in the poultry industry on the central coast—is that we do not take any risk with the importation of cooked chicken meat, whether or not we have AQIS inspectors in Thailand. But I certainly would like to know what the government's plans are in deciding to allow chicken meat to be imported into Australia. This is an issue that I, and I hope many other members of both sides of the House, will be raising on many occasions in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, is a composite bill that covers a number of issues, and the previous speaker has taken the opportunity to raise matters relevant to the chicken industry. It is of grave concern, of course, to his constituents and those of other members in the government that those matters be properly addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: As a representative of an area that produces a substantial amount of wool, I wish to address the issues relevant to Wool International and Wool International Holdings that are also covered in this legislation. The legislation, as the minister points out in his second reading speech, is designed to have an amendment which widens the opportunity of Wool International in terms of its activities. Wool International today is a body set up primarily to dispose of the wool stockpile, and I would like to come back to some aspects of that if time permits.

Early in its development there was a considerable debate because the original enabling legislation made it possible for Wool International to become a privatised public company. There was an intention, I think, on behalf of its bureaucracy or executive and its board of directors to turn itself into some major wool trading organisation using as its capital base any surplus associated with the disposal of the stockpile and other items referred to in this legislation as non‐wool assets, such as wool stores, that have become part of the original wool corporation activities.

The problem that we have with all of this is that, notwithstanding the desires of the board and bureaucracy of Wool International, most wool growers have indicated that they would not want a company created with those funds and the consequent issue of shares to them to cover the contribution they made to this particular establishment through the wool tax, which is also referred to in this legislation. They made it clear that, when this particular arrangement is completed, wool growers want their money back. They want the surplus distributed in cash. They do not want another body active in wool marketing which they have to fund.

Consequently, of course, the directors and others had a short opportunity for employment. There is a point in time when the last bale of wool will be sold under the compulsory fixed disposal arrangements. They, of course, are now having another try to prove to the wool industry that they would serve a longer term purpose. I object to this attempt and think that this particular legislation as proposed is totally unnecessary. Nevertheless, it is still before us and it is to be considered by this House today. I would argue very strongly that it is not needed and, in fact, that it represents very grave risks to the funds of wool growers.
The point is that the proposal as listed in the legislation is quite generic. I will read from the explanatory memorandum in this regard. It says:

BREAK.PARA: 14. Wool International is to be given power to undertake, through a subsidiary such as Wool International Holdings, wool marketing activities, including forward trading and the use of futures and currency contracts for hedging purposes. The amendments would facilitate Wool International undertaking a limited program of forward trading to assist in the development of a broader range of risk management options for the industry.

15. This program would be subject to strict conditions contained in the approval required from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to ensure, amongst other things, the trading activities are kept separate from those of Wool International proper, whose main concern will remain the management of the stockpile.

I feel that those final words are in fact a contradiction in themselves. The first problem that we have with this arrangement is the suggestion that a subsidiary of the proprietor of over two million bales of wool would be seen in the forward marketing and futures marketing area as somehow being totally at arm's length from a trading organisation of that size. It is just a foolish suggestion. It is an established fact that people trying to deal in that market would see the ability of Wool International to affect the market by its disposal policies. There is no way that it could convince those people otherwise. I find there is a contradiction in any suggestion that Wool International Holdings, this proposed company, could go to the point of being an arms length operative in the futures market.

We have to ask ourselves why the wool industry's future would be better effected by this particular proposed activity. The legislation, which is totally blue sky, just enables the minister to approve various schemes that Wool International might put to the minister from time to time. So we are here today giving that power to the minister but we do not know exactly how it might apply. The minister, in his second reading speech, did put forward some conditions as to how the matter might be controlled, and some conditions on himself. Because of debates within our party forums he has proposed a sunset clause. He has also proposed that the proposals be a disallowable instrument with three days notice.

Nevertheless, it does not change the fundamental question: why would substantial amounts of wool growers' money be required to be used for this purpose? The purpose must be a benefit to wool growers. When we look at the potential benefit, someone might argue that there is a need for futures or forward trading. That need is adequately met at present. There is a body known as the Sydney Futures Exchange which will trade you a contract on wool futures at any time you like to contact them. The Macquarie banking people have just announced an insurance policy whereby wool growers for a fee can insure the price of their wool at some time in the future. Clearly, the fee would reflect the amount of money they hope to get at the time. The only certainty of futures selling is that there is always a winner and a loser. History, I think, would prove that wool growers have been more the loser than the winner in these transactions.

Then, of course, there are the major wool brokers. Any wool producer can get them on the phone and say, `Look, I'm going to shear in October. I've got this particular wool style and here are the details associated with it in terms of micron measurement et cetera. How much will you give me for it?' Those companies will quote you a price. The price might not be one that you would like to get, but the company will do it. So there is a plethora of forward selling and forward risk management opportunities available to wool growers. So the question might be asked: what is the involvement of Wool International through Wool International Holdings going to do to improve that situation?

Most of my wool growers tell me that they have tried forward marketing from time to time and not found it to have improved their lot. Any suggestion that it would address what is currently a tragic decline in wool prices, particularly with a reputed investment of $24 million, is patently ridiculous. There is no way that anybody could intervene in the wool market at the futures or forward marketing level and try to shift the price, other than with billions of dollars and that would also be a grave risk. When you enter into the futures markets there always has to be a second person. There are some very, very big investors around the world who literally speculate in futures. If they saw an opportunity to corrupt one market with just pure money they would do it. You would need a lot of money to take them on.

So the reality is that, although the legislation does not tell us, we have a situation where up to $24 million of wool growers' money is to be taken out of Wool International, and made available for this particular body, Wool International Holdings, to be used to play on the futures market. As members of this House, that is as much as we know about what might happen. Admittedly, the minister tells us when it ceases to be blue sky. I do not know why we have to legislate for blue sky. I have seen examples of that in Western Australia. They used to call it WA Inc.

The reality is that we are going to have a look at that. When we do, the minister may or may not approve of it, depending on the comments. Considering his determination to have this piece of legislation, I am convinced that he will want to go on with it. But I do not see benefit for my wool growers. I see grave risk with the money. An official of Wool International actually gave me a very good promise. He said that, if they lost the $24 million, he could promise me that they would not spend any more. But there is a serious opportunity of additional funds being called on if there is some argument that the thing is working positively. I do not know for whom because, unless it affects the price of wool, there is little benefit for wool growers. I am totally opposed to the argument that these sorts of bodies can actually make profits for wool growers through their own investment strategies. At the moment, we can see this in the wheat industry fund where money is being taken forcibly from the wheat growers and they are being told that wonderful profits are being made for them at about 17 per cent.

In the case of Wool International and Wool International Holdings, you have the huge stockpile made available through the pooling system of the Australian Wheat Board and you can sell wheat to the subsidiary that does the private domestic trading. Of course, you can make any amount of profit you like simply by discounting the pool wheat to yourself. That is being done and, in my view, it is the reason for these substantial profits. But, of course, the person who has delivered wheat to the pools is the loser. Of course, if Wool International Holdings eventually starts declaring profits, it is because it has been buying wool from the stockpile for a lower price than it might otherwise sell. They tell us that it is all commercial and above board; they tell us that they never talk to each other in private. That is rubbish; we all know better.

In my last few minutes, having expressed my total opposition to this component of the legislation—it is all in a single bill—I want to say that there are some good parts in it. We are very pleased that the minister has decided to change the wool tax collection arrangements and to put them under regulation. In fact, the wool tax, compared to the research levies, will come down to zero. I approve of that wholeheartedly. It leaves the legislation as a package and, consequently, I am not planning to vote against it. But, on behalf of my constituents, I want the opportunity to express my opposition to this proposal and to give them a guarantee that, when the fine detail is made available to us, I will be looking at it extremely closely. I hope other members in this place will take note of the fact that it will be a disallowable instrument. If they think it is not in the interest of the wool growers they represent, I hope they choose to take some action in that regard. I can assure them that, if that is my view, they will have my support.

Finally, I would like to comment on the very serious circumstances confronting the wool industry which we should be debating today. We should be debating initiatives to get the price of wool up. There are a few factors that need to be known including the fact that stockpile disposal and wool production—if we include that stockpile disposal as part of wool production—is not high in Australia. We have certainly seen a period in international markets where demand has been low. But production is also low in Australia and it is very unusual for wool prices to continue to decline in that situation, if we were relying purely on the auction system. We are not. Wool International has decided that, to meet its fixed disposal obligations, it will sell by forward trading. It has consequently destroyed all confidence in the auction system.

I will never forget the remarks made by a wool broker during the debates on the collapse of the reserve price scheme. He said, `As a wool broker, I do not care how high the price of wool goes; but I have one very serious concern, and that is the price that my competitor will pay for wool tomorrow.' That is what drives the market—what your competitor might buy wool for tomorrow. Of course, once they cannot control that through the auction system, they can only insure themselves by constantly bidding less. The reason why they are being obliged to bid less is that you get a big price on Tuesday at auction and you know very well that Wool International is on the phone while you are bidding, selling wool at a lower price to some other buyer. There is very little confidence. Nobody is carrying stockpiles. Everybody has run down their stocks. They are not prepared to take a long‐term risk in wool. It was not that many years ago that speculators made money by buying wool at auction—actually physically taking control of it, storing it and reselling it at a later time. It was part of the system, and it worked, and it should be happening now.

There is a big debate in Western Australia about what should happen. I have constituents who argue that the stockpile should be frozen again; I have constituents who argue that all of the fixed release should go on the auction system at no reserve and let the market fix it up; and there are a few ideas in the middle. I have to tell you that, as a free marketeer, I tend to lean towards the auction system. I do not support the freezing of the stockpile. I would be happy to look at alternatives in between if I could be convinced that they will work.

But we are not talking about that; we are talking about pie in the sky. We are not confronting an issue that could return billions to people in the wool industry who need it, billions to the nation in terms of additional export income, and, of course, hundreds of millions to the revenue of the government, which is sorely needed in these difficult times to fill that $8 billion black hole.

The reality is that this is what the debate should be about. I hope that there are members in this place who will demand of the government that we get onto that issue, because there does not seem to be any practical or proper reason why wool prices continue to decline. I believe that the major reason is lack of confidence generated by the current selling policies of Wool International, which I think is the worst possible option. One of the other options that I have mentioned would be better.

We really need to address that, and we need to address it with alacrity, because it is a tragedy for everyone for which there seems to be no good reason, other than this lack of confidence. So I would ask the House to consider that. I ask the House to look very closely at the detail of this proposal for Wool International Holdings when it is brought to the House and to deal with it accordingly. I cannot see that it is going to do any good for wool growers. I cannot see how it is going to work. I fear greatly that, even through administrative costs, if not through speculative costs, $24 million of wool growers' money could be lost. It is their money, and they are entitled to have it returned to them at the end of this scheme and not wasted by some people who are trying to guarantee their future, not the wool growers' future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) contains some very important stuff. I think one of the problems we have with the committee system is that it can very easily get buried. I did not realise just how important this was until this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to touch on aspects of the bill. The first part of the bill seeks to deal with the Offshore Minerals Act 1994. What it tends to do is to guarantee the integrity of leases when they are affected by changes to the boundary between Commonwealth and state lands. I entirely support that. The bill does not make it quite clear whether this is retrospective. I believe that it should be retrospective to the enactment of this bill. I know of a couple of places where new surveying has changed the state‐Commonwealth boundary, with significant detrimental effect on people, and I would hope that they would be protected by this very essential amendment here.

The member for Dobell (Mr Lee) spoke at some length on AQIS and quarantine matters. I cannot find it in the bill—and, of course, it is not in the bill—but it does deal with the chicken industry. I entirely support the member for Dobell. I believe that AQIS and the government should take a very hard line with respect to entry of disease into Australia and I believe that we are lessening resolve in this area.

I do not mind if we are taken by competitors to the world authorities on GATT because I have always believed that GATT is, in fact, a very corrupt document and it is not the way for Australia to go. Every time there has been a significant amendment to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade principal traders have gone out and simply found a way around the new agreement. The French have been notable in this regard and I take my hat off to the French. I think that the French have always acted in the interests of their citizens and that is what governments are for. I believe that this is something the government of this country should certainly consider.

I now want to talk about wool. It must be remembered that basically this bill comes from the previous government. I find it passing strange that the new government has so enthusiastically embraced it because I think it is a very flawed document indeed. It is true that this government has made amendments to the part relating to Wool International Holdings, which is what I wanted to talk about. I think that this has made the act better but in my view it is still not good enough.

This was a proposal that arose from minister Collins who, I can say now, never understood the wool industry and never really cared about it. It was a very dangerous move indeed. The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has spoken at length about this and I agree with a lot of what he has said. I want to foreshadow that I will be dissenting from this bill and I will be seeking a division on the matter in the chamber. I do so for very good reasons.

I see no reason at all why anyone would be giving Wool International Holdings $24 million of growers' money. I see that it has done nothing to justify it and, if it wants to justify it, I believe that it should be putting out a prospectus. There are many companies floated on the stock market with a capitalisation of less than this. If Wool International Holdings thinks that it has a saleable commodity, it should be putting out a prospectus meeting the requirements of the Australian Securities Commission and seeing what support it gets from the market. I am sure that it would not get support from growers; it may get it from elsewhere. To say that it is going to initiate changes in marketing is a very dubious proposition. All the things that it talks about are in place already and growers can use them.

I would suggest that futures selling was probably something which originated with the wool industry. It has been used very successfully by the gold industry. I think the reason is that the gold industry has used it as an insurance scheme, not as a gambling scheme. I believe that farmers and wool growers use it as an insurance policy, not as a casino. It is a very useful tool. If they use it as a casino they are inevitably going to get burnt because the house always wins in that scenario.

The member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) was talking about the history of the wool industry. I thought that he was rather harsh on John Kerin. The truth is that had John Kerin opposed raising the wool price under the madman, David Asimus, he would have been hounded and condemned. Fortunately, Asimus was not allowed to put it to 1,000c as he wanted to but it went to 870c, which was fine. That was the floor; it went above that.

I was one of the people who fought for the establishment of a floor price back in the very early 1970s. While it was a price set just below the cost of production, it probably did not do a lot of damage, although, faced with the same decision, I certainly would not support it again. When these people, led by Asimus, decided to make a price leader they were doomed.

It is true that John Kerin dropped the price to 700c. It is also true that anyone who knew anything about the industry knew that it was unsustainable. I used to go into committees and argue with John Kerin, who would dump on me, then he would say to me in the corridor, `Of course, you are absolutely right, but I have to hold the line for the government.' He knew, because he was a competent economist, that the 700c was untenable. I believe he should have spoken out about it and said so at the time, but he was under enormous pressure.

He certainly was not helped by the people who run the industry—the clowns that have encompassed the Wool Corporation and the various people who have been elected to the Wool Council. I think the former member for Wannon and his relation, Hugh Beggs, should come in for a fair amount of criticism with respect to the debacle that was wool marketing.

The truth about wool is that there is nothing that Wool International Holdings will do that is new or an initiative. If there is, it certainly has not been spelt out. If it believes it has something new, then it is its duty to tell us what it is. There is certainly nothing in the published material. I believe there are other people in the market who can do it as well.

What the member for O'Connor said is absolutely true. Even if you could trust Wool International Holdings to keep an arm's length agreement with Wool International and that stockpile, even if it was trustworthy in that regard—and believe me, it is not and it will not be able to isolate it—nobody out in the industry believes that it will. That confidence will not be there.

BREAK.PARA: I think that the member for O'Connor did touch on a very important point. There has been an enormous loss of confidence in wool marketing and it has been brought about by Wool International. It has been selling wool at discounted prices. It says, `Nobody complained when we were selling forward at high prices.' The truth was that any mug can sell forward in a rising market at a higher price. I do not believe it maximised the price on those occasions, but anyone can do that. But then to say that the corollary is to sell down in a falling market is absolutely absurd. It is my view that if the government is going to maintain sales for the stockpile, that wool should be dispersed through the auction system, with no reserve price at all. I am not convinced, as the member for O'Connor seems to be, that we need to do that. But certainly, if it going to be disposed of, it should be through the auction system, with no reserve price.

I believe that we do have to be very careful about the future of wool because it is in our capacity to destroy the wool market. The truth is that nobody in the world needs wool anymore. It is simply replaceable. But we do have a marketable commodity in Australian wool. I would argue that Australian wool is one of the few things—and perhaps the only thing—in Australia that is unique.

The CRA said in the paper today that if we mine coal, the Americans will mine it cheaper. If we grow wheat, the Americans will dump theirs on the market. Australian merino wool is the unique product that we have, yet what have we seen? We have seen Australian wool growers' money used to promote wool generically. In a shop, any garment can wear the wool label if it comes off a sheep. It does not really matter that the sheep has more in common with a wire‐haired fox terrier than a merino, it is still wool and it comes under this generic promotion which is paid for by the Australian wool growers. We should be selling Australian merino wool. It is a unique quality product.

I was in China some time ago on a committee. We asked to go to a store where the Chinese people shopped. We did not want to go into a Friendship store. We got into this place and up on the fifth floor they had a lot of the stuff that was commercially available. I was amazed at the high prices that people were paying. They had a bespoke tailor in there with a big sign which said, `Only the best British cloth used.' I was actually looking for cashmere, but I said to the sales assistant, `Do you have any Australian wool?' `Oh no', she said, `we stock only the very best British wool.'

I saw some jumpers on the counter and asked if could I have a look at one. It was a Pringle garment from one of those great mills along the English‐Scottish border that produce quality woollen knitwear. It did not have the woolmark on it at all, but it did have a label saying, `Guaranteed pure botany wool. Made in England.' So I said to the girl, `Look, this is Australian wool,' and she grabbed it from me, quite irate, and said `No, no sir, made in England.' That was to her British wool; a triumph of marketing of our product. I think we have been duped enormously by wool marketing.

When I finished wool classing—I think in 1956—the instructor said to us, `Every one of you will now go out and overclass the clip,' and of course every one of us did. He also said, `If you want a job in 50 years time, you have got to do something about the American market which is the highest fibre user in the world and the lowest consumer of wool.' Those statistics are very much the same today as they were then, despite $2 billion worth of Australian wool growers' money put into a failed attempt to increase promotion there. If you look at Zegna, they have been extraordinarily successful and North America is now one of their big markets. Their marketing approach was to send Jonathan Todhunter in there with a month's wages and say, `After that you are on your own,' and he was extremely successful. We spent $2 billion basically for nothing.

Quality is going to be the name of the game, yet we have seen in recent times the quality of our wool threatened by blending. I asked a question in the House about the blending of Russian wool with Australian wool. I was told firstly that it was not happening, then I was told it had already happened and we really could not do anything about it. There is no doubt the Russians decided to put their 20 micron wool on the market, looking for cash. The Russians do have some 20 micron wool and it is usually very badly faulted. I actually had documents showing where Australian buyers had been asked to get sound 24 micron Australian wool to blend with faulty 20 micron wool to make it 22 micron filament.

I know of one case of a very large spinner in Europe who recently went through this blending exercise. It produced a lot of thread using the Russian wool blended with the very good quality Australian wool, only to find the whole lot was radioactive. Imagine what that would have done, had it become general knowledge, to confidence in the wool market—to confidence in what we are promoting as a pure product.

The time has long passed when we should have been right out of generic wool. We should be selling not Australian wool but wool from various areas of Australia. I think we should be selling specialised lambs' wool from Albany, for instance, and quality wool from other areas. It should be a promotion of Australian wool—a unique fibre which is very free from impurities and a fibre which the world can have faith in.

If we actually believe there is going to be a future in wool, we have to take steps to protect our investment now. This means that we must put a ban on the export of our genetic material. It is crazy to do otherwise. I went to a lot of effort to get the agreement through the Labor Party caucus—by every appropriate means—that it ban the export of Australian genetic material. It took me 12 months. In that time I went to New Zealand and I consulted with New Zealand stud farmers who said they would be very happy to see a ban applied. They did it only because if they had not someone else would have done so. I got unanimity amongst the major wool studs and enormous support from growers.

The opposition came from a few greedy, grubby, second‐rate studs associated with the Australian Merino Breeders' Association. Those are the people who got to Collins. Collins, massively ignorant of the industry, marched into caucus and with very little effort got the caucus to roll the decision it had made and we did not get what was in Australia's interests. Some people say it is too late: not so. The great users of genetic material in the past have been the Soviet bloc, China and Russia. Through incompetence they wasted it. They put a ram out here and a ram out there, instead of putting them into breeding stations.

I believe the threat now comes from South America. The Italians are moving in there in a big way. Benetton is buying up large properties in South America. The Italians are not fools and they will not make the same mistake. I believe that we should act `yesterday' to ban the export of this genetic material. The Labor Party had the opportunity and through what I see as the perfidy and stupidity of Senator Collins it was lost. I certainly hope that, if this government seriously considers the future of the industry, it will move quickly to bring in that ban on genetic material. If it is not done I believe that the present system of allowing 900 rams a year will be our demise because, with new technologies, it might as well be nine million as 900. I sound that warning and urge the government to do something about it.

In the brief minutes left to me I want to talk about wool marketing. I believe we have to return more money to growers. Commodities throughout the world have been under pressure and the only way I can see out of this for growers is to move further down the production chain and retain ownership of their wool, perhaps down to the single white thread stage, maybe even beyond that. That is going to need some organisation. There is not just one way; there are many ways it can be done. I believe that we should look at doing the very fine wool in Australia.

For the 20, 22 and 24 micron fibres I suggest that India is the place to look. I believe that India has an industry more competent than that of the Chinese. It has labour costs that are comparable and it has a structure which I think is much easier to deal with than the Chinese. If this is pursued I think we could see a greater return to wool growers. It is quite clear that if there is not a greater return, what we are going to see in a very short time is growers in the great Australian wool industry—what was the largest small business in this nation and is an industry that is absolutely vital to the wellbeing of the hinterland of Australia—reduced to the status of peasant shepherds. That is not a future for the wool industry that I want to see.

I believe there is a future for the wool industry. I have great faith in it, but Wool International is not part of that future—Wool International is part of the problem. Garnaut's north‐east Asian ascendancy and the fools on both sides have led us down this mad chase into Asia—the Garnaut report in respect of the wool industry was another very flawed document—and I think it is about time we got a lot more commonsense and commitment into making sure that the wool industry survives as the viable industry that it should be. It should be remembered that if we can increase the value adding process to wool it will very quickly become Australia's biggest single export, exceeding coal. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is little doubt that in a debate like this there is a good deal of common ground. Indeed, on the first two packages concerning the extension of the baselines—that part of the legislation which really deals more with offshore minerals than it does with any other commodity—I think there is unanimity. The move is essential. I note the comments by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) about the timing of commencement. I do not know that it would be practical to backdate the legislation. There would be an advantage, if it were possible, but I am always very hesitant about retrogressive legislation. Therefore, I suggest that it should be at least proclaimed from the date when the legislation was first introduced. I do not know whether that part of it was introduced by the previous government. If it were, then it might be back to that date.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always had problems about applying legislation retrospectively and, for that reason, I would have hesitation accepting that part of his proposal. Quite demonstrably, there is a need to have more precision in the way in which the offshore baselines are defined and this legislation would in fact achieve that. So, in that part of the legislation, I am glad to see there is little opposition.

On the poultry industry amendments in the bill—before I come to the particular problem of poultry imports—I think every primary industry today has a major worry in trying to ensure that adequate research and promotion is undertaken. In relation to both the poultry industry and the wool industry, to which I want to make reference in a moment, I am quite concerned at the degree to which the emphasis within CSIRO has changed and the degree to which there is going to be a capacity within CSIRO for it to maintain the enormous input it has made in the past to ensure our products are competitive.

I do not know whether the CSIRO even undertakes much poultry research. It did in days gone by, but I am unsure whether it still does. In terms of maintaining poultry health and making sure the competitiveness of our poultry stock is such that, domestically and internationally, we can look at being able to produce birds that are fully internationally competitive in meat and egg production, I do not think there would be any denying that we need to maintain a level of commitment.

My worry in relation to the poultry industry has been the extent to which—as in so many other primary industries—the family operation is now prejudiced. The economics of survival are becoming more and more acute. We have had a succession of economic disasters in recent years. At present, one of the real problems in the poultry industry is the price of feed. While we are all conscious that, as a result of price surging largely due to a downturn of production in the American agricultural belt, grain prices are likely to be up this year, the real problem for people in intensive livestock industries—and I classify the poultry industry as one of those—is that they have to buy in so much of their feedstock.

As prices go up, their capacity to produce competitively is affected. It is a major concern and, as a result of it, many of the smaller growers are going out. The bigger growers are of a size that enables them to overwhelm, by their marketing and production techniques, the individual grower. I know in my own state, and in my own electorate which is the second largest poultry producing area in New South Wales, there are enormous problems in trying to remain competitive. I feel very sad for the sake of many of those who were very efficient poultry people in the days gone by. But once the state protection scheme was removed, I am afraid many of them have found it very hard to compete against the bigger operators.

So there is a worry. And it is not just a matter of looking at imports; it is a matter of ensuring that research and marketing are expanded. It is of interest to note that in the primary sector, almost uniquely, over the years there has been an enormous contribution from producers. Certainly through the levy scheme there has been a big contribution to ensure that they are maintaining collectively some capacity to research and develop their product. This legislation is introducing regulations for that very purpose.

On the matter raised first by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), I—like all of those who represent the poultry industry and, indeed, all agricultural industries—am worried about the import of disease into this country. One only has to see what has happened with the mad cow disease in the United Kingdom. It is true that our big advantage in the past has been our tremendous reputation for the purity of our stock. The fact that we are an island continent, that the oceans ensure there is distance and a quarantine barrier, has been a tremendous advantage to us.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie was talking about South America a while ago and future competition in the wool industry. One of our big advantages is that we have not had the disease problems that they have had in their cattle herds and their other livestock. We have to maintain that reputation and I, therefore, am one of those who believes that exactly the same protocols must apply to the production of poultry in any country that seeks to have their product imported into Australia, and that the country and the region have to be sufficiently isolated from any disease, such as newcastle disease, which could be introduced into this country.

I have never been happy about pork imports from Canada and I am no more happy about the prospect of poultry imports from Thailand or anywhere else. At the same time, unlike the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, I believe the Uruguay Round of the GATT was tremendously to our advantage. If we can have free and open trade, particularly in agricultural commodities, it is to Australia's advantage, and certainly to the advantage of our primary exporters.

For that reason I certainly believe that we have to comply within the overall intention of the world trade obligations that are now imposed on us. Yet I would hope that any protocols applied by AQIS—as to whose integrity in maintaining our quarantine borders I have always been rather sceptical—for the imported product are absolutely certain. Having been minister for primary industries when we first thought blue tongue had come into Australia, only to find that it was a non‐virulent strain of blue tongue, I do not want to see a circumstance where in any of our livestock industries we have any threat to local production. Of course, there is also the problem of a further competitive threat to those small and family owned operations of which I spoke a few moments ago.

The main part of this legislation on which I want to say a few words is the wool industry. First, the Australian wool industry is not one industry. There are more than 1,000 types of Australian wool. When people talk about the wool industry, they need to comprehend its diversity, from the superfines down to the strong wools. Those thousand types each have a different market.

I have been very concerned about the research side of the industry. I am appalled at any suggestion, for example, that in my own region the CSIRO research stations at Chiswick, Longford and Arding should be closed. I am most concerned at the impact on the animal production division of any prospective closure because of inadequate funding for research. In this bill there is talk of providing $24 million to Wool International, and I will come to that in a moment. I would far prefer that that $24 million be allocated to research and promotion. I am not happy at the way promotion has been handled in the recent years. I believe that the general drift in the market has been partly because the people responsible, first the Australian Wool Corporation and more recently Wool International, have not known what they have been promoting. They have moved from promoting superfine wool and wool as a quality product to wool in blends—they are really all over the shop. Part of the problem is that they have got to work out what they are going to promote and promote it, but I think it is important we maintain good promotions.

I know there are those who are cynical about what we have done, and I heard what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie said. If you promote a product effectively, it is amazing what you can do. The honourable member was talking about China. All you have to do is to think that the New Zealanders are selling the Chinese gooseberry as kiwi fruit in China to understand how effective marketing can be. It is ridiculous. Here is New Zealand, a small country, which has always been a hell of a lot better than we are in promoting its agricultural produce, actually selling in China, under its brand name, a product that comes from China! As the honourable member suggested, we have tended to be pretty appalling in the way we have marketed wool. We have got to do something about it. So, if we have got $24 million to spend, I would not mind spending it on research and promotion and get a bit of value for money rather than hand it to Wool International.

Having said that, I would point out that the intention of this legislation is not specifically to put Wool International into the business of marketing wool. It is rather to set up a framework to see what it has to offer. The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), when he opened the debate, intimated that it was really a product of legislation of the previous government. I think we have to try to see what Wool International is going to come up with, but my own assessment is that Macquarie Bank and others are introducing any amount of techniques for forward cover of wool. The futures market, as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie said, was in fact begun by Sid Hall in wool as a commodity before the Sydney Futures Exchange. It was Sid Hall's innovation in futures wool selling that began futures trading in Australia. So there have been ways by which you can cover wool in the future.

You are never going to sell wool in futures at a time when the market is declining. It demonstrably is going to make it very difficult for those techniques to succeed while the market is still floundering. Fortunately, it is now starting to recover. On a rising market there is an opportunity for the buyers to hedge, and I suspect that, if the market does remain about where it is at the moment, some vendors may even think of using the cover that Macquarie Bank is now offering. I think that there are any number of other ways through the Sydney Futures Exchange that wool can be already covered.

I am not too sure that Wool International has a role in hedging. I am one of those who are pretty sceptical about Wool International and its forward selling. I would have far preferred that some flexibility be introduced. I do not like the idea of its continuing to bear down on the market by offering wool forward at a rate which discounts the auction system. I believe that in some instances, by withdrawing wool from auction and then discounting it for forward sale, as Wool International asserts its scheduled selling, as a result of the Garnaut report, obligates it to do, it has forced the market down unnecessarily, and I think that it is very regrettable that that should be so.

I point out to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who is still in the chamber, that I was not here when my colleague the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) talked about the problems during the era that John Kerin was minister for primary industry. As far as I am concerned, the real guilt during John's term as minister for primary industry was his change of the Wool Marketing Act. Because the act that I had introduced so long before was changed, the industry was no longer required to retain price relativity to other fibres and this led to the 870c minimum reserve price.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the advice of the industry.

—You never take the advice of industry unless you know it is the right advice. Regrettably, the wool industry is still so divided that it does not know where it is going, and that is part of its problem today. I am very critical of the Wool Council; it has more opinions than there are wool growers. Frankly, until they make up their minds about what they are going to do, we are going to have strife.

SPEECH.PARA: When I introduced that old minimum reserve price scheme, it was essential that the price maintain relativity to the price of other fibres. Had that been retained, wool would not have risen to 870c and the fall to 700c would have been a slower fall because, as other price relativity was maintained, this would have ensured that wool came down. Of course there were other factors and, as far as I am concerned, there is no use turning back the clock. I want to look at tomorrow.

Wool is a fibre for the future. As I have said, there are thousands of different wool types. The superfine wool that is in the best fabrics is a wool that can blend. It can be used for all sorts of new products. One of the reasons I am interested in the $24 million going into building up the money for research and promotion is that, as wool incomes are down, the producers are less able, through levies, to maintain the funding. I want the efforts of CSIRO and others to be maintained to develop markets and so on. In fact, at the moment, there is a new fabric that uses wool to line synthetic fibre. This is a tremendous athletic fibre because it allows the body to breathe but still gives the external attributes of a synthetic fibre. There are all sorts of things that can be done to ensure that wool has different markets in the future. I am in favour of the legislation because I do not believe that it will give Wool International the final authority to go into trading. At least it will enable us to see the new techniques that Wool International believes can be used in the future.In my view, Wool International does not have a future. I would be quite happy to see it wound up. I would like to see that $24 million go into research and promotion. I think it would probably be better used. I am happy to develop what they have apparently spent some time in developing. I do not want the money to be spent until the parliament has had a look at the legislation. I am delighted to see that, as it is to be by regulations which can be revoked within three sitting days, there is going to be an opportunity to do that.

The key items of the program were laid down by the minister in his second reading speech. If they come up with each of his requirements, I will be very surprised. He has set down very tight requirements; I will be looking forward to seeing what is submitted. I urge Wool International to make sure that every member of parliament sees that proposal and has an opportunity to discuss it before any regulations are drafted to implement the spending of the money. As several members have said, it is a field of some controversy and the views on what should be done with the stockpile and the ways in which wool should be marketed in the future are really extraordinarily diverse. It is very important, before this program is implemented, that everybody has a chance to see it and consider it. It is important that we do not just leave it in the hands of the industry. As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie said, some of their advice in the past has perhaps been the genesis of some of the problems of today.
Question unresolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the question is unresolved, in order to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277 the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.
